title: house prices uk rightmove index landlords first time buyer figures data
story: Average asking price of property rose by just one per cent over the last month (Image: Dan KitwoodGetty Images)AS NEWS this morning that the average asking price of property rose by just one per cent over the last month, the lowest monthly rate of increase at this time of year since 2010, indications are that a storm is brewing in the UK property market - but not just as a result of possible no-deal Brexit.&nbspThe slowdown, as reported today by property search portal Rightmove, suggests that the currently subdued conditions are as a result of a weakening at entry level, where the price of properties with two bedrooms or less which are normally the ideal rental investment, are falling in some areas.&nbspThat&rsquos because due to changes in the way that buy to let investors will be taxed from next year, many are holding off purchasing further properties or indeed are beginning to exit the sector altogether.&nbsp                Property for sale: Five bed house on the market for just &pound35,000                Brexit uncertainty has mixed affect on housing market across the UKAs recent figures from lending trade body UK Finance indicate, mortgage approvals for new buy to let purchases are currently down by 14 per cent compared to a year ago and reduced by 53 per cent compared to three years ago.&nbspThe changes to the way that landlords are taxed, otherwise known as Section 24, was actually announced in the 2015 Budget by the then Chancellor, George Osborne.&nbspWhilst it&rsquos been public knowledge for some time - buy to let investors have been paying additional stamp duty on their purchases since 2016 - it&rsquos estimated that as many as half of all landlords in the UK with buy to let mortgages are unaware that they will soon have to pay more tax on their rental income, with the effects ostensibly starting in January 2019 and increasing over the next few years as the amount payable to the treasury increases.&nbspThe changes in taxation were announced by former Chancellor George Osborne back in 2015 (Image: Leon NealGetty Images)Many industry commentators have suggested that spring 2019 will see a significant amount of properties owned by landlords hitting the market as they realise that buy to let is no longer a viable investment for them, spurred on by their self-assessment statement in January which, for many, may be the first inkling of what&rsquos in store.&nbspBrian Murphy, Head of Lending for Mortgage Advice Bureau suggested that creating reduced demand from investors was perhaps in the government&rsquos plan all along, explaining that: &ldquoMany in the industry have long held the view that the introduction of increased taxation on landlords was partly designed to create this very situation, and help to enable more First Time Buyers to purchase their own property due to lack of competition with landlords for the same properties.&nbsp&nbsp&ldquoSo, to that end, more stock at entry level with prices softening may assist that strategy.Brian went on to say: &ldquoObviously, the introduction of the reduction in mortgage interest rate relief, which is a phased process, doesn&rsquot affect those landlords who aren&rsquot leveraged. &nbsp&ldquoHowever, for those who do have borrowings against investment properties and who haven&rsquot as yet taken measures to mitigate their tax position, the additional tax that they will be paying from the next year may make it less viable for them to stay in the sector. &nbsp&nbspHalf of landlords with buy to let mortgages are unaware they will soon have to pay more tax (Image: Matt CardyGetty Images)Of course, the upside in all of this is that those at the very start of their home ownership journey might now have a better chance of getting their foot on the ladder, due to a combination of more suitable properties on the market, lower pricing and as of last year, an exemption on stamp duty.&nbspMiles Shipside, Director of Rightmove, commented on the report&rsquos findings: &ldquoWith the government using the tax system to try and help first time buyers while deterring out-of-favour landlords, prices in this sector have been subdued as intended.&nbsp&ldquoThat gives aspiring first time buyers an autumn opportunity to negotiate a favourable deal. The story at this time of year for the last five years has been an average autumn bounce of 1.6 per cent in the price of property coming to market.&nbsp&ldquoWhilst all regions have seen a monthly rise, this year has a more subdued narrative with only a one per cent uplift. &nbsp&ldquoWhile the backdrop of political uncertainty and stretched buyer affordability remains the same, this month has price drops at the bottom of the market dragging down the national average.Property market (Image: JOHN MACDOUGALLAFPGetty Images)Miles added: &ldquoWhile landlords were hit with a three per cent stamp duty surcharge on property purchases back in April 2016, in contrast most first time buyers were effectively awarded stamp duty-free status in November 2017.&nbsp&ldquoThe fall in prices at the bottom of the market during what is, traditionally, a busier time means that those keen to sell need to price accordingly, which gives an opportunity for those stamp duty-free first time buyers to negotiate harder.At the coal face, Robert Lazarus, MD of Paramount Properties in North West London, observed: &ldquoThere&rsquos a better opportunity for first time buyers coming in to the market at the minute compared to a couple of years ago, especially if they&rsquore looking for a one bed flat.&nbsp&ldquoBefore the additional stamp duty on second homes came in we were selling 20 per cent of these flats to landlords which was driving prices up, and now we&rsquore selling less than five per cent of them to landlords, giving first time buyers the first pick of new stock that comes on.Another layer to this complex picture would be the rumoured introduction in the Autumn Budget of capital gains tax relief for landlords who sell to long-term tenants. &nbsp&nbspIf true, this could generate a unique opportunity for those who want to exit the sector to work with those who want to buy, thus creating a win-win scenario for both parties.&nbsp&nbspHowever, with latest research from the National Landlords Association suggesting that as many as a fifth of all landlords may leave the sector over the next two years, potentially removing up to 980,000 privately rented properties from the UK&rsquos housing stock, the upwards pressure on rents that this shift in the market might create is not to be under-estimated.&nbsp&nbspGood news for landlords with a long-term investment view, but not so positive for those who, out of necessity, have to rent their home rather than buy.&nbsp

story: Speaking to Sky's Sophy Ridge, the leading eurosceptic claimed it was time Theresa May put the ball back into the EU's court and scrapped the Brexit backstop clause agreed in the December 2016 white paper.&nbspMr Duncan Smith also urged Cabinet ministers to make their concerns very clear to the Prime Minister and avoid a little cabal outside government making their&nbspdecisions.&nbspHe said: &ldquoI do say to anyone who is in Cabinet and has concerns about this, you have to make them very clear to the Prime Minister.&ldquoWe mustn&rsquot have a little cabal outside cabinet running this.                Brexiteers ATTACK post-EU preparations in OPEN LETTER                Theresa May faces Brexit MUTINY as David Davis urges Cabinet rebellion&ldquoIt has to be a cabinet decision. More importantly, I think the real question here is we have a very strong set of cards to play.&ldquo&pound39 billion and security are all on the table at the moment and the EU and BMW are now beginning to moan.&ldquoI have a very simple message to the Prime Minister.&ldquoIt&rsquos great that you&rsquore going to be a bloody difficult woman over something, it&rsquos an absolute real strength when you&rsquore on the right course.&ldquoBut when you&rsquore not on the right course sometimes you have to take a pace back and say &lsquois there a better way?&rsquo.&ldquoAnd I think there is a better way to do this which is to put the ball back into the EU&rsquos court and say &lsquolook, we have never accepted this backstop. It&rsquos a ludicrous political intervention, you now must agree with us.Brexit news: IDS calls on Theresa May to 'put Brexit ball into EU's court' (Image: &bullSKY)&ldquo&lsquoThere will never be a hard border with or without a deal.&rsquo&ldquoAnd then, full Canada plus plus plus deal is on the table.It comes as former Brexit Secretary David Davis called for a cabinet mutiny over Theresa May&rsquos &ldquoflawed Brexit plan.Mr David urged ministers to rebel and &ldquoexert their collective authority as the &ldquomoment of truth over Britain leaving the EU approaches.Mr Davis said: &ldquoThis is one of the most fundamental decisions that Government has taken in modern times.&ldquoIt is time for Cabinet members to exert their collective authority. This week the authority of our constitution is on the line.&ldquoThe EU has already offered us a Canada-style, zero-tariffs trade agreement, and Donald Tusk, president of the council, reinforced that offer last week.&ldquoA good deal is clearly within our grasp. We must reset our negotiating strategy immediately and deliver a Brexit that meets the demands of the referendum and the interests of the British people.The Northern Ireland border remains a major Brexit stumbling block, with the EU wanting the province to remain within its rules in the event of a &ldquobackstop to keep the border open.But the DUP and Mrs May have both ruled out the proposal.Mr Davis takes aim at &ldquofundamental flaws in the government&rsquos Brexit strategy, slamming the &ldquounwise decision in December to accept the EU&rsquos language on dealing with the Northern Ireland border.Plans for keeping the UK within the EU customs&rsquo union until the Northern Ireland border was resolved are &ldquoill-conceived, he added, and could lead to Britain being &ldquotrapped.

story: Tory Eurosceptic Jacob Rees-Mogg has played down reports he would align himself with the DUP and Labour to vote down the Budget over Brexit demands.Speaking to Sky News, the prominent Brexiteer campaigner distanced himself from the Unionists, who are&nbspplanning to vote down the Chancellor's Budget.&nbspA vote against the Budget would plunge the Government into chaos and could even trigger a no-confidence vote.The Northern Ireland party are furious at Prime Minister Theresa May's plans to cast off the territory by leaving them inside the EU customs union.                Brexiteers could VOTE DOWN Budget 'to BLOCK &pound39bn orce bill'                Jacob Rees-Mogg warns May she&rsquos UNDERESTIMATING Brexiteers as MPs v...DUP leader Arlene Foster has warned: &ldquoI appreciate the risks of a no deal Brexit but the dangers of a bad deal are worse.Mrs May relies on DUP support in key votes to prop up her minority Conservative leadership.Mr Rees-Mogg attacked the Irish border arrangement proposed by the Government and again urged Mrs May to ditch her Chequers plan.But, he insisted he would vote with the Government on the Budget, which will take place on October 29th.Rees-Mogg has played down reports that he would align the European Reserach Group with the DUP (Image:  SKY)The Brexiteer MP told Sky News: We must remember that there cannot be a separate arrangement for Northern Ireland.They are as much a part of the UK as Somerset. To cast Northern Ireland off into a colony of the EU would be entirely improper.However, when pressed on how far he would go to defend his red lines, Mr Rees-Mogg responded: I would vote against remaining in the customs union, against remaining in the single rulebook as proposed in Chequers.I will vote against paying &pound39bn unless there is a clear trade deal on the table.But, I stood on the Conservative manifesto and I will be supporting the Government in matters like the Budget.During a Leave Means Leave rally in Torquay, Mr Rees-Mogg urged&nbspTheresa May to get tough with the EU.He said that if the EU insisted on &ldquokneecapping Britain for Brexit in a punishment deal, it would prove it was a &ldquomafia-style organisation that we were better off leaving.In a rallying cry to Brexiteers earlier today, former&nbspBrexit secretary David Davis called May&rsquos Brexit plans &ldquocompletely unacceptable and urged cabinet ministers to &ldquoexert their collective authority.&nbsp

story: Speaking to TalkRADIO, the prominent Brexiteer argued it was difficult not to think Theresa May's Brexit approach was intentionally appalling.&nbspMr Bridgen claimed the way Mrs May's Governement has been conducting negotiations with Brussels jeopardises Britons' belief in the British political system.&nbspHe said: &ldquoThe negotiations have been handled appallingly.&ldquoI&rsquom always told in politics it&rsquos always cock-ups and not conspiracy.                Duncan Smith blasts EU and urges May to scrap Brexit backstop deal                Brexit News: Rees-Mogg responds as DUP plans to SCUPPER Budget&ldquoWell, it&rsquos been such a consistent cock-up that it&rsquos difficult not to think that it&rsquos been deliberate.&ldquoWe&rsquove sort of been moved from various positions of leaving: we&rsquore definitely leaving, maybe we&rsquore leaving, it Union.&ldquoBut the people have voted.Brexit news: Andrew Bridgen alleges May's Brexit approach may be a 'deliberate cock-up' (Image: SKY&bull)Mr Bridgen's comments come as a&nbsptotal of 63 eurosceptics have sent an open letter to the Chancellor, Philip Hammond, to&nbspexpress disapproval of the direction of the Government&rsquos Brexit preparations.The letter comes just days before the Prime Minister is expected to unveil a Brexit transition deal with Brussels.Former Brexit Secretary David Davis, ex-Minister Priti Patel, and Jacob Rees-Mogg are among the signatories of the letter which attack&rsquos the Government&rsquos forecasts on life outside of the EU.Attacking Philip Hammond and the Treasury for leaks, the letter said: &ldquoThe Cross-Whitehall Brexit Analysis leaked to the news website Buzzfeed early this year and subsequently &lsquopublished&rsquo in the form of 24 PowerPoint slides, forecasts a 7.7 per cent hit to GDP under a World Trade Deal under WTO rules and a 4.8 per cent contraction under Canada Plus.&ldquoWhile all such forecasts are only indicators of orders of magnitude and general direction, independent private sector forecasts and those of Whitehall are wildly far apart, many of which forecast a positive impact on GDP.Angry at the Government&rsquos &ldquounacceptable leaks of selective data, the backbench MPs demand the Treasury &ldquopublish in full detail the cross-Whitehall Brexit analysis.The letter added: &ldquoAdopting a constructive and transparent approach would be in the national interest.&ldquoThe general public is battered and bewildered by conflicting predictions of the future path of the economy following Brexit, fuelling a growing suspicion that Whitehall is engaging in what is apparently known internally as 'policy-based evidence-making&rsquo.The Department for Exiting the European Union has refused to comment on Mr Bridgen's allegation.

title: Brexit news update Anna Soubry Brexit vote Dominic Grieve Theresa May
story: The Conservative MP for&nbspBroxtowe in Nottinghamshire called on her Parliamentary colleagues to be honest to Britons on Brexit.&nbspShe claimed British voters were owed an apology on the undefined promise Brexit could be delivered with the June 2016 EU Referendum.Ms Soubry, who has been actively campaigning for a so-called People's Vote on the final Brexit deal, echoed Tory rebel Dominic Grieve's claim no form of Brexit isn't hugely damaging to the UK.Ms Soubry tweeted:&nbsp&ldquoThe uncomfortable truth is that #Brexit cannot be delivered.                Furious Arlene Foster ready to lead Brexit rebellion against May&ldquoIt&rsquos time we all faced the reality and were honest with the British people.&ldquoWe owe them a huge apology for a referendum with an option that was undefined &amp undeliverable.Mr Grieve told BBC Radio 4's Broadcasting House that neither Theresa May's nor former Brexit Secretary David Davis' version of Brexit will be successful in securing the future of the country is not damaged by the process of leaving the EU.Mr Grieve said: &ldquoWe are facing up to the reality of what Brexit means.Brexit news: Anna Soubry MP calls on Government to 'apologise' for 'undeliverable' Brexit promise (Image: )&ldquoAnd what I have is a number of colleagues who are all perfectly well-meaning, whether it is the Prime Minister or David Davis, who are having to grapple with this fact that there is no form of Brexit available which isn&rsquot hugely damaging to the future of this country.&ldquoAnd of course each version is damaging in different ways.&ldquoDavid Davis has highlighted that if we remain in the Customs Union it is a form of dependency.&ldquoIt preserves our trade in manufacturing which is important but it has other drawbacks.&ldquoThe Prime Minister is trying to square the circle, trying to maintain the union of the United Kingdom which is very important too, particularly in the Northern Ireland context.&ldquoAnd she&rsquos trying to ensure that we honour our obligations under the Good Friday Agreement and that we achieve a deal which isn&rsquot hugely damaging to our economy.&ldquoAnd neither of these versions I&rsquom afraid is likely to succeed.It comes as former Brexit Secretary David Davis called for a cabinet mutiny over Theresa May&rsquos &ldquoflawed Brexit plan.Mr David urged ministers to rebel and &ldquoexert their collective authority as the &ldquomoment of truth over Britain leaving the EU approaches.Mr Davis said: &ldquoThis is one of the most fundamental decisions that Government has taken in modern times.&ldquoIt is time for Cabinet members to exert their collective authority. This week the authority of our constitution is on the line.&ldquoThe EU has already offered us a Canada-style, zero-tariffs trade agreement, and Donald Tusk, president of the council, reinforced that offer last week.&ldquoA good deal is clearly within our grasp. We must reset our negotiating strategy immediately and deliver a Brexit that meets the demands of the referendum and the interests of the British people.

title: Brexit news Jeremy Corbyn Caroline Flint Chequers no deal
story: Caroline Flint has claimed she will throw her weight behind&nbspTheresa May's Brexit deal, and urged her Labour colleagues to reflect on why you would not support a Brexit deal.&nbspMs Flint, who voted Remain but has since accepted the result, also took issue with how politicians and supporters of the People's Vote campaign had treated Brexit voters.Speaking to Sophy Ridge on Sky News, the Labour Brexiteer claimed that hardline Remainers had been both patronising and offensive to those who want to leave the EU.The latest remarks from the Labour MP come as a growing&nbspnumber of backbenchers &nbspbreak ranks with Corbyn to back a deal with the EU.                Brussels stunned as MAJORITY of EU citizens question its powerLast week, the Prime Minister&nbspmade a bold appeal&nbspdirectly to Labour voters&nbspcalling on them to back her decent, moderate and patriotic Tory party.&nbspAt September's Labour conference,&nbspShadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer said: &ldquoIf Theresa May brings back a deal that fails our tests &ndash and that looks increasingly likely - Labour will vote against it. No ifs, no buts.This appeared to confirm that Labour will whip its MPs to vote against any deal that Mrs May brings back to the Commons.&nbspHowever, Ms Flint put her support behind a reasonable deal if the other options on thetable were a second referendum or a no deal scenario.&nbspShe said: The question for my Labour colleagues is why wouldn&rsquot you support a deal?Flint criticised how politicians and supporters of the People's Vote had treated Brexit voters (Image:  SKY)Why would you stand alongside Boris Johnson and Jacob Rees-Mogg who want us to crash out?That doesn&rsquot serve country&rsquos interests or Labour&rsquos interests.She also attacked how Remainers had continued to belittle Brexit voters.Ms Flint told Ridge: These politicians don&rsquot understand them and their choice of words is both patronising and offensive.Even on social media, whenever I have stood up for the people I represent andl let&rsquos remember every region of England outside of London voted Leave, you immediately get trolled and shut down.The language used by politicians and those involved in the People&rsquos Vote campaign and those that want to overturn the referendum is patronising.They say the Brexit voters were ill-informed, uneducated, that they didn&rsquot know what they were voting for.But people did have an understanding. They knew it would be seismic in terms of their county.We are stuck between hardline Brexiteers who don&rsquot want a deal and hardline Remainers who want to overturn the referendum result.If it is a reasonable deal, I would vote for itLabour MP Ruth Smeeth, for Stoke North, has recently said: &ldquoIf the option is voting for the deal or voting for something that would mean no deal &ndash well, I&rsquom not prepared to vote for no-deal.Brexit-backing Labour MPs such as Kate Hoey and Frank Field could also rebel against their party's leadership to back Mrs May.

title: Brexit news update Emily Thornberry Andrew Marr show Labour Brexit tests
story: The Shadow Foreign Secretary was put on the spot by BBC host Andrew Marr as he said Labour's Brexit tests have been designed to make May's final deal fail in Parliament.The BBC host pointed out one of the tests says Theresa May's Brexit deal must guarantee the UK will maintain the same benefits of being a member of the EU outside of the bloc.&nbspA provision which Mr Marr claimed to be impossible to achieve unless the Prime Minister agrees to keep the UK in the customs union and the single market.&nbspHe said: &ldquoYou mentioned your tests a couple of times but they&rsquore a bit silly, aren&rsquot they?                NO DEAL BREXIT EXPLAINED: What does a it mean for immigration?                PM needs to find her inner Trump to beat Brussels, says TIM NEWARKIf you say we must have the exact same benefits then that means that we have to stay inside the single market and the customs union.&ldquoOtherwise we can&rsquot possibly have the exact same benefits.&ldquoSo it does seem to a lot of people these are tests designed for the Government to fail them.&ldquoThey&rsquore intended to provoke a parliamentary crisis because you want a general election as soon as possible.Brexit news: Andrew Marr challenges Emily Thornberry on Labour's Brexit tests (Image: BBC)The Labour frontbencher responded arguing Theresa May had already agreed to meet Labour tests on the final agreement with Brussels.&nbspShe added Labour will be merely holding the Prime Minister to her promise.&nbspShe said: When Theresa May said she was going to get this deal and we said we will have six tests and she said &lsquooh, it&rsquos fine. I&rsquom going to be able to agree on all of that&rsquo.&ldquo&lsquoMy agreement will meet your test.&rsquo That&rsquos what the Prime Minister said.&ldquoAnd we&rsquore holding her to it.Ms Thornberry hit out at Theresa May's government for playing chicken over the Brexit deal.She added: They have been faffing around for two years.We shouldn't be having a deal where Theresa May comes to an agreement that says 'we haven't been able to agree anything in the last two years but we're going to agree something in the next two years.It's a false choice. We're not agreeing to building half a bridge when we don't know where it goes.

title: Brexit news UK EU deal Dominic Raab Michel Barnier Brussels
story: Dominic Raab heads to Brussels for crunch Brexit meeting with Michel Barnier (Image: &bullREUTERS)The two negotiators met for unprecedented Sunday afternoon talks ahead of a gathering of European Union leaders in the Belgian capital on Wednesday.The meeting, which ended at around 5.45pm local time, coincides with reports from Germany that both the UK and EU were on the verge of concluding an agreement.EU diplomats have warned Express to be sceptical of reports emerging from the meeting that a deal had been concluded between Mr Raab and Mr Barnier.Following the showdown,&nbspBritain's Brexit ministry said the UK and EU&nbsphad made progress in a number of key areas in Brexit negotiations.But they said there remains a number of unresolved issues relating to the backstop.A spokeswoman said: The UK is still committed to making progress at the October European Council.Ahead of the meeting, the Brexit Department has said there are still a number of outstanding issues to be discussed, including the thorny Irish border issue.A UK Government spokesman said: &ldquoBrexit secretary Dominic Raab will be in Brussels this afternoon to meet with Michel Barnier.&ldquoWith several big issues still to resolve, including the Northern Ireland backstop, it was jointly agreed that face-to-face talks were necessary ahead of this week's October European ffCouncil.A meeting of EU27 ambassadors followed the talks between the UK and EU chief negotiators.Express understands member states are positive about how weekend talks have gone but focus remains on next week. &nbspEU diplomats are expecting the talks to go into the early hours as Brussels and Westminster hope to make a breakthrough.This website was told the extraordinary meetings represent short steps toward a deal, despite significant differernces remaining between both parties.&nbspOther high-placed sources have described the events as a positive steps but will require Theresa May to make significant moves domestically.&nbspMembers of Michel Barnier&rsquos team will brief the EU27 on his meeting with Mr Raab, according to European Commission sources.&nbspMember states are have said to have demanded the extraordinary U.K.-EU meeting in order to display &ldquosignificant progress&ldquo ahead of the Concil meeting.But, talks remain on a knife edge as Monday&rsquos meeting of leaders&rsquo most senior aide has been cancelled increasing the posibility of a no-deal Brexit.&nbspA leaked EU planning document, obtained by the German newspaper&nbspS&uumlddeutsche Zeitung, reads: &ldquoDeal made, nothing made public (in theory).The face-to-face talks came ahead of what was described by European Council President Donald Tusk as a moment of truth in the Brexit negotiations when EU leaders gather in Brussels next week.Writing on Twitter after the meeting, Mr Barnier said: &ldquoWe met Dominic Raab and UK negotiating team.&ldquoDespite intense efforts, some key issues are still open, including the backstop for Ireland and Northern Ireland to avoid a hard border.&ldquoI will debrief the EU27 and European Parliament on the Brexit negotiations.Mr Tusk had told Mrs May that he expected maximum progress on both sides plans to ensure there is no hardening of the Irish border as a result of Brexit.EU negotiator Mr Barnier, last week, told Brussels officials decisive progress must be made before the summit if a deal was to be concluded.The Irish border remained the biggest outstanding challenge in making a breakthrough on a deal with Mrs May under signficant domestic pressure on the so-called backstop.&nbsp                Brussels stunned as MAJORITY of EU citizens question its power                Germany mocked for CRINGEWORTHY video to lure UK bankers after BrexitThe Prime Minister has been struggling to convince her Cabinet and the Democratic Unionist Party of her Irish backstop plans.Mrs May has been forced into the tricky situation by EU officials, who have so far refused to offer any compromises &ndash such as allowing a time-limited or UK-wide backstop.The Prime Minister has had to face down reports that Cabinet ministers were planning to resign and the DUP were ready to vote down the Budget if they did not get their own way.Talks between EU and UK officials have been holding intense negotiations over the weekend as they hope to break the impasse.&nbspDespite the withdrawal agreement being on the verge of completion, EU leaders are considering using a planned emergency summit in November for no-deal talks.EU diplomats have revealed the November 17-18 meeting could be used to closer examine the consequences of Britain leaving the bloc without a deal.The plan is likely being used to pile pressure on the Prime Minister to offer a number of concessions in order to strike a deal.Despite the plans, Mr Barnier's deputy Sabine Weyand told member states that talks were progressing well during a Coreper meeting on Friday night.

title: scottish plan to plant 500 acres of broadleaf trees above the A83
story: The Rest and Be Thankful Woodland Creation Project was approved in August (Image: NC)The motorists have been forced to take a 60-mile detour since Tuesday when 2,500 tonnes of debris tumbled down Ben Luibhean blocking the main road and the Old Military Road which is normally used as a relief route.However, after another 300 tonnes of debris on the A83 and another 50 tonnes on the old road came down on Friday, there is no quick solution for the ongoing access issue.Three huge boulders - including one weighing 75 tonnes - which were trapped in the steel catch fences on the mountain earlier on in the week have been secured by engineers but difficult conditions brought on by Storm Callum hampered further clearance efforts.Forestry Commission Scotland (FCS) and Transport Scotland are planning to plant 500 acres of native broadleaf trees and shrubs on the slopes above the A83 to reduce erosion and increase stability.                A483 traffic update: A483 CLOSED after lorry and tractor crash                 Traffic lights could soon be removed from UK roads, this is whyThe Rest and Be Thankful Woodland Creation Project was approved in August after a public consultation and the planting of up to 250,000 trees is scheduled to start in 2020.However, work cannot begin until the land is purchased from the current owner, who uses the barren slopes for rough sheep grazing.Even then, it will be at least 15 years before the new forest starts to reduce landslides in the steep-sided mountain pass between Tarbert and Arrochar.The project was first put forward in 2012 in a report for FCS by Bill Raynor and Bruce Nicoll of Forest Research in Edinburgh.They said it would not be possible to plant quick-growing conifers in such a windy location and suggested reintroducing a mix of native species that would have covered the slopes before they were cleared for sheep grazing.The species included ash, aspen, bird cherry, blackthorn, common alder, downy birch, eared willow, hawthorn, hazel, holly, rowan and sessile oak, with blaeberry and wood sorrel ground vegetation.In the same year, a report by Transport Scotland concluded that low-height broadleaf trees and shrubs should be planted alongside other measures such as deer fences and engineering work.As well as the land ownership issue, the impact on golden eagles, black grouse and badgers and concerns from hikers and mountaineers have also complicated matters since then.The SNP Government has focused instead on opening the relief route and has spent &pound10million on measures such as netting, drainage and road safety works.Despite this massive outlay, the road has been closed on dozens of occasions causing long delays for motorists and the emergency services and damaging the rural economy of Argyll.Jamie Greene, Scottish Conservative transport spokesman, said the landslips caused enormous disruption and inconvenience for everyone in the local area and added: While clearly a previous attempt has been made to prevent this kind of landslip, it has not worked.                M4 crash: Three dead after minibus and lorry collision                M26 traffic: Kent motorway CLOSED to prepare for Brexit no dealThe species included ash, aspen, bird cherry, blackthorn, common alder and many more (Image: AGF)&ldquoThere are questions to be asked about why an alternative approach that was suggested in 2012 has not been tried.&ldquoIf tree planting is the best solution, as suggested in this document, then we may have simply wasted 6 years.A Transport Scotland spokesman said: The plan to plant trees above the A83 Rest and Be Thankful to help mitigate landslips cannot begin until the complex land purchase process is complete and the necessary planning permission is in place. Transport Scotland has been working closely with the existing landowner and partner agencies and it is hoped these will be finalised in the near future, allowing preparatory works to begin in the new year.Work has already begun on a further &pound2m worth of additional mitigation measures, including the construction of road side catch pits.&ldquoThese measures, which were agreed with the A83 Taskforce, will help improve the resilience of the A83 and help keep Argyll open for business.

title: Brexit news update UK EU deal customs union Hans Olaf Henkel Germany
story: Speaking to Sky News, the&nbspEuropean Conservatives and Reformists MEP claimed the EU will soon realise that by trying to punish the UK in the Brexit negotiations it is punishing itself.The German politician argued Brussels should acknowledge the importance and the magnitude of Britain in the EU common market and offer the UK the best possible deal.&nbspMr Henkel said: &ldquoI think very slowly and only very late the Europeans will realise that by trying to punish Britain they punish themselves.&ldquoAnd that is a sort of masochistic approach of the Brussels bureaucracy.                Brexiteer CEO debunks 'Armageddon' fears of no deal Brexit                Brexit news: Dominic Raab heads to Brussels for Michel Barnier meeting&ldquoI think we should realise that Britain is big.&ldquoBritain is as big as if 19 small and medium-sized countries would leave the European Union at the same time.&ldquoAnd the best thing the European Union has ever done is the common market and without Britain, the common market will not be as important and as valuable to Germany, for instance, as it was before.&ldquoSo I think it is so logical for everybody and for every reasonable person to try to avoid this.&ldquoEither do the best deal for Britain possible and if that&rsquos not possible, avoid it all together.Brexit news: German MEP Hans-Olaf Henkel calls on Brussels to give UK the 'best possible deal' (Image: &bullSKY)It comes as the Departement for Exiting the European Union announced Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab will meet EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier on Sunday.&nbspThe unplanned meeting is expected to focus on the issue of Northern Ireland and the Brexit backstop agreed by Theresa May last December.&nbspA UK Government spokesman said: &ldquoBrexit secretary Dominic Raab will be in Brussels this afternoon to meet with Michel Barnier.&ldquoWith several big issues still to resolve, including the Northern Ireland backstop, it was jointly agreed that face-to-face talks were necessary ahead of this week's October European Council.The Northern Ireland border remains a major Brexit stumbling block, with the EU wanting the province to remain within its rules in the event of a &ldquobackstop to keep the border open.But the DUP and Mrs May have both ruled out the proposal.European Union leaders will meet in Brussels on Wednesday for the European Council summit.EU negotiator Mr Barnier, last week, told Brussels officials decisive progress must be made before the summit if a deal was to be concluded.

title: Brexit news update UK EU customs union Barry Gardiner Labour Brexit latest
story: Speaking on BBC Radio 5 Pienaar's Politics, the Shadow Trade International Secretary claimed a Labour Government would negotiate UK's post-Brexit membership of a newly designed customs union with the EU to retain veto powers on future trade deals.&nbspBut BBC host John Pienaar called the Labour frontbencher out on the unrealistic Labour Brexit proposal arguing the EU would never agree to the UK enjoying the same powers as Germany or France without being a member of the Brussels bloc.&nbspMr Pienaar said: &ldquoYou say not the EU&rsquos customs union as it is now but a new remodelled one tailored to British needs.&ldquoYou say that you&rsquod do it rather differently than the present Government.                Emily Thornberry GRILLED by Marr on 'silly' Labour Brexit tests                Brexit news: Dominic Raab heads to Brussels for Michel Barnier meeting&ldquoAnd the problem with all of that is who can imagine the European Union - let&rsquos say there is a Labour Government doing a deal where Britain is part of a newly designed customs union with a veto and a greater say than other parts of the 27 members of the European Union in what future trade deals will look like.&ldquoBecause you would be in that group with Germany and with France, other powerful economic blocs who have their own interests to defend when it comes to striking these trade deals.&ldquoBritain would be just another like those with membership with no greater say.&ldquoYou&rsquore even saying that Britain would have a special place at the table!Brexit news: John Pienaar dismantles Labour post-Brexit alternative to EU customs union (Image: SKY&bullBBC)Mr Gardiner attempted to hit back claiming Labour's approach should be considered on the basis the UK will be a third country outside the European Union.He said: &ldquoWhat we&rsquore saying is you have to consider the UK now as not a member state of the European Union.&ldquoThen concluding an agreement with the EU.But as the Labour frontbencher&nbsptried to justify his position, Mr Pienaar interrupted him: &ldquoYou wouldn&rsquot be a member but you&rsquod have a veto on EU trade deals? How realistic is that?To which Mr Gardiner replied: &ldquoIt&rsquos very realistic because other customs unions around the world do this.&ldquoOther customs union do exactly this where other countries come together and they each have a say, a co-decision making power over the trade agreements that they conclude.European leaders will meet on Wednesday in Brussels for the European Council summit.&nbspEU chief negotiator Michel Barnier claimed significant progress between Brussels and the UK should be agreed before the summit.&nbspThe UK Departement for Exiting the European Union confirmed Mr Barnier and Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab will meet on Sunday afternoon to discuss the future of Northern Ireland amid increasing domestic pressure on Theresa May over the backstop agreed upon last December.

title: Bavaria election 2018 results Angela Merkel Germany Chancellor
story: Hans-Olaf Henkel has predicted that long-serving German Chancellor Angela Merkel will be gone by December, but not because of the bruising election in Bavaria today.Bavarians have gone to the polls today to vote in an election that could further shake Germany's fragile coalition government.&nbspMrs Merkel&rsquos Bavarian allies&nbspin the CSU are heading for their worst state election in more than 60 years and could lose&nbsptheir absolute majority.But, according to German MEP Hans-Olaf Henkel, a local election set to take place in just two weeks time will be more decisive for the future of Mrs Merkel.                Germany mocked for CRINGEWORTHY video to lure UK bankers after Brexit                Bavaria elections: Polls open as Angela Merkel set for BRUISING resultSpeaking to Sky News, Mr Henkel suggested that if Chancellor Merkel's own CDU party struggles to hold onto power in the local election in Hesse at the end of the month&nbspthen the leader's future is doomed.He said: You will see a lot of bickering that will start tonight. They will start blaming Berlin and Berlin will blame Seehofer.Nothing material will happen until the next local elections in Hesse in two weeks, which is as big and as important as Bavaria, and there it is Merkel&rsquos own party that is expected to get a severe beating.Then you will have a lively debate on the future of the German Chancellor Angela Merkel.Henkel predicted that long-serving German Chancellor Angela Merkel will be gone by December (Image: )We have never had a chancellor who has left the job by their own choice.They were all either axed by their own parties or voted out by the population. Merkel will be no different.She has got to be moved away. There is growing opposition in her own party.It will come to a very important decision in December when there is the CDU party congress where Merkel has to be re-selected.For the very first time she has two opponents already, and this will grow.Right now she could survive it but if the Hesse election goes as badly as the Bavaria is expected to go today then there is a strong likelihood that there will be a new chancellor.Volker Bouffier, a CDU state premier in Hesse, said that the coalition chaos in recent months had seen the government lose trust.&nbspIf the CSU lose their majority in Bavaria, the party leader and the coalition's interior minister Horst Seehofer could face calls to resign.&nbspDivisions between the CDU-CSU allies have widened in recent months, after they struck a coalition deal with the centre-left SPD.

title: bavaria election 2018 results exit polls germany AFD Angela Merkel CSU
story: The preliminary results reveal that Merkel's allies are set for their worst election results since 1950.The Christian Social Union (CSU) has&nbspwon 37.3 percent of the vote and has&nbsplost its absolute majority for only the second time since 1962.This bad result for Chancellor Merkel&rsquos party could increase tensions within Germany&rsquos fragile government.The Bavarian premier Markus Soeder said: &ldquoOf course today is not an easy day for the CSU. We did not achieve a good result. We accept the result with humility.                Bavaria elections: Polls open as Angela Merkel set for BRUISING result                German MEP reveals Merkel could be OUSTED by end of the yearThe Greens have recorded strong gains and are the second largest party in the Bavaria vote with 17.8 percent of the vote.The far-right Alternative for Germany party (AfD) are set to enter the Bavarian Regional Assembly for the first time with 11 percent of the vote.The centre-left Social Democrats (SPD) are expected to win 10 percent of the vote.The Christian Social Union (CSU) is expected to win around 34 percent of the vote and is set to lose the absolute majority for the first time since the end of the war.Merkel is set for a bruising in these Bavarian elections (Image: )Political scientist at the University of Passau, Michael Weigl, has said that personal attacks on Angela Merkel by leader of the CSU Horst Seehofer are to blame for CSU&rsquos weak result.Mr Weigl said: &ldquoThis created a political climate of polarisation from which the Greens and the AfD benefited the most, with their clear stances on immigration.&ldquoFor the CSU, this strategy backfired. I expect that Seehofer will have to step down as interior minister.Three in four voters who have abandoned the CSU in Bavaria have said they think the party has focussed too much on immigration and has neglected other issues.Green Party members celebrate the exit polls  (Image: Getty)Mr Seehofer has been highly critical of Merkel&rsquos immigration policies toward migrants and has excluded her from election campaigning.Initial figures show that more voters have left the CSU for the Greens than for either the AfD of the Free Voters.SPD national chairwoman Andrea Nahles said: &ldquoCongratulation to the Greens, who were the true winners of the election.&ldquoThere's no doubt that one reason for our poor performance in Bavaria was the poor performance of the grand coalition in here Berlin.Ms Nahles said the poor performance of the federal government in Berlin was one of the reasons for her party's weak showing in Bavaria.She said: It's clear that something has to change.&nbspThe Bavarian election comes a day after a mass protest in Berlin on Saturday where 240,000 people demonstrated against racism, xenophobia and the rise of the far right.In Berlin, the CSU is one of three parties in Merkel&rsquos federal coalition government along with the Christian Democratic Union and the Social Democrats.Regional Green co-leader Katharina Schulze says people are fed up with the politics of hate and agitation and want a policy that gives courage instead of fear.Chancellor Merkel, who has been in power since 2005, has already been weakened this year by government infighting.Members of the CSU await the results of the Bavarian election  (Image: )After the CSU has held power in Bavaria for so long and needing a coalition partner would be a humiliating setback for the party.Bavaria has 13 million residents and is the biggest by area of Germany&rsquos 16 federal states.The Christian Democratic Union will hold its annual congress in December when Merkel will seek re-election as a party chairwoman.

title: Bavaria election results angela merkel news germany AFD results
story: The Christian Social Union (CSU) secured just 37.3 percent of the vote, which is expected to deal a blow to her fragile three-party coalition government.The results reveal that the Greens have won 17.8 percent of the vote and the Conservative Free Voters have won 11 percent of the vote.The Social Democrats (SPD) leader Andrea Nahles said that the &ldquopoor performance of the federal government in Berlin was one of the reasons for her party&rsquos weak showing in Bavaria.She said: &ldquoIt&rsquos clear that something has to change.The SPD leader Andrea Nahles called for 'something to change' following the results  (Image: )This comment is especially devastating to Chancellor Merkel as she only managed to secure a fourth term in power after the SPD backed a coalition deal earlier this year.Prior to their agreement of a coalition, there had been six months of uncertainty and Germany had been without a government for the longest time in its postwar history.The SPD won nine percent of the vote in the elections.&nbspFor the second time this year, Merkel&rsquos party will be scrambling for coalition allies, either the Conservative Free voters or the Greens.                Merkel's ally calls on EU to 'DELIVER' on migration ahead of election                Germany mocked for CRINGEWORTHY video to lure UK bankers after BrexitChancellor Merkel angered many voters in Germany for her immigration policies, which has seen more than a million people enter the country since 2015.The anti-immigration Alternative for Germany (AfD) won 11 percent of the vote and has now entered the 15th of Germany&rsquos 16 state assemblies.President of the Atlantic Council think tank Fred Kempe said: &ldquoThe political earthquake was in Bavaria, but the aftershocks will be felt in Berlin.&ldquoTalk will increase ever more about the end of the Merkel era.The Green Party have been celebrating following the Bavarian election results  (Image: )Die Linke member Bijan Tavassoli told Russia Today: &ldquoEven though Angela Merkel was not on the ballot tonight, she was on the ballot.And the vote was a clear vote to end the era of Merkel.The leader of the CSU in Bavaria, Markus Soeder, said: &ldquoOf course today is not an easy day for the CSU. We did not achieve a good result.&ldquoWe accept the result with humility.Top candidate of the ecologist Greens party in Bavaria Katharina Schulze and Ludwig Hartmann  (Image: Getty)Jan Techau at The German Marshall Fund of the United States think-tank described Merkel as exhausted and weakened.He said: And yet, her strategy to keep the Union firmly in the middle does not look so silly after this result for the CSU.Whether this temporary reprieve can hold or not will depend on the result in Hesse.

title: north alaska earthquake Kotzebue magnitude 5 5 Kikiktagruk USGS
story: Kotzebue or Kikiktagruk is a city in the Northwest Arctic Borough in the US state of Alaska.It is the borough's seat, by far its largest community and the economic and transportation hub of the subregion of Alaska encompassing the borough.According to the United States Geological Survey, (USGS) nearby places that could be affected by the tremors are Ishiuk, Alaska, College, Alaska, Fairbanks, Alaska, Badger, Alaska, Anadyr, Chukotka, Russia.The USGS reviewed the quake and put it at a magnitude 5.3, which means slight damage may be caused to buildings and other structures.There is little or no area affected or population exposed to landslides, the USGS said.There is also little risk of liquefaction with little or no population exposed.Liquefaction is when the soil loses its strength in response to the ground shaking.The process can cause major damage to buildings and other structures during earthquakes.An earthquake has hit Northern Alaska  (Image: )A map shows where the quake hit (Image: USGS)Although the earthquake was only moderate, the perceived shaking was very strong, the USGS said.The USGS said the potential damage caused by the tremors is &ldquomoderate.The National Weather Service (NWS) issued a statement about the earthquake&rsquos potential to cause a tsunami.It said: &ldquoThere is NO tsunami danger from this earthquake.The city of Fairbanks could be affected by the quake, the USGS said (Image: )The NWS gave a preliminary earthquake parameter of a depth of 13 miles, 70 miles north of Kobuk, Alaska.Kobuk is a city in Northwest Arctic Borough, Alaska, United States.At the 2010 census, the population was 151, up from 109 in 2000.

title: Wikileaks julian assange ecuador embassy london United Nation talk
story: Wikileaks founder Julian Assange and President Moreno of Ecaduor (Image: )The Ecuadorian government revoked his internet and phone access in March after he breached an agreement &ldquonot to issue messages that might interfere with other states.Only members of his legal team have been allowed to visit during this period.However, Wikileaks yesterday announced that his &ldquoisolation regime was over after talks between UN officials and Ecuadorian President Lenin Moreno on Friday.The UN High Commissioner for Refugees Filippo Grandi and UN Special Rapporteur for Freedom of Expression David Kaye met with President Moreno and agreed to partially alleviate the ban on communications.                Britain PREVENTED Julian Assange from becoming Ecuadorian diplomat                Julian Assange RESIGNS as WikiLeaks editor as internet access DENIEDEditor-in-chief of Wikileaks Kristin Hrafnsson said: &ldquoIt is positive that, through UN intervention, Ecuador has partly ended the isolation of Mr Assange although it is of grave concern that his freedom to express his opinions is still limited.&ldquoThe UN has already declared Mr Assange a victim of arbitrary detention.&ldquoThis unacceptable situation must end.&ldquoThe UK Government must abide by the UN&rsquos ruling and guarantee that he can leave the embassy without the threat of extradition to the United States.Ecuadorian embassy in London, where Julian Assange has been residing for six years  (Image: )Mr Assange has not left the Ecuadorian embassy for six years after losing a legal battle against extradition to Sweden over rape and sexual assault allegations.He fears eventual extradition to the United States to be questioned over the leaking of sensitive information via Wikileaks and could be charged with treason or spying.The Australian-born programmer founded Wikileaks in 2006, but came to international attention in 2010 when the site published a series of highly sensitive leaks from Chelsea Manning.In the same year, Sweden issued an arrest warrant for Mr Assange for rape and sexual assault allegations, which he denies.                Julian Assange &lsquoplanned to flee to Russia&rsquo - leaked documents revealJulian Assange speaks from the balcony of the Ecuadorian embassy (Image: )He was arrested by UK police in December 2010, but released on bail.He then absconded before being granted asylum by the Ecuadorian government and has been in their embassy in London since 2012.He maintains that he fears the Swedish government would hand him over to the Americans.

title: its simply sickening to spend 4bn abroad on dubious foreign aid projects
story: But it is simply sickening to spend £billion abroad upgrading road and rail schemes and urban infrastructure.Look at the appalling state of OUR roads, needing a £billion fix of their own. Look at our shambolic rail system and its creaking, crumbling infrastructure overseen by state-run Network Rail.Look at our public finances, our deficit, our gargantuan debt. Look at the local councils facing bankruptcy.Listen to the Government, now facing a headache over Universal Credit, insisting every penny must be made to count.We are entitled to expect decent public services infor our taxes. What justication can there be for hiving off billions from them to improve transport systems in Pakistan Or in India, which has billions for a fleet of new warships and a space programme but needs the British public’s generosity to mend its roads It is insane. The consequence of an idiotic law which compels us to donate billions every year no matter how dire our finances or how spurious the cause.The Sun is all for helping the genuinely needy. But not for foolish virtue-signalling on the world stage.It is an abuse of public funds and a cast-iron election loser.THERESA May must find the cash to help those losing out in the sht to Universal Credit.The new scheme DOES work well for many. It is far simpler and, crucially, incentivises work. But cuts by former Chancellor George Osborne are now biting too hard. Some claimants face a severe blow to their income.If the PM is genuinely “listening to concerns”, as she says, then good.Voters generally back less generous benefit payments. Especially compared with the absurd levels under the last Labour Government, which fostered idleness and trapped huge numbers permanently on the dole. But Brits are famously keen on fair play too.They won’t support families being stripped of money through no fault of their own.KIDS don’t need a smartphone in class. It can only wreck their concentration and harm their education.How can they learnthey’re too busy sneaking a look at Snapchat How can they learnthey’re too busy sneaking a look at Snapchat Other countries have done already.But generations of pupils survived without them. And the downside is too great.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: princess eugenie wedding itv katie glass comment
story: But this time there was no argument over the TV remote. The BBC and Sky turned down the chance to show it, leaving Eamonn Holmes and Ruth Langsford on ITV’s This Morning to oversee the whole shebang.It meant coverage was relaxed, which suited Eamonn and Ruth, who admitted they had no idea how to pronounce the bride’s name.When we cut to Windsor, guests were thin on the ground. Just a smattering of overzealous royalists and tourists waving flags.“It’s not the same as Meghan and Harry,” Eamonn was forced to admit.As we waited for the couple to arrive, Alison Hammond was sent to interview superfans who had waited since am. Only they didn’t seem to know why. Asked what she loved about Eugenie and Jack, one royalist shrugged: “I don’t really know anything about them.”Another, Anita Atkinson, , was a bit more fun and “really, really, really excited” about the wedding.She then ulged a wee bit more than we wanted to know by confessing: “When you get to a certain age things happen, you know.”Even the royal pundits ITV had wangled on struggled to convey much enthusiasm for the whole thing.“Remember that she is a blood Princess,” one said.“She’s ninth in line to the throne and Harry is only sixth, so there’s not a lot of dference,” another offered.In an interview before the shindig, the couple promised Ruth and Eamonn a wave. But it didn’t happen.A disappointed Eamonn wailed: “He promised us a wave, Ruth. He lied!”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: we dont owe musical genius to the eu
story: Fine, highfalutin words, Bono.But try telling them to the ­millions of young people who are unemployed in Italy, Spain and Greece, the economies of those proud countries dragged down by the dead weight of the euro. And try out the windbag oratory on the .million decent British democrats who voted to leave the European Union, and who have been told ever since that they are racist, ignorant ­bigots who should never be allowed near a polling booth.I like Bono. In person, he is a decent, thoughtful man. His band are not bad. But why do the former rebels of rock music always tug their forelocks to the European Union  Why does everyone in leather trousers act like the EU is an unalloyed good thing  Why does rock music have a blind spot when it comes to Brussels How can Bono, right, possibly mistake Jean-Claude Juncker for Joe Strummer   The EU is the ESTABLISHMENT, man! And the EU is the ­establishment at its most ­unaccountable, undemocratic, incompetent and corrupt.The EU is not a beautul thing, Bono. It is a crumbling ­expansionist empire, rotten to the core, merciless in its opposition to democracy.The EU is a gravy train, Bono, a trough for puffed-up political piggies, a sclerotic body of ­privileged old white men in suits with MEPs who do not have to provide receipts for their £,-a-month expenses. The EU really stinks, Bono.And the music that you and I grew up with — the music we loved, the music U and I were inspired by, the music we placed at the centre of our worlds — was meant to be against this kind of thing. Bono bent the knee to the bullies of Brussels in the same week that Bob Geldof sent a ­letter to Theresa May warning her that Brexit will be the day the music dies.“Imagine Britain without its music,” thundered Geldof’s letter, co-signed by musicians including Sting, Ed Sheeran, Jarvis Cocker and Damon Albarn. “If it’s hard for us, then it’s impossible for the rest of the world. Britain does rule the waves. The airwaves. But Brexit threatens, as it does so much , this vast voice.”But it is simply not true that our country owes its musical genius to the European Union. The golden years of British music were before we joined the EU — when it was still being touted to us as a common market — back in .The Beatles, the Rolling Stones, The Who, The Kinks, Pink Floyd and Led Zeppelin all somehow managed to make great music without Brussels. Now Geldof and his co-signatories seriously suggest that British music can’t survive outside the European Union.No doubt the Brexit-loathing Boomtown Rat believes this rubbish but everyone  who signed his Whinge Aid letter should have paused to think before signing. Because by claiming that Brexit will kill British music, Ed Sheeran, Sting and the rest just make themselves look like laughably out-of-touch luvvies. Not a good look for the wild boys of rock ’n’ roll.Geldof is right about one thing — British music has been brilliant for  years because our little country embraced the world.But John Lennon, Jimmy Page, Joe Strummer, Mick Jones, Ray Davies, Robert Plant, Mick Jagger, Keith Richards, Eric Clapton and Pete Townshend opened their ears and their hearts to the sounds coming out of America.The glorious music that smashed down the walls between white music and black music was born in Chicago and Nashville and Detroit and Memphis.  Its roots were in the backwoods of the Deep South and the ­Mississippi Delta, and reached all the way back to Africa. Belgium never came into it, Bob.The Rolling Stones never needed a grant from the EU. They just needed one glimpse of Buddy Holly, one listen to Muddy Waters, one nod from Elvis Presley. British bands changed the world and they sure as hell did it without the help of the European Union. Sorry, Bob. Sorry, Bono. But no British musician in history was ever inspired by the mysterious rhythms coming out of Brussels.PETER JACKSON’S new film, They Shall Not Grow Old, shows painstakingly coloured images from World War One for the very first time.Because we have only experienced World War One in black and white footage and photos, there has always felt like a huge distance between our time and the unimaginable horrors of the trenches.Lord Of The Rings director Jackson has bridged that gap and the results, above, take your breath away. He says: “The war was a colour war. You’re seeing it as they saw it. And they saw it in colour.”World War One never felt closer. And the humour, humanity and courage of the men who fought it has never been more heartbreaking.BEST wishes for the future to Trevor Engelson and his bride Tracey Kurland, who were married in a low-key ceremony in Calornia last weekend.Andyou don’t recognise the names, that is because Mr Engelson has chosen to keep a discreet silence on the subject of his two-year marriage to Meghan Markle.And in an age where every broken relationship is ­dissected on social media, isn’t it refreshing to see a man who can keep a dignied silence “WE lost the match but won the battle,” claimed Conor McGregor after his beating in last weekend’s UFC .  What planet was that victory on then, Conor To the casual fan it looked like McGregor  followed up months of denigrating Khabib Nurmagomedov with a feeble performance in the octagon and a lack of grace in defeat.True, Khabib spoilt his victory by jumping into the crowd to continue the punch-up with McGregor’s corner.  But for the le of me I can’t see how Conor McGregor can claim anything other than unconditional surrender. Neither man brought credit to MMA.There is only one reason why mainstream sports fans have been paying interest to Mixed Martial Arts in recent years and that is Conor McGregor. But after the squalid scenes around Conor v Khabib, many of us will be turning off the MMA.Even Mike Tyson was shocked. And he once bit off part of a man’s ear.WHAT my mum would have found unforgivable about Strictly star Seann Walsh snogging Katya Jones is that it happened when Walsh’s girlfriend, Rebecca Humphries, was home alone on her BIRTHDAY.My mum would never have forgiven that kind of casual cruelty from some curly-haired love rat. And I suspect the great British public will feel the same. But what we call the Strictly curse is really just an office romance that spirals out of control.People get thrown together at work all the time. The dference is that a couple from the accounts department don’t usually spend hours every day rubbing up against each other perfecting their Paso Doble.But the intense, intimate physical contact of doing Strictly makes it certain the curse will strike again.The mystery is why Katya was never led astray by Ed Balls.FEMALE terrorist, married to a British jihadi, claimed a council breached her human rights by not giving her a new home after she turned down seven homes because they were not big enough or not in the right location.Kindly Brent Council also offered her £, to put down a deposit on a home of her own.Are we insane Our welfare state was built to care for the most vulnerable members of our society.Not creatures who would spit on our society’s grave.TINA TURNER is the only female performer who was hotter live than Blondie’s Debbie Harry in her pouting, heavy-lidded prime.So it comes as some surprise to hear Tina say that she never tried to be sexy on stage. “Fishnets are practical,” Tina says primly. “They don’t run. And leather doesn’t show the perspiration on stage or wrinkle. I only wore a mini-dress because everyone knows you can’t dance in a dress that goes past your knee.”OK, Tina, we believe you – even though your practical work clothes launched a million adolescent fantasies. And that was just in my house.DRESSED like a street-walking disco ball, Taylor Swt urges America to go out and vote Democrat in the American mid-term elections.I admire young Taylor but does it never occur to these celebrities that their smug self-importance might possibly be drumming up votes for the other side But where were your sensible shoes WHY should anyone vote Conservative  This Government is slashing benefits for the British poor and disabled but can still find £billion in foreign aid money to improve roads and railways in Pakistan and India. Why should we vote for you, Theresa There is nothing remotely Conservative about you.WHY should anyone vote Conservative  This Government is slashing benefits for the British poor and disabled but can still find £billion in foreign aid money to improve roads and railways in Pakistan and India.Why should we vote for you, Theresa There is nothing remotely Conservative about you.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: men stop chatting up schoolgirls
story: The figures come from a report by children’s charity Plan International UK, which also found two-thirds of girls say they have experienced unwanted sexual attention in public.A third of girls have been touched, groped or grabbed by men they don’t know. This kind of thing is so commonplace that many — some as young as eight — feel street harassment is “part of growing up”. How awful is that  Partly, the problem is that somewhere along the line, the idea that schoolgirls are “sexy” has become normalised, acceptable, even mainstream.Yes, I know that the waters were somewhat muddied by the likes of Britney Spears in her Baby One More Time video and Gemma Arterton in her St Trinian’s films — both looking as sexy as heck in school unorm.  And yes, I know a lot of girls look older than they are, and might even try to do so by wearing make-up, smoking or shortening their skirts on the way to and from school.But let’s be really clear about this. — girls young enough to wear school unorm are children. And the idea of any man thinking it’s OK to wolf-whistle, chat up or give any kind of sexual attention to a girl in a unorm is not just seriously worrying. It should be a criminal offence.By the way, I wonder what a similar survey of boys would find. Because the thought of women wolf-whistling schoolboys in the street is unimaginable, right  Parents of ­secondary school children need to give them some freedom to help them on the path to adulthood.Often, that involves letting them walk unaccompanied to school.  But the idea that doing that is exposing their child to the possibility of sexual harassment will be pretty distressing to any parent.One of the saddest things about this report is how many of the girls interviewed thought this kind of behaviour is “normal”. One -year-old said she felt street harassment was part of the “bro culture” and her dad had told her: “You know what men are like.”  What kind of advice is that for your daughter Another girl, aged , said: “It’s just become normal.” But the net result of behaviour like this is that it makes girls scared of walking the streets.All too often, our response to such news is to try to protect girls by telling them not to look too ­provocative. But that just perpetuates the idea men “can’t help themselves” so it’s down to the girls, and the way they dress, to make sure they are left alone.You can’t blame girls or women for men’s behaviour, no matter what theof their skirt. But the dficult truth is that we know women do have to ­mody their behaviour, and the way they dress, to stop men from ­commenting on their appearance, harassing them or worse.Perhaps what I am most shocked about is the young age at which this starts. One good thing is that these days, girls at secondary school have phones. They can record things that happen to them and report it. Also, Plan International UK is calling on bystanders to challenge harassment when they see it.Certainly,I was around someone wolf-whistling schoolgirls, I’d flip my lid. I would not be too scared to speak my mind and verbally intervene. I think my opening ­gambit would be: “How would you feelthat were your sister, ­granddaughter or daughter some old git was harassing ”To any man reading this who thinks it’s OK to talk to schoolgirls like this, let me tell you some of these girls are terried. It’s not funny or cute. It’s threatening. Lots of teen girls look older than they are butyou are confused and in doubt, here is a clue: The school unorm is a giveaway.Any man who leers at a child in a unorm is nothing short of ­disturbed. Andthey can’t stop themselves from doing so, the law needs to intervene.AS you know, I’m a huge advocate of body acceptance and self-love but I confess to a moment of envy at model Rachel McCord’s fantastic figure.Yes, clearly she must spend most of each day at the gym . . . But you have to give credit where credit is due. And she looks amazing!ANOTHER day, another crazy promise from Labour. This time it was Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell saying a Labour government would bring in a four-day working week.This, as Treasury analysis shows, means Labour would have to borrow £trillion to bankroll its spending spree over the next ten years – the equivalent of £, for every UK household. Frankly,the Labour Party gets into power, it will end up being a zero-day week as business will collapse and there will be no jobs to go to. The simple fact is you can’t run a country or a business on a four-day week.I LOVE a good party as much as the next person.But I can’t be the only person who rolled my eyes at the claim that Coldplay frontman Chris Martin and actress Dakota Johnson hosted a “baby gender reveal party” on Sunday.Apparently, large arches of pink and blue balloons were spotted flying above a star- studded bash at Martin’s Malibu home. Moments later, blue balloons were freed into the air, presumably announcing a baby boy is on the way.The couple claim it was just her birthday party but the singer did help introduce us to the term “conscious uncoupling”. Stand by for this being a new thing . . .She was being “punished” for running away with her Hindu boyfriend.Police were reportedly called to the scene but did not make any arrests – which beggars belief, doesn’t it Stories like this are a reminder that religion can be a negative power as well as a positive.I COULDN’T agree more with Sir Anthony Seldon, above, Buckingham University’s vice-chancellor, who wants the uni to adopt an actively anti-drugs stance.My son is at Buckingham uni and they already have snfer dogs all around campus, randomly checking students. Sir Anthony says he wants to create a “psychological contract” between students and the university so undergraduates implicitly agree to shun drugs when they enrol, which I think is a brilliant idea.His approach is the opposite to Sheffield University, where the student union gave advice on how to take ious hard drugs safely. But the fact is drugs aren’t safe and they ruin lives.  Barely a week goes by without another drug death appearing in the news.Some might say a drug-free campus is unrealistic. And sure, you probably can’t stop everyone taking them.  Nor can you prevent people wanting to experiment.  But making young people really aware that drugs are not only dangerous but illegal can only be a good thing.A WRITER called Kamin Mohammadi had an Instagram rant about “manspreading” this week. And yes, I know this happens. But I think we’ve got to get better at politely asking people to just stop it.Forget gender for a moment. I think it comes down to respect: It’s just blatantly rude to invade someone ’s space and the answer, in my view, is to call the person out.  If someone’s arm is on my arm rest on a train or plane, I ask them – in the nicest possible way – to move it.Let’s not be embarrassed when it’s someone’s legs.My personal bugbear is backpacks. I called a man out for keeping his on while on a crowded Tube train this week and he was really apologetic.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pm must secure free trade deal
story: As the Prime Minister heads into the most signicant EU summit, she must secure the Brexit promised to the ­British public.Now is the time to deliver for the United Kingdom on the Conservatives’  General Election manesto promise to take back control of our laws, borders, money and trade.It does not get clearer than the pledge: “We will no longer be members of the single market or customs union.”  Our manesto also promised that our laws would be made in the UK and interpreted by judges here, not in Europe. That’s why the Prime Minister’s Chequers proposal was not right.Under such a deal, we would be required to follow EU laws under the EU rule book and we would still be subject to the European Court of Justice.We would be out of Europe, yet still run by Europe. Any proposal that is brought forward and put to Parliament needs to take back control of our laws and make sure the European Court has no say over us.  So what should Theresa May do  The answer, once again, is set out clearly in the  Conservative manesto.It says: “We will seek a deep and special partnership including a comprehensive free-trade and customs agreement.”  That’s why the Prime Minister should move on from her Chequers proposal and seek an advanced free-trade deal with the EU. A comprehensive free-trade deal, like the EU’s free-trade deals with Canada and Japan, is what our manesto promises require.Such a deal would ensure we take back control of our laws, borders, money and trade. It would honour the referendum mandate. It would be in line with our manesto commitments. And it would work for the EU too. The Government’s objection to this is the supposed dficulty of keeping an open border in Northern Ireland.For this reason, Government figures claim we cannot seek a trade deal with the EU unless this problem is solved. This is nonsense.Clear proposals have been set out by two former Northern Ireland Secretaries as to how a frictionless border can be maintained under a free-trade agreement. These proposals have been endorsed by former Brexit Secretary David Davis and Good Friday Agreement architect Lord Trimble.Moreover, former Cabinet minister Iain Duncan Smith has set out how we can build on the system of joint border controls at Dover to avoid delays or friction at the UK’s borders — including in Ireland. This would work for the EU’s rules and ensure a positive future relationship going forward.This approach is not simply a bad use of taxpayers’ money. It breaks another manesto pledge.For our  manesto says “it is necessary to agree the terms of our future partnership alongside our withdrawal, reaching agreement on both within two years” of our serving notice to leave the EU. In other words, by the end of March next year.So it is wrong for the Government to agree withdrawal terms without sorting out the full detail of our future relationship. A temporary fix does not honour the referendum mandate, it does not keep our manesto promise and it certainly fails to look after our hard-earned money.Moreover, would this temporary fix really be temporary  Just ask the people of Norway how such a deal turned out for them. In  they signed the European Economic Area Agreement. They were told by the EU their sovereignty would be respected. Yet  years later, this “temporary” arrangement has become permanent.Meanwhile, the cost has increased ten-fold and nearly , EU directives and regulations have been implemented through Norway’s EEA agreement.Our Government should fear to tread such a dangerous path. Voters will not tolerate any “temporary” arrangement becoming permanent. They would see it as a betrayal. People voted to leave the EU because they wanted change. They believed in Britain and the land of opportunity we can build. They voted to take back control of our laws, money, borders and trade.The Conservative manesto promised that we would leave the EU altogether. That we would seek a free-trade deal and a new national future.Now is the time for the Government to honour the referendum mandate and the Conservative manesto by seeking a free­-trade deal with the EU that enables Britain to become an economic powerhouse in the decades to come.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
