title: starving dog skinny bones north shields car park
story: The neglected Staffordshire Bull Terrier, named Ayma by vets caring for her, was discovered in the early hours of Friday morning by a member of the public walking in North Shields, Tyne and Wear.The RSPCA are now looking into the incident in which the poor Staffy was so seriously underweight that all of her bones were visible through her skin.RSPCA inspector Cathy Maddison, who is now investigating the appalling case, says no amount of experience working in animal rescue can prepare you for seeing a dog so horrendously starved.She said on Friday: I dont know how she is still alive and what is even more heartbreaking is just how lovely and friendly she is, despite what she has been through.She is now on fluids at the vets and has been given some much-needed food.Sadly, it is really touch and go for her as she is so emaciated so it’s not knownshe will pull through the night.Unfortunately, Cathys fears were confirmed when vets took the dficult decision to put Ayma to sleep last night after her appalling condition deteriorated.The Staffy wasnt microchipped but was believed to be about four years old and was found covered in fleas.The man that found Ayma told Cathy he was on his way to a job interview when he came across the poor pup.He wrapped her up in a towel to keep her warm and contacted the RSPCA to get urgent help, but ultimately her sickness was too far gone for vets to save her.Earlier this year, The Sun and the RSPCA put out a call for people to come forward and adopt puppies and dogs that have been abandoned or abused across the UK.Tens of thousands of dogs are abandoned in Britain every year for a iety of reasons ranging from poverty, human sickness, and the puppy trade churning out designer dogs.

title: universal credit sanctions under 30s iain duncan smith
story: New figures show that more than  per cent of penalties under the Governments controversial new system land on Brits under .Campaigners have demanded that the system - which has been beset with problems so far - be halted while the issues are fixed, or even scrapped altogether.Today the architect of the scheme, Iain Duncan Smith, said ministers would be betraying the Just About Managing Britsit didnt help plough extra money into the scheme.He told Skys Sophy Ridge on Sunday programme: Theresa May stood on the steps of Downing Street and said I want to look after those who are just about managing.Universal Credit is the single best system to get to those who are just about managing... we need to put the money in. Im asking him to do that. Nobody should lose at all.Ministers have reversed some of the cuts to the welfare budget - but Brits are still set to lose out under the new regime.Today  Tories signed a campaign urging Theresa May to change rack and reverse the planned cutts.Research from Labour showed that out of , decisions to sanction Brits under Universal Credit, , were for those under  - and a fth were for claimts who were aged  and .Most sanctions are handed out because claimants failed to attend scheduled appointments.

title: pregnant woman lost baby says unborn child saved her life
story: Louise Abbott, , was  weeks pregnant when Leroy Margolis, , veered across the road and ploughed into her car.The nursery worker, from Braintree, Essex, was saved from suffering fatal injuries due to the baby bump taking the impact.But tragically baby Layla died from a fractured skull and heartbroken Louise had to give birth to her because she was too injured for a cesarean.Louise has now received an undisclosed financial settlement to pay for the specialist therapies and support she is continuing to receive following her ordeal.She said: The crash, finding out Layla had died and then giving birth to her is something that will stay with me for the rest of my le.It is almost impossible to put into words the effect it has had on me and [husband] Laurence.We go through a full mix of emotions each day knowing that Layla should still be part of our family and thinking what , even though the events were clearly out of our control.Louise was being driven to a wedding party on October , , in Cambridgeshire when Margolis overtook a lorry at mph.He lost control at a staggered junction and smashed into the car Louise was travelling in with a witness describing his driving as suicidal.The former Lloyds banker was caged for two years last year after being convicted of causing serious injury by dangerous driving.Louise was later told by medics she may never have children because of one of her oies had been rendered useless as a result of her injuries.But her and husband Laurence, , welcomed a healthy daughter named Avery last year.At first we felt guilty because of Layla but Avery was not a replacement for Layla.Layla will also be part of our family. Avery will know all about her big sister but we will always be sad that they never got to meet each other and grow up with one another, forming the bonds and friendships sisters should.Louise said previously: Our babyhad little nails and hair and she was fully formed, fully developed, ready to be born the next day.But now, we know that without I might not be alive had it not been for the accident- and little Avery wouldnt have been born, and I wouldnt be here to have more children in the future.Because of the extra blood I had in me due to my pregnancy, and because Layla cushioned the bump, I wouldnt have lived had it not been for her.I will never forget those words, Im sorry, your baby has died.The mum has joined their legal team at Irwin Mitchell in using Baby Loss Awareness Week to speak out about the support available to other families who have experienced the heartbreak of losing a child.Tracey Storey, Partner and specialist serious injury lawyer at the firm, said: It may have been two years since Layla’s death but the pain and loss that Louise and Laurence continue to experience is still understandably extremely raw.While no amount of money will ever make up for what has happened, we are pleased that Louise has been able to access the support she needs so she, Laurence and their family can try and look to the future the best they can while never forgetting Layla.

title: brexit deal latest dominic raab brussels talks showdown
story: Michel Barnier told EU ambassadors that talks with the Brexit boss didnt go well when the pair held surprise negotiations talks to thrash out a deal on the Northern Ireland border.Four diplomats confirmed a key meeting of EU leaders’ top advisors - known as Sherpas - due to take place on Monday had been cancelled due to a lack of progress.Brexit Secretary Mr Raab dashed out to the Belgian capital for emergency talks with EU negotiator Mr Barnier yesterday afternoon amid hopes of a breakthrough.But last night he said: “Despite intense efforts some key issues are still open including the backstop.”And it is understood Mr Raab told the Frenchman that the UK has objections to the terms of the withdrawal treaty beyond just the border solution.An EU diplomat said: “They’re still trying to solve the most dficult issues. No agreement has been reached. No agreement, no Sherpas.“There’s been no new progress. The issue of the Irish border is the main reason. Our hopes are now for the end of November.”A second diplomat said there had been “some progress” but it only amounted to “small steps” in the right direction.A joint statement by No  and the Department for Exiting the European Union said: “In the last few days UK and EU negotiators have made real progress in a number of key areas. However there remain a number of unresolved issues relating to the backstop.“The UK is still committed to making progress at the October European Council.”Representatives from the  other EU nations were told there wasnt yet a deal over the UKs exit from the bloc, and further meetings were needed to get a deal.Mr Raabs last-minute trip was announced after it was reported last night in German press that a deal was set to be sealed today.It came just three days before Theresa May is set to travel to Brussels to give her final pitch to other EU leaders over dinner, in the hopes of securing a deal.One source told the Press Association: It’s very much in the EU’s interests to make it look like there is a deal, as it would look like we are the ones being intransigent.Mr Barnier said last month he needed to see maximum progress by this weeks European Council meeting to make sure a hard border in Northern Ireland would be avoided.And the EUs Donald Tusk branded this week the moment of truth for a Brexit deal.But another summit has already been pencilled in for Novembera deal cant be reached by then.The Northern Irish border is a sticking point for both sides - Mrs May needs to keep her DUP allies happy by making sure theres no extra checks in the Irish sea, but also ensure that her Brexiteers are kept on side too, who want to ensure a clean break with the bloc.However, it was reported yesterday that the DUP boss thinks No Deal is the most likely outcome - after she had hostile talks with Mr Barnier in Brussels last week.The talks are stalled over what should happen with trade and Northern Irelandno Brexit deal is reached.Earlier today Health Secretary Matt Hancock raised the option thata definitive end-date for the Brexit backstop isnt stated, then there could be another get-out clause that Britain could trigger which would mean we would not stay in a customs union with the EU indefinitely.He told the BBCs Andrew Marr Show: The proposal is that is it temporary and time-limited. There are dferent ways to make sure it is time-limited.You can set conditions under which the arrangements come to an end.Previously Brexiteers had been unhappy that the Northern Ireland backstop would have no specied end-date.But another form of break clause could be an alternative option that could keep Leave-backing members of the Cabinet onside.Four ministers could be on the verge of quitting, it was revealed today.The news came as:

title: new five pound world high street bargain chain where everything costs 5 set to open 150 stores
story: Five Pound World aims to take Britain by storm over the next  months with ambition to take the retail spaces left vacant by Poundworld.Poundworld collapsed in June with the loss of , jobs and  stores.Five Pound World opened its first branch in Burton-on-Trent, Staffs, last month and two more are due to open this month  in Derby and Walthamstow in North London.The discount chain is the brainchild of Dev Singh, managing director of Opium Group, a firm describing itself as trading in ious sectors all over the world.Everything costs £ with plans to also sell cheaper products in multi-buy deals at the same price point. An example given was Domestos bleach spray at four for £.The range currently consists of only general merchandise and homewares but this is only a quarter of what is planned, with food and other fast-moving consumer goods to be added in multibuy deals, a source told industry magazine The Grocer.Five Pound World is set to go head-to-head with competitors such as BM by opening other shops across the country.Bosses hope that raising the single price point will help Five Pound World escape some of the pressure on pound shop margins from the devaluation of sterling.

title: historic drakes island off devon coast goes on sale for 6m and could be transformed into caribbean style hotel
story: But you’ll need a cool £million to take on this six-acre property off the coast at Plymouth, once used to defend against France and Spain.Unfortunately it’s not as yet a Caribbean-style paradise, thanks to its centuries-old derelict gun battery, former barracks, crumbling ablution blocks, commanding officer’s house and guardhouse.However the current owners of Drake’s Island hope a buyer will be drawn to the site’s huge potential as a luxury hotel and spa complex – for which there is planning permission.Former Plymouth Argyle owner Dan McCauley bought the island from the Crown in  for £,.His son, Aidan, , told The Sunday Times his dad described it as “the jewel in the crown of Plymouth”.“We want to see the place come back to le. It has to come back to le,” he added.In August this year Plymouth Live reported that the development of a “stunning waterfront location entertaining the rich and famous” could finally begin after a marine licence was granted to enable the repair of the ageing jetty.It said this work would clear the way for “experts to gain access and begin transforming the maritime jewel into a world-class spa complete with a high-end hotel, conference facilities and a posh restaurant with commanding views of Plymouth Sound.”Formerly known as St Nicholas Island, after a chapel there, it was used during the Tudor period, having been fortied from “at least the th century”, according to Plymouth City Council.The first fortication was commissioned as part of the country’s maritime line of defence during the war with France, and strengthened in the late s by the installation of guns and garrisons during the war with Spain.It was named after Sir Francis Drake as he set sail from the island in  to famously circumnavigate the globe.Interestingly, two centuries later, Royal Museums Greenwich says, “the first recorded submarine fatality occurred north of Drake’s Island just two years after Captain Cook’s departure [from Plymouth in ], when a carpenter named John Day died while testing a wooden ing chamber.”Although regarded as a heritage site of national importance, with signicant wildle, the council last year gave the green light for a major resort complex.This includes conversion of the existing Grade II buildings and the Scheduled Ancient Monument casemated battery.Drake’s Island’s website explains its plans include reusing the former Governor’s island house, barrack block and ablutions building “as the core for the hotel development”.The barracks will be turned into a -room hotel, while the casemates will become luxury suites.An extensive network of underground tunnel, originally intended for the store of ammunitions and safe passage to the Casemates, will provide access and points of interest for visitors to the island.They will also “serve as cellars and wine stores for the hotel,” the website said.John Kinsey, a director at JLL in Exeter, which is marketing the property, said: Drakes Island is a remarkable piece of British history and a much-loved landmark that the Plymouth community holds close to its heart.

title: cops let thief go 9k tools
story: Cops were called when neighbours spotted shty men breaking into Slawek Zarebas vehicle overnight on Saturday.Officers arrived and found a man loading nearly  boxes of gear from Mr Zarebas van into another car in Morden, South London.But instead of nicking the thief on the spot, blundering cops had a chat with him and allowed the chancer to drive off with a car full of loot.Tradesman Mr Zareba , woke the next morning to find his whole van emptied.He now has no tools to work with and has slammed cops for letting the theft unfold in front of them. He said: Its absolutely ridiculous what happened.I cant understand what the police are playing at.It was am at the time and I was inside my house, completely unaware of what was happening.Instead of quizzing the thief, checking the car registration details or even knocking my door to double-check, they had a talk with him and watched as they let him waltz off into the night.The police havent even apologised or been back to get fingerprints from my van or look at the CCTV.I havent been able to work since and am losing money.CCTV footage shows the moment police arrive and speak to the thief - who has his own car boot open and a collection of Mr Zarebas tools hanging out the back.Cops bizarrely then get back in their patrol car and drive off behind his car - only for the man tosome  minutes later and continue raiding the van.The gaffe follows reports that cops are not properly investigating nearly a million reported crimes a year.Home Office data shows police abandoned nearly three quarters of car theft probes without identying a suspect.And figures show four fths of house burglaries and nearly half of shoplting cases go unsolved.A Met Police spokesman said: Police were called to reports of a vehicle being broken into in Morden, South London.Officers attended and found a man loading tools from a van into another vehicle.The man gave an explanation for his actions and no arrests were made.Police later established the tools had been stolen. An investigation was launched and a warrant was executed at a property in Morden.A number of items were recovered.The suspect remains outstanding and enquiries continue. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: twins squash uk record with 6ft 174st giant pumpkin the weight of a ford fiesta and it can make 810 pumpkin pies
story: Stuart and Ian Paton, , used more than  gallons of water a day to grow their enormous squash.They already held the UK record with a steffort last year, but smashed that on Saturday with the second-biggest pumpkin of all-time.It has a world-record circumference of more than ft, and took  days to hit full size from pollination.The pair, from Lymington, Hants, are the only people to have grown five weighing more than ,lbs.The brothers unveiled their latest at the Autumn Pumpkin Festival in Netley, Hants.They have now set their sights on the world record, currently held by a Belgian, with a monster .st .Ian said: “We will celebrate with a couple of beers. We have a few improvements to make for next year and I’m sure we will break the world record,not in  then the year after.“We won’t rest until we’ve done it! The secret is having the very best seeds.“We cross-breed the very best each year so seeds from this giant will go to making next year’s.“You also need very light and fluffy soil and then you need to add an awful lot of water.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markle prince harry sydney tour australia new zealand
story: The pair held hands and smiled as they arrived Down Under, accompanied by a ten-man entourage for their first international tour as a couple. Despite the long-haul flight - which saw the couple briefly stopover in Singapore - the Duke and Duchess of Sussex looked fresh and excited for their tour as they were greeted by excited fans.But Meghan sparked a flurry of pregnancy rumours, clutching purple folders in front of her stomach as she walked hand in hand with her husband.Eagle-eyed fans were quick to speculate with Meghans latest appearance - just days after similar rumours were sparked when the former American actress wore a loose-fitting coat to Princess Eugenies wedding. Meghan, who has never been to Australia before, beamed as she was ushered into a car with Prince Harry.Harry and Meghan were met by many police officers at Sydney Airport who escorted them to their hotel.Among their ten-person strong entourage will be Meghans best friend and stylist Jessica Mulroney, as the duchess is expected to change her outfit up to three times a day.Harry wore a grey jumper and put his bag into the boot of a car as he gave a thumbs up to onlookers.The couple will have a lowkey start to their tour, not starting official duties until Tuesday.But the couple were spotted stretching their legs after arriving at Admiralty House, where they will be staying.The prince was spotted by Nine News, with the -year-old clutching the hand of his we as they strolled around the grounds before heading inside.They are expected to meet with Governor-General Sir Peter Cosgrove and his we tomorrow.They will not receive an official welcoming ceremony which is often tradition for the arrival of British Royals in Commonwealth countries.As part of the tour, the couple will travel to many Australian cities in the first week including Sydney, Melbourne, Dubbo and Fraser Island.After spending a week in Australia, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex will head to Fiji, Tonga and finally New Zealand before they make the long journey home on October .Harry and Meghan will use charter flights to get to Fiji and Tonga and will then have the use of a New Zealand Air Force plane to get to most of their engagements.Among  engagements, the Invictus Games Sydney  will be the main event of their royal visit.Prince Harry founded the event in  which gives sick and injured service personnel and veterans the chance to compete in a iety of sports.The couple will be present for the launch and closing ceremony.New South Wales police cleared the area and escorted Harry and Meghan to Admiralty House in Kirribilli where they will meet the Governor-General Sir Peter Cosgrove and his we.There was a crowd of people waiting outside the Governor-Generals house to greet the Duke and Duchess.The palace said in a statement: The programme across these four Commonwealth countries will focus on youth leadership, environmental and conservation efforts, including the dedication of several new Queens Commonwealth Canopy projects, and the recovery and rehabilitation of servicemen and women through the Invictus Games Sydney .During an interview in November the couple said they wanted to promote humanitarian causes close to their hearts across Commonwealth-member countries including Australia.Harry and Meghan will leave Australia for Fiji on October  and head to Tonga on October .They willto Sydney briefly before finally crossing the Tasman Sea to New Zealand on October , landing in Wellington, the countrys capital.Six months ago, Prince Charles made his th official visit to Australia to open the st Commonwealth Games at Gold Coast city in Queensland.The Duke and Duchess were seen looking glamorous at Harrys cousin Princess Eugenies wedding to Jack Brooksbank on Friday.A body expert claims they may have had a minor spat during the wedding ceremony.It is thought the royal couple left the celebrations early to make the -hour journey to Sydney.When Harry and Meghan travelled to Amsterdam for a star-studded boat party last month, their plane was struck by lightning, it has been reported.In a terrying mid-air drama, their Dassault Falcon X was hit close to its navigation equipment, narrowly avoiding a disaster.Despite being zapped with million volts, the aircraft landed safely at Schiphol Airport.

title: posties to combat loneliness with check and chat visits to thousands of vulnerable and isolated elderly brits
story: The PM will today reveal postal workers will take time out of their usual delivery round to speak to lonely and isolated people as she launches a cross-Government Loneliness Strategy.GPs will also be asked to prescribe social activities such as community art clubs or cooking classes for the lonely.And Ministers will launch a review of the impact the explosion of social media is having on loneliness among Britain’s youth.Some , older people have not had a conversation with a friend or relative for over a month. And GPs claim loneliness can be linked to conditions such as heart disease or Alzheimer’s.The PM will say: “Loneliness is a reality for too many people in our society today. IT can affect anyone of any age and background.“This strategy is only the beginning of delivering a long and far reaching social change in our country.”Postal workers launched a pioneering ‘Call and Check’ service in Jersey on the Channel Islands four years ago – with staff chatting to OAPs, help arrange grocery deliveries or book doctor’s appointments for them.The Royal Mail has approved trials of a similar scheme in Liverpool, Whitby and New Malden in Surrey.Theresa May committed £ million for charities and community projects tackling the misery of loneliness in June.It followed a ground-breaking report from the Jo Cox Commission established by the Labour MP murdered during the Referendum campaign.Announcing the strategy today, the PM will say three quarters of GPs claim to see between one and five people a day suffering with loneliness.A survey earlier this month claimed  to  year-olds were the “most likely” to feel lonely because of the pressure to present a perfect le on social media.Sports Minister Tracey Crouch was given the brief of ‘Minister for Loneliness’ in January.Speaking yesterday she said businesses from Sainsbury’s to the National Grid and British Red Cross had also signed up to do more to help their staff cope with feeling lonely.She said: “Nobody should feel alone or be left with no one to turn to. Loneliness is a serious issue that affects people of all ages and backgrounds and it is right that we tackle it head on.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit chancellor air passenger duty
story: They claim a £.billion cut to the “levy on holidays” will get Britain ready for take-off after Brexit.And Ulster unionists in the DUP will take their demand to the doors of the Treasury  in another high profile attack on Theresa May’s Government – which they prop up in the Commons.Dozens of Tories are believed to support the call.APD has soared from just £ in  to £ on one-way economy ticket for long-haul journeys.Campaigners claim this can make up nearly a third of the ticket price for some flights to Dubai.Short haul routes cost an extra £ in APD in economy.Writing for The Sun, ex-Tory Cabinet Minister Priti Patel and the DUP’s Sammy Wilson said: “The summer holidays are a distant memory and families across the country will be starting to save up for next year’s trip.“Yet a big chunk of that cost doesn’t pay for your holiday - it goes straight into the government’s coffers.“The UK has the highest short and long haul aviation tax anywhere in Europe. Cutting air passenger duty is exactly the kind of policy that Brexit Britain should embrace.”Cutting it will make holidays cheaper for families who have been hit by pricier trips because of the weaker Pound.On long haul flights, there is a £ tax on an economy ticket. This is a huge leap from  when it was just £.There is no environmental justication, it is simply used to fill the Treasury’s coffers. Slashing it will also boost businesses hoping to sell products outside of the EU. It will show BrexitBritain is an outward-looking, global nation.We hope you’re listening, Mr Hammond.“It would make saving for hard-earned holidays easier, and it would also make the UK a more attractive place to come to.The Chancellor this March launched a review into APD in Northern Ireland as promised in the confidence and supply deal Theresa May struck with the DUP after last year’s Election disaster.Belfast Airport claims that nearly a million passengers have switched to Dublin in the past year, where the tax was axed in  by Ireland’s then transport minister, current Taoiseach Leo Varadkar.Ms Patel and Mr Wilson said a cut would prove Northern Ireland was “open for business” as well as other regional UK airports.The total contribution from APD for the Treasury has ballooned from £ million in  to £. billion – a rise of  per cent.But campaigners claim there is little evidence the money is being used to tackle environmental issues.Frontier Economics last month claimed more than  new airline routes may be added at UK airportsthe Government abolished APD altogether.The think tank claimed an extra  routes would become viable, including eight new destinations from Aberdeen, nine from Belfast and seven from Southampton.James Roberts, political director of the Taxpayers Alliance, said: “Air Passenger Duty manages to fly under most people’s radar, but it has to be one of the most pointless taxes out there.“There’s no real environmental justication – it’s just a straight up levy on both family holidays and air trade links.”The summer holidays are a distant memory and families across the country will be starting to save up for next year’s trip. Yet a big chunk of that cost doesn’t pay for your holiday - it goes straight into the government’s coffers.Buying a ticket for a long-haul flight out of the UK will set you back at least £ in air passenger duty, a tax levied on all adult flyers from UK airports. So for a family of four flying in economy class, you’d have to fork out £, on top of whatever the airline is charging as their fare and airport charges.This is quite the increase from when two rates of either £ or £ was introduced in .Research released last year by A Fair Tax On Flying, which campaigns for a reduction in air passenger duty, shows that this tax makes up  per cent of the average cost of a European short-haul ticket.Looking around, you quickly realise our tax on flying is giving Brits a raw deal. The UK has the highest short and long-haul aviation tax anywhere in Europe. Countries nearby, like Ireland, have abolished their air taxes after seeing the bad effects it had for their economies. Northern Ireland gets hit particularly bad, as holidaymakers head to Dublin to dodge the unnecessary costs.Flying does have consequences, like emissions and noise for people who live right near airports, but the £. billion it raises pays for those many times over.Cutting air passenger duty is exactly the kind of policy that Brexit Britain should embrace. It would make saving for those hard-earned holidays easier, and it would also make the UK a more attractive place to come to. It would be a massive boon for Northern Ireland. Tourists and exporters would see that the country is open for business.Committing to cut air passenger duty in half would be a great message and save flyers millions. That’s why MPs from dferent parties are supporting this campaign from the TaxPayers’ Alliance and A Fair Tax On Flying. The Chancellor should commit to this in next week’s budget and make saving for holidays that bit easier.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: vaping aiming at kids
story: Nicotine liquids are banned from sale to youngsters under  as they are highly addictive and can harm brain development.But some are sold online under names such as Jam Doughnuts, Jelly Babies and Snowy Candy Bears for as little as £.The Royal Pharmaceutical Society compared the marketing of “sweet-treat” vape liquids with the sale of alcopops to underage drinkers.Firms deny targeting kids and claim the liquids are nostalgia products aimed solely at adults.But British American Tobacco has taken its E-Fizz and Dinner Lady products off its website pending a review. title: justgiving five per cent charity charge
story: The fundraising  will be free for those donating to emergency funds following tragedies such as a terror attack or a fire.It follows outrage over The Sun’s revelations earlier this year that JustGiving pocketed nearly half a million pounds from funds raised for victims of last year’s Grenfell Tower fire, Manchester bombing and London Bridge attack.It charges five per cent on all donations made on its site.It meant JustGiving kept £, of the £million raised to help survivors and relatives of the Grenfell blaze.The site raked in £, from the £. million of donations made to victims’ families and survivors of the Manchester Arena terror attack that killed  last year.And it took £, from the £, raised in the wake of the London Bridge atrocity - helping victims and Borough Market traders whose businesses were hit by the attack.But the site will continue to charge five per cent for all other charity donations on its site. It is only removing the fee for emergency fundraising and for its crowdfunding .And controversially it will continue to charge the five per cent fee on Gt Aid, which is the income tax charities can reclaim and helps boost charitable donations by an additional £. billion a year.It said it will consult on demands by ministers to stop charging commission on Gt Aid. Treasury Minister Robert Jenrick has threatened to ban fundraising sites like JustGiving from slapping the five per cent fee on Gt Aid.Peter Lewis, head of the Institute of Fundraising said: “We welcome today’s announcement from JustGiving.“We are pleased to see JustGiving continuing to develop its model and responding proactively to enable donors’ money to go even further, especially at times of major incidents.JustGiving boss Jerry Needel said: “We are very proud to announce that from today, people using JustGiving can crowdfund for free.”He added: “Following feedback from our amazing community of fundraisers, we are also announcing that JustGiving will now be free to use following major incidents including acts of terrorism, catastrophes or natural disasters.“We know people want to help those affected as quickly as possible after these events and we want to do everything we can to support that.”“We are excited about the signicant changes we are making and look forward to continuing our work supporting thousands of charities and millions of iniduals raising funds for the causes that matter to them the most.”Labour MP Neil Coyle, who has lobbied the government to ban sites from charging fees on donations, demanded JustGiving pay back the half a million pounds it took from Grenfell and terror attack funds last year.He said: It is reassuring that no company will again profit when disasters or terrorists strike in our country.But JustGiving must acknowledge the damage theyve done by picking the pockets of all the people affected by Grenfell or last years terror atrocities. Its payback timethey want to rebuild trust completely.John Coventry from the GoFundMe site, which doesnt charge a penny for fundraising, said: The vast majority of campaigns on JustGiving are people raising money for charity, and the companys whopping % fees will still apply to all those running marathons and doing their sponsored walks.When it comes to gt aid - JustGiving will keep pocketing % of taxpayers cash under the cover of a consultation. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: flint backs pm

title: brexit is worst defeat since 1066
story: As negotiations flicker to a halt, it seems Brexit actually means abject surrender, taking orders from Brussels and standing mute as the Council of Europe assumes control of our economy. We risk being sold down the river.Barring a last-minute revolt by Tory Brexiteers, Brussels has won and we have lost. The world’s sixth-largest economy will not just be worse off outside the EU, but reduced to a powerless political pawn on its margins — and paying for it.Sniggering can be heard across the capitals of Europe, with France guffawing loudest. The British Lion is a toothless kitten and we are the laughing stock of Europe.Unless stopped by her Cabinet, her MPs or by Parliament itself, this Prime Minister seems to be leading us to the greatest defeat since the Norman Conquest in , the last time we capitulated to a foreign power.The ransom demanded for our degrading humiliation — £BILLION of taxpayers’ money — is merely a down payment. The botched Chequers deal will bind this country in subordination to Europe.Forget about becoming a sovereign, free-trading nation. We will accept EU rules indefinitely while having no say at all in their terms or conditions. In effect, our economy will be run by Brussels, not by our democratically elected government.For an example of missed opportunities and failed leadership, this beats even last year’s election disaster, which wasted the first Tory majority for  years and put Marxist Labour within grasp of power.Worse, it now seems the PM’s apparent last-ditch capitulation was stitched up months ago behind closed doors after a dodgy threat by car giants to leave the UK.Now the Tory party is in uproar, with cries for a leadership contest. Downing Street is stupidly threatening a snap election. Nobody buys that except Jeremy Corbyn, who is licking his lips at the scent of power. Ministers, like frogs in a pot, are sizing up whether to jump or stew. Careers will be made or broken.At least three — and maybe six — are threatening to quit at tomorrow’s Cabinet unless Theresa blinks. Tory MPs are close to triggering a leadership fight, with sketchy plans for a quick and ruthless contest. “We have the numbers,” says one Tory MP.“If anything the mood is hardening, not softening.”Ex-Brexit secretary David Davis, the first rebel to quit Cabinet, will certainly run, infuriating Boris Johnson, who thinks it should be him. Once the gun is fired, half the Cabinet and plenty of hopefuls will join in.Everyone deserves blame, including Brexiteers who assumed the game was over after their victorious out vote and abandoned the field. Remainers are at fault for refusing to accept the will of the people — and the shortcomings of their beloved EU.But it is Downing Street, and Theresa May personally, who must take responsibility. Mrs May has dreamed of being Prime Minister since she was a child.It’s a tough job. It means leading from the front, making swt decisions and rallying the country with confidence and authority in dficult times.Instead, Mrs May’s team talk like defeatists about parliamentary “arithmetic”. How can she push through a dficult Brexit against ferocious opposition without a commanding Commons majority  But who was responsible for that parliamentary arithmetic It was Theresa May alone who decided to call an unforced election and it was she who single-handedly blew it. Her only task was to deliver the referendum mandate handed to her by .million voters. She blew that, too.People knew the risks. They did not vote for us to stay half-in, half-out or to see our sovereignty handed over to foreign powers. To govern is to decide. Mrs May made a career out of being the strong and silent type.Many of her MPs worry she is actually weak, vacillating and inarticulate.We are becoming accustomed to ruthless “wet jobs” by authoritarian tyrannies such as Russia, North Korea and the People’s Republic of China, many of them “friends” of Jeremy Corbyn.But Saudi Arabia has always revelled in public and private bloodshed. When it comes to terrorism, all roads lead back to Riyadh.A respectable MP, who does not joke about such matters, tells me the Saudi Embassy in London once had a torture chamber in the basement.I wonderit still does Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The humorous photos show the tail sticking out of the young brown bears mouth as he enjoys every last bit of a juicy salmon.Amateur photographer Isabel Hernandez, , took the pictures at Lake Clark National Park, Alaska, where she spotted the  month old bear munching on the fishtail.He had actually been given just the tail to chew after his mother had caught the fish and eaten the rest.Isabel said: The cub was lying on the beach while its mum was fishing. When the mum caught one she wouldto the cub, but wouldnt give him any.He would watch her eating, whining and making grunting noises but mum wouldn’t give him anything.My pictures show the fishtail that was left after the mum had finished with the rest of the fish.The cub played with it for about an hour and it was very entertaining viewing.Cubs are like little kids, they are very curious and will play with anything and everything.I took these photos while lying flat on my stomach about  to  yards away.Isabel, from Elkton in Maryland, USA, said she made a y journey to Lake Clark in order to take photos of mother bears with cubs.She said: I flew  hours from Philadelphia to Anchorage and from there I jumped on a tiny, four-person plane to the remote location of Lake Clark.The flight was delayed for two days because of bad conditions, but we finally made it and stayed in a small lodge from where we could drive up and down the lake looking for the bears. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: On Wednesday, she flies to Brussels for the European Council summit.With mounting Cabinet unease over the prospect of a Customs Union fudge, it is, as one Government source puts it, “squeaky bum time”.Four potential ministerial resignations loom over fears Britain could be tied to a permanent Customs Union. title: brexit pizza club plots theresa
story: NewsBrexit pizza club plots Theresa Mays downfall ahead of EU summit as last-minute talks end in deadlockBrexiteer Cabinet ministers could launch a bid to kill off the PMs Brexit plan after Dominic Raab made a failed last-minute dash to BrusselsShareCommentsByAndrew GregoryPolitical Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsThe PM is facing the sack from No as Ministers plot over pasta how to kill Brexit plans "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May is facing the biggest threat to her premiership with a two-pronged attack from warring Tories over her Brexit plan. Brexiteer Cabinet ministers will on Monday night plot over pizza how to kill it off, which could lead to her being toppled. In a second equally lethal threat,  letters demanding a vote of no confidence in the Prime Minister had by Sunday evening been submitted by Tory MPs to the Conservative  Committee. That is just four short of the number required to trigger a ballot, which could see Mrs May being dumped from No. The “pizza club” has reportedly met secretly during times of crisis in Brexit negotiations.  Its latest meeting comes ahead of a crunch summit of EU leaders on Wednesday. And at least nine Ministers want Mrs May to drop her current EU plan when the Cabinet meets on Tuesday. Former Brexit Secretary David Davis today urged a full-scale rebellion against her. He wrote in a newspaper: “It is time for the Cabinet to exert their collective authority. This week the authority of our constitution is on the line.” His successor Dominic Raab ed empty-handed from last-minute talks in Brussels on Sunday night - despite speculation Britain had stitched up a secret deal with EU chiefs.  Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt said the talks were a bid to seeprogress could be made on outstanding issues and a sign of “how much effort we are putting in”. But EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier tweeted: “Despite intense efforts, some key issues are still open, including the backstop for IE NI to avoid a hard border. I will debrief the EU.” A joint statement by the Brexit Department and  Downing Street did not even commit to the issue being resolved on Wednesday - it only said there would be progress. The statement said: In the last few days UK and EU negotiators have made real progress in a number of key areas.However there remain a number of unresolved issues relating to the backstop.“The UK is still committed to making progress at the October European Council.” The backstop – a mechanism to avoid a hard border – poses a threat to Mrs May’s leadership. The EU’s version would keep just Northern Ireland aligned with Brussels’ rules. Mrs May’s counter-proposal is for a “temporary customs arrangement” for the whole of the UK. But Tory Brexiteers fear it could become an open-ended position which would prevent free trade deals around the world. Mr Hunt insisted only Mrs May could get the right deal for Britain, adding: “She is battling for Britain”. But Tory MP Nadine Dorries suggesting installing Mr Davis as interim leader, adding: “Getting May out and him becoming an interim leader may be the only way to deliver Brexit and FTA.” Allies of Mr Davis said he has been contacted by several Tory MPs urging him to run for the leadership. He is understood to be prepared to runthere is a contest.  Critics of Mrs May believe the no confidence vote threshold could be passed by Wednesdayshe refuses to change her position. At least four Cabinet Minister are rumoured to be seriously considering quitting over her Brexit plan. Speculation has centred on Andrea Leadsom , Penny Mordaunt and Esther McVey . But Scottish Secretary David Mundell, and Scottish Tory leader Ruth Davidson, could also quit. In a letter to the PM, the pair said the integrity of the UK “remains the single most important issue for us”. They indicated they will not tolerate a situation in which Northern Ireland is treated dferently from the rest of Britain over the EU customs issues. A source close to Ms Davidson said the issue was a “red line” for her, while a source close to Mr Mundell said resigning was a “logical outcome” for those who do not agree with Government policy. Mrs May, pictured today at her local church with husband Philip, depends on the votes of the Democratic Unionist Party , who prop up her minority administration. According to a private email exchange between senior UK officials, DUP leader Arlene Foster has indicated her party was “ready for a no-deal scenario, which she now believed was the likeliest one”. But Shadow Foreign Secretary Emily Thornberry said the Labour party wanted a “meaningful vote”, adding: “If she comes back with something that’s just a fudge she’s cooked up with Brussels... we’re not voting for something that’s essentially a bridge to nowhere.”

The national interest is largely forgotten with Brexit a battleground for Tory rivals, bloodlust opponents agonising over what’s best for them rather than the country. When the post of Prime Minister’s the goal of wavering Ministers calculating whether it’s better to back or sack May, the jobs of millions who voted to Leave and Remain are collateral damage for Tories obsessed with their own futures. I’ve never witnessed a Government disintegrate with the poisonous animosity of May’s collapsing regime. The reigns of Thatcher, Major, Blair, Brown and particularly Cameron finished in acrimony – an iron law of politics the tenure of all PMs end in failure. Yet this Conservative uncivil war’s unmatched in bile, squabbling Tories too busy scoring points against each other to champion Britain in negotiations with  united European neighbours.  At such a crucial juncture for the country, revolting Conservative MPs coming close to submitting the  letters triggering a self-indulgent leadership contest is proof Brexit is all about them, not you. Plastic patriots, right-wing nationalists blindly waving flags to hide their cluelessness, call the shots in a misgoverning party’s increasing Ukipisation that is symbolised by the membership of a purple Colonel Blimp former MEP, offensive reactionary Godfrey Bloom. So Andrea Leadsom, Penny Mordaunt and Esther McVey fret over staying or going, boosting or ruining their chances of the Premiership. Jeremy Hunt and Sajid Javid fuss over supporting or opposing May’s Brexit plan for the same reasons.  And David Davis and Boris Johnson compete to be the most aggressive quitter. Whatever Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab, another with his eye on the personal prize, agrees with EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier is irrelevantMay loses the Tory Party, never mind Parliament. She is left relying on Labour rebels in a salvage operation, just as Ted Heath depended on John Smith to take us into Europe in . The best deal remains Britain’s continued EU membership. The tragedy is too many MPs are scared to tell the truth.

title: saudi arabia vows retaliate against
story: NewsJamal Khashoggi: Saudi Arabia vows to retaliate against any action over the murder of journalistWashington Post journalist vanished in Istanbul on October  and US President Donald Trump has threatened to “punish” Saudi Arabiaits found to have had a hand in killing himShareCommentsByAndrew GregoryPolitical Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video police-footage-detailing-saudi-squads-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSaudi Arabia has dramatically vowed to retaliate against any action taken by the West over missing journalist Jamal Khashoggi. The country is ready to hit back against any punitive action “with a bigger one”, a source quoted by state news agency SPA warned. Washington Post journalist Mr Khashoggi vanished on October  after visiting the Saudi consulate in Istanbul. US President Donald Trump has threatened to “punish” Saudi Arabiait were found responsible for killing him. And Health Secretary Matt Hancock warned Saudi Arabia would suffer “serious consequences”evidence showed the country murdered Mr Khashoggi. But the source quoted by SPA said: “The kingdom affirms its total rejection of any threats or attempts to undermine it whether through threats to impose economic sanctions or the use of political pressure. “The kingdom also affirms that it will respond to any action with a bigger one. The Saudi economy has vital and influential roles for the global economy.”  The war of words came as a joint statement by the foreign ministers of the UK, France and Germany called for a credible investigation to ensure those responsible for Mr Khashoggi’s disappearance were held to account. “We encourage joint Saudi-Turkish efforts in that regard, and expect the Saudi Government to provide a complete and detailed response,” said Jeremy Hunt, Jean-Yves Le Drian and Heiko Maas. Britain and the US are considering boycotting a major international conference in Saudi Arabia this month. Turkey believes Mr Khashoggi was murdered in the consulate by Saudi agents. Saudi Arabia says this is “lies”. Reports say Mr Khashoggi may have recorded his own murder on his Apple Watch. They claim the device was logging his interrogation by a -strong hit squad. A copy of the audio then synced with his iPhone, which he had handed to his fianceacutee before entering the Saudi consulate in Istanbul. It is claimed the recording automatically uploaded to his iCloud account.  Fianceacutee Hatice Cengiz would have had to have been in bluetooth range outside the embassy to receive the audio on the phone. It was also alleged Saudi officials tried to delete the watch recording - first by incorrectly guessing Mr Khashoggi’s PIN, then later using the journalist’s finger. Apple Watches do not have a fingerprint ID unlock , unlike iPhones. The reports remain unconfirmed.. Washington Post journalist Khashoggi, a staunch critic of Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, has been missing since visiting the consulate on October . Turkish officials believe he was executed by an assassination squad. They also alleged that they have video of the murder, but have yet to explain how they have it. Saudi Interior Minister Prince Abdu-laziz bin Saud said: “What has been circulating about orders to kill are lies and baseless allegations against the government of the kingdom.” Turkey’s Foreign Minister Mevut Cavusoglu urged Saudi Arabia to start co-operating with the investigation and to let Turkish officials into the consulate.  UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres has demanded “the truth” over Mr Khashoggi. He said he feared such disappearances would become a “new normal”. Meanwhile, Labour Shadow Foreign Secretary Emily Thornberry has vowed that Britain would stop selling weapons to Saudi ArabiaLabour were elected into government. She also slammed the UK government response to Mr Khashoggi’s disappearance, saying the Tories had failed to hold the Saudis to account in the face of mounting evidence.  Ms Thornberry said the alleged murder was “yet more evidence of how the Saudi prince in particular appears to be out of control” and “this country has had enough”. A critic of Saudi Arabia’s de facto ruler Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, Mr Khashoggi was living in self-imposed exile in the US and writing opinion pieces for the Washington Post before he vanished. He visited the consulate on October  to obtain a document confirming he had orced his ex-we, in order to allow him to remarry. Turkish officials have said he was killed on the premises and his body removed. Saudi officials have denied the allegations as baseless.

title: tory matt hancock claims hes
story: NewsTory Matt Hancock boasts hes had no letters about Universal Credit - just  days after mums e-mailEXCLUSIVE: Single mum Joanne Sansom accused Matt Hancock of a "bare-faced lie" after warning him shed lost £ a week - only for the MP to claim hed had "no letters at all"ShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror tv tv-news video matt-hancock-on-universal-credit-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Tory minister who boasted hes had no letters at all about Universal Credit was sent an e-mail about it by a desperate single mum just three days ago. Joanne Sansom, , wrote to Matt Hancock on Thursday complaining she had lost pound a week while caring for her autistic nine-year-old son Joshua.But today the Health Secretary - who has even set up an app to talk to constituents - claimed: Ive seen Universal Credit in operation in my own constituency, where I’ve had no letters on it at all.Joanne said she was left in anger and disbelief by Mr Hancocks performance on the BBCs Andrew Marr Show - which she branded a bare-faced lie. She told the Mirror: Ive never personally experienced a politician lying. You obviously hear that they do and you know they spin things to suit their agenda.Are you a West Suffolk constituent who has written to Matt Hancock about Universal Credit  If so contact ususing the form at the bottom of this article. I just couldnt believe it. I can pretty much guarantee Im not the only person [who wrote to him] - I would put every single penny in my bank account on that. Universal Credit, which combines six legacy benefits into one monthly payment, first rolled out to Mr Hancocks rural West Suffolk seat in October . Joanne, from Stanton, said she moved onto UC around two months ago when her seasonal warehouse job ended - triggering a change in circumstances. She told the Mirror she receives around pound a month in UC, plus carers allowance and a Disability Living Allowance award for her son.  Joanne claimed she first wrote to Mr Hancock in September, but had since deleted the e-mail account she used so could provide no proof. Mr Hancocks office found no record of that correspondence today. However, the Mirror has confirmed she sent a second e-mail, dated October , in which she told the MP: The amount UC pays me is pound a week less than what I was receiving on tax credits and income support. I was completely unaware that this was going to happen and not told by anyone in the process that I would actually be paid less than I was before. I am now in a financial crisis whilst trying to care and provide for a disabled child. I am of working age, but cannot have a full-time job because of my caring responsibilities.A food bank in the next-door seat to Mr Hancocks warned in July its stocks were at critical levels amid record demand due to benefit changes.Days later a letter to the Bury Free Press urged locals to write to Mr Hancock to stop UC leaving people without free NHS prescriptions.Mr Hancock has previously been accused of failing to reply to constituents.Jacqui McKay wrote to the Bury Free Press in July: I had cause to write to him last year but did not receive a reply or even an acknowledgement. I also know of a charity that contacted him and, like me, had no response. She did not say what the letters were about. Mr Hancock was also accused of failing to respond to a local parish council on a separate issue in . He defended the delay at the time saying I receive hundreds of letters and e-mails a week.A source close to the minister admitted the e-mail had been received but staff had not had time to update Mr Hancock on it. The source said it took up to a fortnight to respond to correspondence. A spokesman for Mr Hancock’s office said: We have recently received an email from a constituent that Matt wasnt aware of and he will respond in the usual way.  UC has already rolled out to .million people, % of whom have a job, and .million existing claimants will move onto it from July. Labour and Tory backbenchers have urged the rollout to be stopped, while its Tory architect Iain Duncan Smith has demanded poundbillion is put back into the system. This week Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey admitted some claimants will be worse off. Mr Hancock insisted that for people who are migrated onto the new benefit, there is a poundbn package to ensure people aren’t worse off. The Mirror are demanding a halt to the expansion of Universal Credit and for a review to take place. We say there are three options:Redesign UC to be fit for purpose Axe it in favour of the old systemUC is unfixable Introduce a brand new systemSign our petition to stop the rollout of Universal Credit across Britain and to replace it with a fairer system by signing our petition. But claimants like Joanne who move due to a change of circumstances are not part of the migration process. Tory Vice Chairman James Cleverly today accepted the benefit needs to be well-resourced as talk swirls of a possible climbdown in the Budget on October . Meanwhile Labours stance on Universal Credit appeared to sht back from a commitment to scrap it entirely. Last week shadow chancellor John McDonnell said it has got to go. But Shadow Foreign Secretary Emily Thornberry said although fundamental reform” was needed, the principle is one we don’t have a problem with - it has always been how it works.”

title: universal credit not fit purpose
story: NewsUniversal Credit "not fit for purpose" and causing misery for millions, declares Nicola SturgeonThe First Minister of Scotland - who has fans both north and south of the border - writes in the Mirror how rent arrears and food banks soared where the programme was implementedShareCommentsByAndrew GregoryPolitical Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsNicola Sturgeon is backing the Mirror campaign "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May is today warned by Nicola Sturgeon that Universal Credit is “not fit for purpose” and is causing misery for millions. The First Minister of Scotland highlights how rent arrears and food banks have soared in areas where the despised benefits programme has been implemented. And backing our campaign to halt the roll-out to three million more families from July , she attacked the “damaging impact it is having on our people and communities”. The Mirror’s petition calling for a fairer system has already been signed by , readers. Ms Sturgeon warns the lives of many desperate families “already struggling” have actually been made worse. “Quite simply, the rollout of universal credit needs to be halted,” she writes in the Mirror on Monday . Mirror Campaign: Stop the Universal Credit Cruelty - sign online HERE  Shadow Foreign Secretary Emily Thornberry also attacked it, saying yesterday: “We must not come out of austerity on the backs of the poor. This is fundamentally wrong.” Even Iain Duncan Smith – the architect of the system – called on the PM to back poundbillion of extra funding for welfare in this month’s Budget. Meanwhile, Health Secretary Matt Hancock told the Andrew Marr Show universal credit was working as he had received “no letters on it at all” – only to immediately be blasted by constituents who claimed their letters had simply been ignored.  By NICOLA STURGEON, First Minister of Scotland Universal Credit is causing misery. Increases in rent arrears and the use of foodbanks in areas where Universal Credit is already implemented paint a clear picture of the damaging impact it is having on our people and communities. Our Welfare Reform Report showed that by the end of this decade Scottish people will have lost pound.billion through UK Government cuts to welfare spending. That’s money out of the pockets of the lowest income families in our country and, importantly, out of local communities. That will have an impact on people on low pay, or low hours and those in fluctuating or seasonal work. People already struggling will have their situation made worse by a policy not fit for purpose. The benefits freeze is the largest of the cuts and the UK Government should show its commitment to ending austerity by immediately lting this freeze and uprating benefits in line with inflation. But it’s not the only part of Universal Credit that is causing issues. Our report also estimates that by   the Two Child Limit will cost Scottish families poundmillion in reduced payments, so the policy that led to the abhorrent “rape clause” will cause further damage. I can tell the UK Government just a few changes they could make right now to minimise the impact on people:Lt the benefits freeze Stop sanctions End the two child limit Reinstate work allowances so work actually pays And no one should have to wait five weeks to get money to feed their children or heat their homes.Quite simply, the rollout of Universal Credit needs to be halted and that is why I support this campaign by the Daily Mirror. story: NewsEugenie wedding photographs: Hidden messages including a special gt from the Queen and where Fergie stoodSome of the noticeable things from the stunning official royal wedding photographs released to the public on SaturdayShareCommentsByNeil Murphy:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsPrincess Eugenie and Jack Brooksbank leave St Georges Chapel after their wedding "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Princess Eugenie and Jack Brooksbank make the picture perfect couple in newly released official photographs taken during the pairs spectacular wedding day ceremony in Windsor on Friday afternoon.The stunning images show the happy newlyweds posing for photographs at Windsor Castle alongside members of the royal family and their adorable page boys and bridesmaids. title: gps prescribe dancing cookery classes
story: NewsGPs to prescribe dancing and cookery classes to patients suffering from lonelinessTheresa May said social prescriptions would reduce demand on the NHS and improve patients’ quality of leShareCommentsByAndrew GregoryPolitical Editor:,  OCT NewsLonely people will be encouraged to take part in cookery classes, walking clubs and art groups"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailGPs are to prescribe social activities for patients suffering from loneliness, the Government will announce today. Instead of offering pills, family doctors will be encouraged to use “social prescribing” to refer lonely people to activities including cookery classes, walking clubs and art groups. Announcing an extra pound.million for community projects, such as creating new community cafes, art spaces or gardens, Theresa May said social prescriptions would reduce demand on the NHS and improve patients’ quality of le. Launching the first loneliness strategy, the Prime Minister confirmed English GPs will be able to refer lonely people to community and voluntary activities by , as she paid tribute to murdered Labour MP Jo Cox, who had campaigned to end loneliness before her death.  Mrs May said: “Jo Cox was absolutely right to highlight the critical importance of this growing social injustice which sits alongside childhood obesity and mental well-being as one of the greatest public health challenges of our time. “I was pleased to be able to support the Loneliness Commission set up in Jo’s name and I am determined to do everything possible to take forward its recommendations. “This strategy is only the beginning of delivering a long and far reaching social change in our country - but it is a vital first step in a national mission to end loneliness in our letimes.”  Loneliness is one of the greatest public health challenges of our time, Mrs May said, and is linked to illnesses including heart disease, strokes and Alzheimer’s disease. About , older people have not had a conversation with a friend or relative in more than a month and three-quarters of GPs said they see up to five people every day suffering loneliness.

Just off the coast of Plymouth and stretching out six acres, Drakes Island is dotted with buildings from the Napoleonic era. The island has a rich history including time spent as a prison during the reign of Charles II and was neamed after SI Francis Drake who set sail to circumnavigate the world in . Now on the market it also comes with planning permission for a spa and hotel.Aidan McCauley, son of the islands owner Dan McCauley, told BBC : My dad has long held a vision to see the island brought back into use.We are passionate about seeing his vision turned into a reality and are exploring all options to make this happen.  Mr McCauley had bought the land in the s and in  Plymouth City Council granted planning permission for the development of a luxury spa and hotel. The island was named after Sir Francis Drake, who had planned to sail from there in  to discover the world. Estate agents JLL are seeking initial expressions of interest with a guide price of poundmillion.The company told PlymouthLive : “Best and final offers are invited by a date to be announced. The owners are not obliged to accept any offer made.”But it stressed “detailed consideration is given to all the offers received”. In November  plans for a poundmillion-plus hotel and spa complex on the island were revealed. Engineering firm Rotolok Group, the island’s owner, wanted to create a resort and opening the island to the public. With planning consent secured in April , details were released showing how the Grade II-listed Island House, Barracks Block and Ablutions building could be linked to form a hotel containing  double- and twin-bedrooms. A new “lightweight contemporary” structure would be built to house a ground-floor bar, with restaurant and reception above. Another new building would contain a spa.  The Casemates battery was planned to be transformed into  “luxury” bedroom suites with sea views. The building could also accommodate rooms explaining the history of Drake’s Island. The plan also included landscaping, refurbishment of the jetty and infrastructure works. Bob King, project co-ordinator for the Drake’s Island development, said work has started on what will be a complex project. The initial focus will be to make the jetty safe for contractors and consultants to land, and then to bring utilities to the island.

title: horrified smart meter installer discovered
story: NewsHorried workman discovers indecent images of naked children FRAMED on customers wallPhillip Gilbert, , from Cheshire, led police to a laptop and drawer full of over , downloaded images after a workman discovered sick images hanging up in his bedroomShareByLinda Roughley:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsPhillip Gilbert had downloaded over , images "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA horried smart meter installer discovered sick images of naked children framed and hanging on a customers bedroom wall. The workman had been visiting the home of Phillip Gilbert in Knutsford, Cheshire, when he spied the indecent snaps through an open door.Gilbert, a -year-old grandfather, had printed them after downloading over , shocking images of youngsters being abused, Manchester Evening News reported.The shocked meter reader told his boss what he had seen and police were dispatched to Gilberts home, Liverpool Crown Court heard.  Chris Taylor, prosecuting, said: “After arresting him and askinghe had any other material he responded ‘come on then, I’ll show you, so you don’t make a mess’.” Gilbert, a retired plumber, led them to a front bedroom and from the bottom drawer of a chest and a cavity within a wardrobe he produced a number of folders which contained indecent photographs of children and a laptop. He told them: I know it’s getting out of control. When you live on your own you need someone to give you a kick up the arse. I’ve been telling myself for years, I’ve got kids and grandkids, just get rid, but I never did. If my son and daughter ever find out I don’t know what I’ll do.” A full analysis of his computer, an SD card and the folders revealed he had , indecent images of children, including girls ranging in age from six to  and boys aged  to  years. The majority were in the lowest category of seriousness. Gilbert had also used ious incriminating search terms when browsing the web for such images, the court was told.  Seven sickening images of bestiality were also found,” said Mr Taylor. Gilbert, of Lowe Drive, pleaded guilty to five offences involving downloading and possessing the indecent images. Defence barrister Gareth Roberts said Gilbert was relieved when the police arrived at his home “as it started the process of him bringing to an end what he knew was a bad thing and started his rehabilitation”. He has no previous convictions and is regarded by the probation service as a low risk of re-offending. Mr Roberts said his client had an unhappy le and although he was married for  years, his we suffered mental health problems when their children were young and was sectioned. He added: “Since his we’s death and possibly before he became increasingly isolated living alone.”  Mr Roberts said Gilbert had not had a good relationship with his children and is now estranged from them since the offences came to light. He said: “He had become increasingly obsessed with pursuing pornographic images of children, it became it was what he did most days and he knew that he was doing wrong and accepted that behind every image there was an abused child.” Mr Roberts said Gilbert no longer had any equipment enabling him to get onto the internet and wants to avoid any potential for re-offending. Sentencing him to a three-year community order, Judge Stephen Everett said Gilbert had had more than , indecent images of children.He said: “We will never know what happened to those children. You and people like you encourage this behaviour. They may have been disposed of by these terrible people to stop them talking.“Potentially the last moments of le was that sexual abuse and then their lives ended. You will never know.” The judge told him he was making a community order as there was a genuine prospect of his rehabilitation and he will be under supervision for three years.He imposed a five year Sexual Harm Prevention Order and ordered him to sign the Sex Offenders Register for the same period of time.

story: NewsMeghan Markle and Harry missed a huge part of Eugenies royal wedding - and they regret itThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex ed to their own wedding venue on Friday to watch Eugenie tie the knot - but couldnt make all of the celebrationsShareCommentsBySophie Evans:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video harry-meghan-hold-hands-closely-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle and Prince Harry ed to their own wedding venue on Friday to watch Princess Eugenie tie the knot in a star-studded ceremony.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex were joined by more than  other royals for the Queens granddaughters spectacular wedding to Jack Brooksbank. But while they attended the lavish ceremony at St Georges Chapel, Windsor Castle, they were forced to miss a big part of Eugenie and Jacks celebrations.The couple, who married at the same th Century chapel just five months ago, reportedly did not attend the wild wedding after-party on Friday night. The tequila-fuelled bash took place at the Duke of York’s residence, the Royal Lodge in Windsor Great Park, with guests partying until the early hours of the morning. But Meghan, , and Harry, , couldnt be there - because they are flying to Australia today for their first royal tour together, the Mail on Sunday reports.Their absence was said to be to Harrys deep regret.
