As part of the , mile and -day trip, Prince Charles took in the surf at one of the worlds most famous beaches, Bondi. Harry will follow in his mother and fathers footsteps when he touches down in Australia with his new bride this week.  The couples sojourn in the southern hemisphere will be more brief, but will see them retrace parts of the path once trod by Charles and Diana. The pair will visit Bondi Beach, where they will meet a local surfing community group which raises awareness for mental health and wellbeing. And in New Zealand, they will tour the capital Wellington and visit Auckland and then Rotorua, which is famed for its Maori culture. They will then head to Abel Tasman National Park in the South Island. Similarly, Charles and Diana took in the traditional Maori culture  years ago in Auckland and the Bay of Islands, where the couple were rowed into the area in a traditional canoe. The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge - Harrys brother and sister-in-law - came to Australia and New Zealand with a young Prince George in  for an -day visit. Keep up to date with all the latest news from the Queen, Charles, Will, Kate, Harry, Meghan, George, Charlotte Louis and the rest of the family. Well send the best Royal news directly to your inbox so you never have to miss a thing.to our newsletter here.  William and his we, who were invited by the governments of the two countries, took part in a commemoration of Anzac Day, as well as heading to Sydneys Taronga Zoo. Harry and Meghan are also scheduled to visit here. While at the zoo, William, Kate and George saw a bilby enclosure which contained a marsupial named after the youngest royal on the tour. During this months tour, Meghan and Harry will take part in a massive  engagements. The trip coincides with the Invictus Games in Sydney, which run from October -. The sporting event - founded by Harry in  - gives sick and injured service personnel and veterans the opportunity to compete in sports.  After landing in Sydney, the Duke and Duchess will travel to Dubbo and Melbourne, before spending three days in Sydney from October - to mark the launch of the Games. They willfor the closing ceremony. However, sport is not the sole focus of the trip. While in Australia, Harry and Meghan will also visit organisations including schools and a rural Flying Doctor service, greet members of the public at the Sydney Opera House, and meet young leaders and community members at Government House. After Australia, they will fly to Fiji, where they will be greeted with an arrival ceremony similar to one attended by the Queen and Duke of Edinburgh in . In Fiji, Harry will pay tribute to Fijian war veterans and the couple will attend a state dinner, before flying to Tonga. The tour will conclude with a four-day trip to New Zealand, where they will be greeted by Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern.  The Duke and Duchess will learn about environmental challenges while in Wellington, visit a charity which supports children with parents in prison, and meet members of the public in Auckland and Rotura. They willto London from Auckland on November . In an earlier statement, Kensington Palace said: There is a long history of friendship between the Royal Family and Australia, Fiji, Tonga and New Zealand, and their links with the UK are extensive.The Duke and Duchess are very much looking forward to experiencing the unique cultures and customs of those four Commonwealth countries and have asked that this tour allow them opportunities to meet as many Australians, Fijians, Tongans, and New Zealanders as possible.

title: mum gives birth next busy
story: NewsMum gives birth next to busy motorway at rush hour while on way to hospitalLeanne Parrett, , had spent weeks frustrated at her second childs "stubbornness" before going into labourShareCommentsByNeil Murphy:,  OCT NewsLeanne gave birth in a lay-by next to the M at rush hour in Gloucestershire "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum has spoken of her shock after giving birth in her car on a busy motorway at rush hour. Leanne Parrett was on her way to an induction at Gloucestershire Royal Hospital with husband Sam.She suddenly went into labour by M for Dursley, Gloucestershire, at .pm on Thursday, GloucestershireLive reported.-year-old Leanne had spent weeks frustrated at her second childs stubbornness and was disappointed at the prospect of an induction. Leanne, a paranormal investigator, had initially wanted a natural birth at the same hospital where she had her first child, three-year-old Imogen.  The induction for Leanne and well known graphic designer Sams baby Sebastian had been booked for pm on Thursday. Bristol-based Leannes pregnancy journey up until her shock car birth wasnt an easy one. She had been getting awful Braxton Hicks contractions but after a check up, she was told that she wasnt in labour and that she could go home. Leanne was again tortuously tantalised with a beautul delivery room in Gloucestershire Royal last week, when she had similar contractions, before being sent home again. She said: I was admitting defeat and knew he was going to have to be forcibly evicted, when at .pm, after a super strong contraction, my waters broke. My mum rushed to my house to look after Immy, and within minutes my contractions were two minutes apart.  We jumped into the car to go to Gloucestershire Royal and just as we were about to get on the motorway at rush hour, I screamed. I needed to push. It was Leannes husband and partner of almost a decade, Sam, who delivered his first son. Leanne said: Sam couldnt believe that I needed to start pushing, so was about to get onto the motorway at Junction  towards Gloucester, just past Tortworth. But he pulled over in the lay-by literally meters from the motorway turning. He had a look and was like Okay I need to ring . I was in agony. I was squatting in the back seat and I just needed to push, and within two pushes he was out and Sam grabbed him, and then hestarted to cry. Leanne expressed her gratitude to her husband and the NHS workers who helped her through the birth.  She said: At .pm baby Sebastian was here on the backseat of our car with only Sam, myself, and the lovely  operator to guide us through what the hell to do. The ambulance arrived  minutes later and we got taken to Gloucester. After a quick check up we were home by am. The first paramedic on the scene was Scott, who arrived within  minutes of the call. An ambulance with paramedics Amy and Lloyd arrived very soon after. Leanne described the team as beyond amazing. But she was worried something would go horribly wrong.  We were so lucky there were no complications as it was just us, she said. I feel great now. I was induced with my first. I had a very strong and long labour, and this was the exact opposite. Im on an adrenaline high at the moment. The midwives at Gloucester were amazing and gave us all a quick check-over and a cup of tea. I had some stitches, and then they said we were free to go home, so was home by am. I cant thank the paramedics enough. I bloody love the NHS and emergency services. Sebastian Bobby Parrett was born weighing lb, oz.

title: russian spies target retired mi6
story: NewsRussian spies target retired MI officers and British diplomats to turn traitor for desperate PutinEXCLUSIVE: The Foreign Office is warning everyone considered to be a high-priority targets of the spooks tacticsShareCommentsByChris HughesDefence and Security Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsDesperate Putin is trying to get retired British spies to work for the Russians "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRussian spies are targeting ex-MI officers and diplomats in a bid to make them traitors. The Foreign Office has put out an urgent warning over Putin’s spooks’ tactics. A memo states: “Russian services regard them as high-priority targets.” Putin’s ruthless shycampaign to recruit traitors from Britain comes as he tries to appear strong at home, experts say. The Russian President is under growing pressure amid a flagging economy and recent blunders by his GRU intelligence agency – including the botched novichok attack in Salisbury. A former British intelligence officer told the Mirror: “The perceived threat Putin wants to portray to Russians is that the West is surrounding them and that his motherland is a victim.  “Whilst all the time he can smirk at the suggestion the GRU has been trying to disrupt Western democracies, the blunders his men have made are becoming embarrassing. His intelligence agencies are desperate to claw back credibility by making inroads into shyBritain’s intelligence operations by recruiting insiders.” Such is the escalating campaign by Moscow’s spooks that Foreign Office officials have sent out an urgent warning to ex-MI staff and diplomats. The memo, leaked to the Mirror, states loved ones could be threatened.  It says: “Russian services regard both current and former retired members of the service as high-priority targets. Russian services have a tradition of using pressure in their operations. This may be used against both former members of staff and close relations.” Russian spies use a iety of techniques to coerce people into becoming agents or disclosing secrets, ranging from blatant threats of violence to subtle persuasion. Behind the scenes for years, Moscow’s spooks have become increasingly aggressive towards Western diplomats, sometimes resorting to violence. The Mirror understands several US staff have been beaten up by Russian thugs on the intelligence agency payroll. Some have also had their homes burgled.  One security source said: “This is an intimidation tactic, it breeds insecurity, builds up tension and is considered a breach in the professional standards of the intelligence community.” The Foreign Office declined to comment on the memo. Tensions between Russia and Britain escalated in March with the novichok nerve agent attack by GRU operatives Anatoliy Chepiga and Alexander Mishkin on former Kremlin intelligence officer Sergei Skripal and daughter Yulia. Twelve GRU men have also been indicted with hacking the US election. There are few known examples of Britons becoming Russian spies. However, one is still alive. George Blake, , turned on being captured during the Korean War. In  he was jailed for being a KGB double agent. He escaped in  and fled to the Soviet Union. In  he was awarded the Order of Friendship by Putin.Spies involved in novichok-style attacks will face EU sanctions including asset-freezing and travel bans, Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt will say today.Ex-spooks are vulnerable and there are plenty of targetsANALYSIS By Chris HughesBritish intelligence agencies have doubled in size in the past  years and many officers serve for under  years. This means there is a huge pool of Brits with sensitive information. Ex-spies will know operational details of MI missions against Russia, names of spies and double agents and new spying techniques. Diplomats may have data on ex-colleagues, Government plans and commercially sensitive projects. All of this can be used to give Russia the upper hand – making former staff vulnerable. Particularly at risk are new businesses set up by former Government workers, needing cash to get started. The really dficult area is security, where many ex-spooks go to earn decent money. Russians throwing cash at these companies to perform due diligence checks on employees or other small projects can mask their real intentions. Gradually, people can be sucked in until they are compromised and find it hard to turn down lucrative contracts or refuse to work with someone they suddenly suspect is on the payroll of the Kremlin. It is in this area that Russia has been particularly aggressive – trying to employ British intelligence firms to find out information about iniduals. There are many ways Russia can subtly recruit someone. Sometimes they can do it and the target does not realise until it is too late. Other times a more direct approach is used – or even blackmail.

title: school suspends pupil best bum
story: NewsSchool suspends pupil with the best bum awards after outcry from parentsChildren at the Highfields School in Matlock, Derbyshire, were encouraged to nominate who who the best bum and who was flirtiestShareCommentsByNick Reid:,  OCT NewsHighfields School in Matock, Derbyshire, has come under fire "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Children at a school were asked to vote for who among their peers had the best bum and was most flirty .Worried parents have slammed Highfields School in Matlock, Derbyshire and the yearbook awards have been suspended. Many parents have expressed their anger at the voting forms, branding them a type of bullying and were calling on the school to ditch the awards, designed for inclusion in a yearbook.Staff at the school are aware of the complaints and have since suspended the yearbook until further notice, reports Derbyshire Live . Jane Gretton, who has a -year-old daughter at the school, said: I am absolutely appalled by these voting slips, it is more like something out of an American school and to me it is just another form of bullying. To be asking questions like who has the best bum at that age is just ridiculous. They are young people andthere are children at the school who have hang ups over their body or their personality, then it could affect their mental heath in the fuutre. I thought schools were meant to be stopping this sort of thing. It is ridiculous and inappropriate.  Having said all this, I think Highfields is a fantastic school. I have had two children who were there right up to A-level and are doing really well because of what they learnt at the school. These awards are not right though and I hope they are stopped. Award categories included most likely to become Prime Minister, sportiest, funniest, friendliest and those most likely to become a millionaire or be late to their own wedding Parents have fumed though as the awards also include best bum, flirtiest, most lovable rogue, teachers pet and best looking. title: smiling boy 4 looking forever
story: NewsHungry toddler becomes a happy, smiling boy just lacking one thing - a forever familyEXCLUSIVE: When Jay came to his foster family two years ago he was completely dferent - a small boy whod sit in the corner and not let anyone touch himShareCommentsByRhian Lubin:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsJay is completely dferent from the child he was two years ago "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAny parent knows a supply of snacks is vital to keep up with the almost constant demand for food from most young children. So imagine a two-year-old so affected by his early le he won’t ask for food, no matter how hungry he gets. That was the reality when Jay came to his foster family two years ago. A small boy who would sit in the corner of a room, too nervous to let anyone touch him. Now Jay is unrecognisable from that child, a smiling, happy four-year-old and testament to just what a dference having a loving home can make. Foster carer Bukky, , recalls: “When he first came he was very, very withdrawn. He wouldn’t ask for food. If we let him, he could have gone all day without eating, that was normal for him. He was very quiet, very shy. The first three days he wouldn’t let me touch him. “He’d just sit in the corner on his own. By the fourth day he was with us I couldn’t handle it any more. I had to be able to pick him up, hold him. And very slowly, he began to open up to me. “But now, he’s come out of all that. And he’ll tell me when he’s hungry and enjoys food – especially any African food – he’s now in a comfortable place.”  Bukky, who also fosters a little girl, recalls the first time Jay allowed her to hug him. She says: “At the beginning, he was still pushing away from me, it was hard. But soon he understood that I was there to care for him. I was there to feed him, bathe him, give him all he needs. “Then he slowly understood I was there to care, not to harm him. “He started to open up very quickly and would then latch on to me. No one  could carry him!” When I arrive, Jay, who is eating a snack at the kitchen table, flashes a cheeky smile and gives a little wave – a sign of how far he has come. In the last two years, he has blossomed into a happy, confident little boy, but he desperately needs a permanent family to adopt him. Jay is one of thousands of children across the UK waiting to find their forever home and the authorities are appealing for prospective families to come forward in the hope they will find someone to adopt him. As Bukky recalls his first month at her home in London, Jay is playing happily with his toy police car at our feet. It is hard to imagine him as a timid little boy as he happily shows off his favourite toys. He takes me up into his bedroom, where his toy cars are neatly in a row. His favourite is his police car, which has blue flashing lights and a siren. Ask Jay what he wants to be when he grows up and elements of that shy personality are still apparent, but it is adorable. He runs up to Bukky, whispers in her ear, “a policeman” and runs back to his toy car. “He also says he wants to be a fireman and a doctor”, Bukky laughs. Jay is in reception class at school and is settling in well, especially with reading and writing.  Bukky says: “His teachers adore him and he gets on well with the other children. He’s very sociable, quiet at times, very caring. Above all, Jay loves to read. We read every day. “Before school, I’d take him to the library every week.” But Jay also enjoys making the most of the outdoors as well as being in the classroom. Bukky adds: “Jay just loves to dance, he loves to run, and I take him to the park as much as I can.” And one of the other things Jay prides himself on is his appearance. Laughing, Bukky says: “He loves getting his hair done. He used to have long hair. “We cut it about three months ago and he loves it. It was the funniest thing though, the first time we had his hair cut, we went to a specic barber. But when we took him the second time, my husband took him to his own barber’s. “But Jay said, ‘No! I already have my own barber!’ We all laughed a lot. He’s very sure of himself when it comes to his presentation and he knows what he wants.”  One of the most noticeable things about Jay – evident from meeting him just once – is his kind and loving nature, the way he keeps running up to his foster mum and gently giving her a cuddle, how polite he is when meeting new people. Bukky says: “When we got rid of his buggy because he was too big for it, he’d say, ‘Can we give it to another mummy with a baby ’ That’s the kind of thoughtful boy he is and that’s all him. He is naturally caring. “He just has the loveliest nature.” Even though Jay has matured into a positive little boy, he still has moments where he will keep to himself. Bukky says: “Because of everything he’s gone through, Jay needs a lot of love, someone that has time for him that really, really loves him. “He can be a child who sometimes keeps to himself, he will go back into his cocoon sometimes. All you have to do is look at that smile.” * If you are interested in adopting Jay, call    or visit www.firstadoption.org.uk There are THREE TIMES more children than adopters Children who are desperate for “forever families” face a crisis, with almost three times as many of them as there are adopters. story: NewsWhat to never say to a parent who has adopted a child - and what you shouldMany adoptive parents face hurtful remarks from loved ones - even though they often mean wellShareCommentsByRichard JenkinsStephen JonesDeputy News Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video things-you-should-never-say-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThree quarters of adoptive parents have been left devastated by thoughtless comments from friends and family, a study has found. A poll revealed many face hurtful remarks from loved ones including ‘I cant believe they abandoned them’ and ‘where are their real parents ’ Despite the questions being well-meaning, they leave seven in  adoptive families feeling asthey are not yet perceived as equal within society. One in four have also been subjected to ‘do you worry about them going back to their real family one day ’ This was voted the most hurtful to adoptive parents, who are legally the ‘real family’ of their child. More than one third have also had people say, ‘you’re so cute, how could anyone have given you up ’ or ‘I cant believe they abandoned you ...’ to an adopted child. Shockingly,  per cent of families have even been asked ‘what type of abuse did the child go through ’ Others were grilled by people asking ‘wheres his or her real parents ’ while  per cent were told ‘youre a saint for adopting, I couldnt’. Fatima Whitbread to adopt a child aged  after being adopted herself The research by parenting site ChannelMum , also revealed mums with adopted children regularly have to deal with inappropriate comments about their fertility.Two thirds have been asked ‘will you have one of your own too one day ’ and a further  per cent were told ‘sorry you couldn’t get pregnant’. Thirty-five per cent have had people say ‘oh just watch, now youll get pregnant’ – suggesting a biological child is more important.Siobhan Freegard, founder of ChannelMum , said: “How you become a parent doesn’t matter – it’s the job that you do when you are a parent which is crucial.“Parents by adoption simply want the same treatment as everyone . “Although the questions are well-meaning, it’s unlikely any other parents would face that level of personal intrusion, so there’s simply no need to ask them to parents by adoption.” The poll also revealed strangers are most likely to make inappropriate comments, with  per cent of adoptive families targeted by people they don’t know.  One third of adoptive families have had inappropriate questions from workmates, and  per cent have fielded them from medical staff, such as health visitors and GPs. However, another one in three of the , mums and dads polled have said something which they didn’t realise would hurt an adoptive parent. The study also found  per cent of UK families have considered adoption with the top reason being ‘to give a child a good home.’ However, just five per cent went ahead with the adoption process. One in seven were worried about being judged by social workers and adoption agencies, while  per cent said their partner was not fully supportive. To boost falling UK adoption rate, three quarters of parents think the Government must do more to publicise the positives of adoption, so it is viewed as equal to parenting a biological child or having IVF. Three in five also want adoption to be offered alongside IVF while almost half would like to see more positive adoption storylines in soaps and the media.

story: NewsWoman spent  hours crawling out of quarry after suffering horric injuries in ft fallSally Nowell, from Midsomer Norton, Somerset, was unconscious for up to two hours before, severely wounded, she struggled to safetyShareCommentsByJoe SmithBradley Jolly:,  OCT NewsSally Nowell had a miracle escape after falling ft into a quarry "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A determined dog walker plunged ft into a quarry and spent  hours crawling out - despite breaking her ribs, shattering her pelvis, puncturing a lung and rupturing her spleen. Sally Nowell, , tripped on her dog Kyra and tumbled into the pit. The stable jockey told Somerset Live she suffered horrendous injuries and was unconscious for some time.But brave Sally dragged herself along on her elbows to clamber out of the quarry  hours later. Speaking of her ordeal for the first time today, Sally said: Ive been up there with my husband lots of times. But this time I decided to take a path I hadnt ever been down before.  I wanted to see so I wandered off the path and peered over the edge – it was a big drop with a lot of rocks and undergrowth. I got a bit scared and I turned back around to make sure the dog hadnt got too close the edge. But I was a bit disoriented, I took a step back and tripped over a dog. Despite crashing into rocks at the bottom of the clf and suffering a shattered pelvis, Sally somehow crawled through the chambers near Midsomer Norton, Somerset. She added: I remember falling through the air. Everything slows down. I remember thinking to myself this is going to hurt. I remember it was getting dark when I woke up.  I didnt know where I was – I was severely concussed. It took me a while to figure out but it started coming back to me. The pain wasnt too bad at first. It must have been the adrenaline. I knew my arm was broken because it was at a funny angle. I tried to walk but the pain in my pelvis wouldnt let me use my legs. Sally said she heard a rescue helicopter hovering above the quarry as she scurried to find safety.  But her husband Paul, , wasnt due home from his job as a self-employed mechanical engineer until much later. I was crawling along on my elbows. It was further than I thought, I kept having to rest. I couldnt very get far with the pain and the concussion. I managed to get about half way but I had to stop.  At one point it [the police helicopter] flew straight over with its searchlight but it didnt see me. Thats when I started to panic. When they flew away again, I think I started to give up hope. Sally spent the rest of the night in August this year drting in and out of consciousness.  She continued: As the morning came the I started to panic, I thought maybe nobody would find me.But then one of the dogs barked – I thought they might have heard someone so I called out – and one of the search and rescuers called back Weve got you. Were coming.Sally was overcome with relief and exhaustion when her rescuers arrived.  The jockey was given painkillers and airlted to Southmead Hospital in Bristol where she was found to have three broken vertebrae, a broken wrist, three or four broken ribs, a collapsed lung, a shattered pelvis and a lacerated spleen. Her heat stopped on the operating table while surgeons were trying to save her. They had to resuscitate me and they had to put a chest drain in. They said I was very lucky I didnt bleed to death from the injury to my spleen, said Sally.  She was out of intensive care in a week and ing home in another week. However she still is receiving hospital treatment for her injuries. Pre-existing conditions, such as anorexia, have been worsened as a result of the ordeal. I really wanted to say thank you to the search and rescue team and the air ambulance and everyone at the hospital.

story: NewsWW scenes recreated  years on in amazing photographs as Mirror s to France to mark  ArmisticeEXCLUSIVE: The Daily Mirror has gone back to Armentieres and found five statuettes perfectly preserved a century after they were pictured being saved after a German bombardmentShareCommentsByTom Parry:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsBack in , Daily Mirror photographer David McLellan spotted five British Tommies helping a priest st through the wreckage "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIn the aftermath of a devastating German bombardment in the French town of Armentieres, Daily Mirror photographer David McLellan spotted five British Tommies helping a priest st through the wreckage. He followed them on to the steps outside and asked them to pause for a picture as they gingerly clutched sacred wooden statuettes salvaged by Pere Leon Peulmeule from the debris scattered over the aisle. The soldiers stared sternly at the man with the camera and then followed the priest’s directions to a place where the mahogany icons would be protected. It was a moment McLellan, , thought deserving of posterity amid the chaos of the First World War in . His photographer’s instinct was right. A century later, the Daily Mirror has gone back to Armentieres and found the five statuettes have been perfectly preserved. Last week I visited the reconstructed Saint-Vaast church and found the same figures of saints on shelves in a side chapel. In a little-used corridor they are like silent sentries, survivors from the town’s darkest hour.  Even though  years have passed, today’s parishioners are well aware of the bravery of the British soldiers back in . They know that after the moment frozen in time in the photograph the British troops went back to an uncertain fate on the frontline. Saint-Vaast church meanwhile was pummelled by further intense shelling in attacks that ultimately failed to shatter Allied resistance. Accompanied by the current priest, Abbe Luc Lesage, the faithful were pleased to recreate such a symbolic event for one of McLellan’s successors - Daily Mirror photographer Phil Coburn - as they finished mass. Sylvie Duclercq, , said: “It’s incredible that these statues survived after what happened at the time, just extraordinary. The church itself was completely ruined. The roof was blown off completely, making the building unusable. “For us it is amazing that this picture exists which shows how the statues were saved. Thanks to the photographer from the Daily Mirror the people of Armentieres will always have this memory of what took place in .” Today Saint-Vaast is a magnicent edice that stands proud in the heart of Armentieres, which was right on the frontline when the photograph was taken in February . By the time German forces took it during their Spring Offensive, aimed at pushing British isions back and cutting off supply lines to the English Channel, it was mostly rubble. There are reminders of the First World War wherever you go, on giant posters throughout the town, and in a copy of McLellan’s photograph pinned to the church noticeboard.  In the last  months of the First World War no other photographer depicted the most signicant events so thoroughly as David McLellan. After a transfer from the Royal Flying Corps, he was appointed as an official war photographer in December  along with another Daily Mirror snapper, Tom Aitken. One of only five official photographers working on the Western Front, his work was noted for the way it captured the immense scale of operations as Allied forces engaged in vital rearguard actions and offensives that eventually led to the Armistice of November . What makes the images remarkable is that all of them had to be submitted to Army generals for censorship before publication as part of his photographer’s permit. When the Allies broke through the German defensive lines in the autumn of  in what became the final big push, McLellan made sure he was there. He travelled with the troops as they breached the Canal de Saint-Quentin, one of the most heavily fortied stretches of the Hindenberg Line. The assault had been preceded by the greatest British artillery bombardment of the war, in which more than one million shells were fired in a short period of time.  Such was the ferocity of the onslaught that the enemy soldiers were pinned in their dugouts. In early October  the troops of the North Staffordshire Regiment seized the strategically vital Riqueval Bridge before the Germans had a chance to fire their explosive charges. Thousands of prisoners were taken by British, American and Australian soldiers. They also managed to gain control of a key tunnel on the canal, a short walk from Riqueval, which had been turned into a fortress complete with kitchens and field hospitals. The triumph at Saint-Quentin became one of the most signicant victories of the war, and a moment to be captured on camera. Several thousand British soldiers sat on what had, until the day before, been the German-controlled eastern bank opposite as Brigadier General JV Campbell addressed them from the bridge. They were like tiny ants on the high earth bank, which had been raised by the Germans for deep trenches dug behind. Such a gathering of so many infantrymen in the same place at the same time was a rare spectacle.  Many of the them were smiling and wore le jackets having swam or got across the canal in the flotation devices. Once again McLellan recognised such a striking image. The photograph resonated with the generals as brilliant propaganda to show the public back home. It proved that after four appalling years, progress was slowly being made. Having broken through at Riqueval, the Allied forces were able to advance, eventually bringing about the Armistice ceasefire. Thousands more men came over the bridge, including poet Wilfred Owen with the Manchester Regiment. Conditions at Riqueval when I visited last week could not have been more dferent. There was birdsong instead of gunfire, shards of sunlight hitting the still water and where there were once soldiers there are now trees. But the evidence of what once happened here was all around. On the bridge I met three local young men with metal detectors and a bag containing their haul from the morning – shrapnel, shell casings and even the remnants of a German soldier’s identity tag. Raphael Plancot, , said: “The ground here is full of First World War ordnance. We come here all the time and find things. Millions of bombs landed here. When the sun is shining you can see the shells glinting on the bed of the canal.” After Riqueval McLellan stayed with the Allied armies as they surged forwards. His work now forms an important part of the archives kept for future generations, including those at the Imperial War Museum and the National Library of Scotland. Not only did he show British soldiers in battle, he also showed what was going on behind the lines – the men, women and children whose lives were forever changed. He portrayed the daily lives of soldiers in the trenches, the first use of tanks across no man’s land, gas attacks and even the brief of interludes of peace when the guns fell silent. McLellan’s legacy is an unparalleled set of photographs, now digitised, which are a permanent reminder of the horrors of the bloodiest conflict in history.

title: call for shuttle bus service amid frightening state of poorly lit ninewells car parks
story: Concerns have been raised over the safety of the car parks at Ninewells Hospital.People regularly using the facility say that a lack of handrails in some of the car parks is a danger to the public.There are also fears that poor lighting in all the car parking areas could put people using them at risk.The lack of lighting has been described as “frightening”.Miles Staton, , a telecommunications worker from Ninewells, said: “It should be well lit because there are so many people hanging around.“I think it would be a concern for women when it’s late at night.”A former student nurse at Ninewells also expressed her concerns.She said: “It’s quite frightening walking along to the multi-storey parking area at night. There should be some kind of shuttle bus service to take people directly to the car park from the hospital entrance.“You have to stop in the dark and look for money to get a parking ticket – that is a safety concern.”Steven McDonald, , a construction worker from Perth, said: “If it’s dark it should be lit up, especiallyyou’re paying for it. People could trip and fall.”Louise Davidson, , from Menzieshill, said: “If there’s no light, anyone could be creeping around.”Bob McGlashan, senior officer for the Royal College of Nursing, stressed that safety is paramount and called for anyone experiencing any issues to come forward.Indigo, which operates the car park, declined to comment on the issue.The concerns raised come as support continues to flood in for the Tele’s petition calling for Indigo to freeze parking fees.Indigo is locked in a -year contract with NHS Tayside to run all the Ninewells Hospital car parks.Fees have been rising constantly in recent years, meaning people who attend the hospital through necessity are having to fork out more and more.The firm plans to raise the costs again, so day tickets will go up to £. from next month.

story: A young people’s charity is dancing for joy after being awarded a five-figure cash boost.Showcase the Street has been handed £, by grant-giving charity Garfield Weston Foundation, as part of its th anniversary celebrations.The money will go towards replacing the roof above Showcase The Street’s indoor G football pitches at Manhattan Works.Charity chairman Fergus Storrier said: “The facility we operate in the Stobswell area is well used by young people and the wider community.“Showcase has already been recognised through local awards for our work and this year has seen a nomination for us to be recognised as Social Enterprise of the Year.“The area above the football pitches will see a new insulated roof which will help the many groups who use the facility as well as the wider projects we run“This incredible investment from the Garfield Weston Anniversary Fund will mean so much to everyone and I’d like to thank them so much.”Showcase the Street, based at Manhattan Works in Dundonald Street, offers a range of sport and dance classes for children.Former Dundee United coach Steve Campbell runs a football academy at the venue, which is also home to the Scottish FA East Region.Steve said: “I was delighted to hear about the donation, having come from a professional background it’s great to see such high quality facilities at Showcase.“It makes a dference for so many of the young people from whatever background they come from.“The new roof will make such a dference and I’m sure the young people and wider users of the sports surfaces will notice the dference and appreciate the changes.”Showcase the Street was one of  charities to benefit from the foundation’s £ million fund.Philippa Charles, director of Garfield Weston Foundation, said: “We heard about so many amazing projects involving local people who are helping their communities thrive.“The impact of these grants will be signicant, with benefits for many people lasting years.”

title: dundee fans group writes to top officials over referee steven mcleans links to kilmarnock
story: Angry Dundee fans have written to two top refereeing officials over whistler Steven McLean being put in charge of Saturday’s controversial clash with Kilmarnock despite having strong family connections with the Ayrshire club.McLean blundered by awarding the second-half penalty that saw Killie take the three points from the Dens Park clash.And supporters with long memories are unhappy he was handling the proceedings despite his father, Stewart, making over  appearances for the Rugby Parkers between  and .To add to the conspiracy theories, for  years he was a team-mate of Paul Clarke – brother of their current boss Steve.The pair even appeared on the same sticker in an edition of the annual Panini football album.All that’s prompted the Dundee Supporters’ Association to write to SFA head of referees’ committee chairman Willie Young and their head of refereeing, John Fleming, to question the sense behind having McLean taking games involving Kilmarnock.“Several of our members have contacted me to express their concerns over this and we think it’s only right to pass them on to the authorities,” said DSA chairman Kenny Ross.“And I do think there is reason to question the validity of this appointment when the referee so clearly has family connections to Kilmarnock.“If nothing  it puts him in a dficult position when you get a decision like Saturday’s.“I know that Steven McLean’s brother Brian played for Dundee United, Ross County and a few other clubs and he was not allowed to take charge of games involving teams he was at.“You think the same common sense approach could have been applied to his dad’s old team.”The fans also pointed out should the Killie player who ed to win the kick, Jordan Jones, be handed a two-game ban, that in itself could damage Dundee.The games he would miss would be against St Mirren and Hamilton, the two sides immediately above the Dark Blues at the foot of the Premiership.SFA chief executive Ian Maxwell was copied in when the letter was e-mailed and has promised a response will be given.

title: dundee people all aboard the weddingday special
story: After an eight-year engagement, it took just five weeks for Dundee bus drivers Kevin Lowden and Dawn Brownlie to plan their big day.Kevin, , and Dawn, , met in  through their work with bus company Xplore.Although they would soon be driven madly in love, Dawn, from Tealing, admits her first impression of Kevin was not positive.She said: “I thought he was arrogant because he never spoke but when he eventually decided to chat to me I thought to myself, ‘oh, I quite like him’.”Kevin, originally from St Mary’s, added: “I had noticed Dawn before and was definitely interested in her. That is probably why I never talked as I was nervous.”When a colleague found out about the mutual interest, she channelled her inner Cilla Black and set them up.After their first date, Kevin and Dawn were inseparable and within six months they were engaged and living together.Kevin said: “We had been shopping one day and Dawn pointed out an engagement ring that she loved as it was so unique.“I waited until she went into another shop and went back to the jewellers and bought it.“That was in August and it was meant to be her Christmas present but I couldn’t keep it a secret so I got down on one knee in the house.“Dawn said yes straight away, despite being a bit shocked.”After the y engagement, a barbecue and a few drinks this summer led to the frequently asked question from the couple’s pals: “When are you two going to get married ”.With a holiday booked for September, the bride-to-be joked: “Who knows, maybe we will just do it while we are off.”Kevin decided to move things on and booked the registrar’s office for September  – just five weeks later.Dawn said: “Once the date was confirmed, it was mayhem.“We were offered a vintage bus as our transport by Tay Bus Vintage Vehicle Society and I was really up for it but Kevin point-blank refused. We then realised that our wedding day coincided with the opening of the VA so the only way we were getting to our wedding was on the bus driven by our good friend Stevie Reid. He was amazing all day and acted like our taxi driver.“I am so glad now that we had the bus as it was such a laugh.“We got some funny looks driving down the dual carriageway in it.“Everyone on the streets was waving and my bridesmaid Jenner Turner started a confetti fight.“I had my bus driver head on and told her she couldn’t do it but when she asked Stevie he just laughed and it turned into confetti chaos. It was amazing.”Kevin added: “Although I didn’t want the bus to begin with, I was so happy with it on the day. It was very cool and a great laugh.”Kevin was joined by pal Paul Turner as best man, admitting he has too many male family members to have had to choose from them.The couple said “I do” in the registrar’s office in the city centre before having a meal with close family and friends and hitting the Fairmuir clubbie at night for an unofficial reception.Dawn said: “One of Kevin’s sons lives in Australia and couldn’t make it to the wedding so we decided we would wait until he is home next year before having a reception.“Instead we went to the Fairmuir clubbie, where we go every week, and they made it so special. Even the band, Scotland Rocks, pulled us up on to the dancefloor and gave us a first dance. I can’t thank the club enough for making it an even more special day.”The happy couple would also like to thank good friend and former colleague Gordon Baird for his photography skills, David Murdoch who created the wedding cake and Flowers by Dawn who made the bouquets.Dawn added: “I may have only had five weeks to organise the day but I wouldn’t change a thing.”

title: dundee people walk in memory of laura
story: The NHS Tayside Continence Advisory and Treatment Service took part in a team sponsored walk around Fe to raise funds in memory of nursing colleague Laura Balfour, who died of septicaemia.The charity FEAT was founded in memory of Falkirk based GP Dr Fiona Agnew and her baby daughter Isla, who both died after contracting sepsis in August .FEAT aims to stop sepsis through funding research into the early detection of the condition and raising awareness of the illness.Lisa Henry, specialist nurse at Wallacetown Health Centre in Dundee, said: “Laura’s colleagues past and present attended the walk and wore bright colours to remember her by.“The sun was shining on the day and everyone who participated was glad to support Laura’s family in raising awareness and funds for septicaemia in her memory.”The team, pictured, raised £, in total. Lisa added: “Someone dies of sepsis every four hours in Scotland and by donating to this charity we are enabling funding for research.”

story: Kilmarnock winger Jordan Jones has been charged with ing by the Scottish Football Association.Jones has been hit with a notice of complaint over the penalty incident which led to his team’s winner at Dundee on Saturday and faces a two-match banthe case is proven.Dundee manager Neil McCann insisted there was no contact after Jones went down under the attention of Cammy Kerr before Eamonn Brophy netted from the spot to earn KIllie a - win.The SFA charge said: “No player shall cause a match official to make an incorrect decision and or support an error of judgement on the part of a match official by an act of simulation which results in that player’s team obtaining a substantial advantage.”Jones will face a hearing tomorrow.He will miss Ladbrokes Premiership games against St Mirren and Hamiltonthe charge is upheld.Dundee fans# group writes to top officials over referee Steven McLean#s links to Kilmarnock" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp dundee-fans-group-writes-to-top-officials-over-referee-steven-mcleans-links-to-kilmarnock embed # secretBSNUfzww" data-secret"BSNUfzww" width"" "" title"#Dundee fans# group writes to top officials over referee Steven McLean#s links to Kilmarnock# # Evening " frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"

story: A pub chain is to open the doors of new premises in Perth next month, it has been revealed.BrewDog, which began in  in Fraserburgh, has confirmed the finishing touches are now being applied to the site in George Street, and outlined its reasons for moving to the Fair City.The company would not ulge the cost of the development but expressed its delight in transforming the site in Perth, which was formerly a coffee shop.BrewDog confirmed food will be served at the Perth premises.A spokesman said: “We don’t have a confirmed opening date just yet but the team is putting the final touches together for a November opening.“The bar will employ a team of eight people.”A planning statement submitted to Perth and Kinross Council by Firstplan on behalf of BrewDog added: “BrewDog has been seeking suitable premises for a bar in Perth for some time to help enhance its presence in the area.“The BrewDog bars are operated with a strong emphasis on ‘beer education’, specialising in the sampling and tasting of its beers.“A limited food menu will be available, primarily comprising cold items such as dry-cured meats, along with a small range of pizzas.“The premises had sat vacant for some time.“The new development represents an opportunity to bring this prominent listed building back into a productive, employment-creating, long-term viable use.“This will contribute to the vitality, vibrancy and viability of the centre of Perth.”

title: scorching summer sees bumper harvest of pumpkins at local fruit farm just in time for halloween
story: Pumpkin fans will be seeing double this Halloween thanks to the scorching summer.Cupar-based Cairnie Fruit Farm has enjoyed bumper crops of the squashes thanks to the sunniest summer of the century.This year’s orange pumpkins are also even bigger than usual – all the better for carving.Cameron Laird, proprietor of Cairnie Fruit Farm, said some of the biggest pumpkins weigh lb.He said: “Thanks to the excellent hot weather we had in the summer time this is proving to be a bumper year for the annual pumpkin crop.“Normally we would see around , pumpkins but this year we have somewhere in the region of , – more than double our normal yield.“The pumpkins are also considerably larger than normal.”Cameron, whose family have owned Cairnie Fruit Farm since , said that demand for the pumpkins is high.Since the farm began selling the squashes on October , they have shted about .Cameron said: “People were queuing up on the first day and they have been coming along ever since. I’d envisage it will be like this until Halloween. One of our big attractions is our pumpkin patch.“People can go along and pick their own pumpkins and this is proving to be very popular with our customers.”Pumpkins are a member of the gourd family, which includes cucumbers, honeydew melons, cantaloupe, watermelons and courgettes.The heaviest pumpkin ever weighed ,lb oz and was presented by Chris Stevens at the Stillwater Harvest Fest in Stillwater, Minnesota, in October .Carving pumpkins into jack-o’-lanterns is believed to have originated hundreds of years ago in Ireland, originally using turnips or potatoes.

title: scotland-v-portugal-five-things-we-learned
story: Sting through the wreckage to find the positives from a defeat to what is essentially Portugalrsquos reserves is not a fun way to partake of a Sunday evening. In fairness to Alex McLeishrsquos side there were some elements to take from the performance in the opening half which seemed far more cohesive that the shambles that was the defeat in Israel last Thursday night. Still, though, whether you look at the game through the most optimistic glasses, the fact is that even at this ridiculously early stage, McLeish has the look of a manager who is already under tremendous pressure. The manner of the three goals shipped to Portugal had the hallmark of team already weary from being on the same familiar treadmill. For all the rare glimpses that suggest Scotland might be able to build something, the overall impression gleaned from watching McLeishrsquos side is that this is a team in absolute decline. How to arrest it is the most prescient question but on recent evidence there is no suggestion that answers appear to be forthcoming.
