It would mean no more sports lets of the main hall for football, badminton and handball, the squash court would shut and the property would be shted from South Ayrshire Council ownership. Muirhead Residents and Tenants Association fired the first warning shot over the takeover. Chairman Frances Carson said: “The answer is no. If the council have pulled a fly one over this then they will never hear the end of it from this community.” Scott Telford, head coach of the gymnastics club, promised this week he will speak to the community about his ambitious plans. But Tory councillor Peter Convery slammed the secrecy, saying: “This came out of the blue to all the councillors and community and is an utter disgrace. “People at a meeting on Friday night were flabbergasted the hall could be taken out of council ownership. “The acid on the cake is the council has been speaking to the group without anyone knowing. “The council should not be treating its citizens this way.” Scott Telford said he has a full business plan for the centre and believes it can work. The club has  members and a waiting list of  more. He said the club have restricted facilities at their present base Dundonald Activity Centre, where five adults spend hours setting out and dismantling equipment. As a result they cannot develop youngsters to elite performance level and lose talented performers at an early age. Former top gymnast Scott, who lives in Muirhead, said: “The community will still get use of the centre for things like meetings and birthday parties and we would look to develop that. “There will also be the chance for the community to take part in gymnastics. “I appreciate people don’t like change but we can make this work. We could even look at parkour gymnastic sessions with teenagers on Friday night. “There is also a lot of outdoor space which we could change for other activities, depending on what the community want.” The dad first started helping at Dundonald when there were only  kids and ten mats. He added: “At the moment we get about  inquiries a week and just cannot cope. “I want to work with the Muirhead Residents and Tenants Association and want to hear all views. “We will be running a seven-day-a-week facility but it has to be financially sustainable and work with the community.” Councillor Craig Mackay said he wants full transparency when consultation starts. He said: “The onus will be on the gymnastics club to demonstrate the wider support of the community. “I am relaxed about the process and will very much wish to take on board the community’s views on this once we know the details of what is proposed. “I am concerned about how any potential transfer would impact on the use of the centre by the wide range of groups who currently use it. “The centre currently runs at a small but manageable loss and in my view any decision must be made on what is best for the community and not on the very minimal cost savings.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrAyr NewsGymnasticsSouth Ayrshire CouncilBadmintonTroonDundonald

title: shops replace homes new ayr
story: NewsShops to replace homes in new Ayr town centre regeneration plansPeople to have their say on radical proposalsShareBySarah Hilley:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT News"Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShops are to be replaced with homes in Ayr town centreradical new plans get the go-ahead. Proposals also include the High Street being coated with a new easy clean surface and bins being kept out of site. A great shop clearance has been proposed to regenerate the ailing shopping strip. South Ayrshire Council wants empty retail units to become homes at the bottom of the town. Council leader Douglas Campbell said: “Internet shopping has signicantly altered the landscape in the town. “We need people back staying in the towns.” SNP Councillor Campbell took to his feet at week’s full council meeting to talk through the complete overhaul of the town centre. Conservative Councillor Ian Davis askedshop owners would be consultedthey are forced to move. He said: “This could mean some businesses will have to move. I want reassurances for businesses thatan area is to be reused for a dferent purpose that they are well consulted.” The meeting heard businesses would be consulted. The cleared Riverside block, which included Woolworths, would become a public square. The original proposal for a huge office block has been shelved. Commenting on the cleared site, Councillor Campbell said: “None of us expected the vista.” But he conceded how homes of some description could be erected on the site. He said: “Some sort of building on the site will be necessary.” A report submitted to council said: “There will also be the potential for a small number of residential units on the Riverside sitethis proves desirable through the public consultation exercise.” Council staff from soon-to-be demolished Burns House are likely to move into the Clydesdale Bank Building, the Town Hall and County Buildings instead. The Citadel is to be replaced with a brand new state-of-the art leisure centre on the High Street. A new streetscape surface could also be on the way. Councillor Campbell said: “If we are going to revamp the High Street we need to do it in a signicant way to keep it tidy. “During the main shopping times all the bins should be off the street. We need to present the High Street well. “We need to move the bus stops away from the Clydesdale Bank building.” Conservative opposition councillor Hugh Hunter got to his feet to “welcome” the report. He said: “It would be spectacular for the administrationthey could pull it off.” He called for a park like Belleisle to be built at the Riverside. SNP councillor Siobhian Brown said she welcomed the report but said morale of the community was “on its knees.” All plans will be issued for public consultation.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnClydesdale BankScottish National PartySouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr

title: slow progress new troon mega
story: NewsSlow progress for new Troon mega surgeryBut work on Templehill expansion should start next yearShareByStephen Houston:,  OCT News"Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNational Health top brass have been summoned to Troon to explain what is happening to expansion plans at the town’s mega surgery. Members of the public spoke at last week’s Troon Community Council –asking why there has been no obvious progress at the Templehill Surgery in nearly six month. The surgery swallowed most of the collapsed  Medical Practice, re-opening with , patients at the end of April. The Community Council has asked an NHS representative to attend their meeting next month. When Templehill took over they were to be handed around pound, by NHS Ayrshire  Arran for an extension. And partner Robbie Cumming said then it was still to be agreed wether to use a ready-made modular building or a traditional build at the back. At the time he said: “We intend to expand and develop our current premises with the addition of two or three consulting rooms, disabled access doors and a larger reception area.” A planning application has been lodged but it has not even been “validated” yet by South Ayrshire Council. Councillor Craig Mckay has quizzed Pamela Milliken, head of primary care, on the extension which had been a central plank of the transfer. Councillor Mckay said: “I welcome the Health Board’s comments which suggest that there have been no major issues following the transfers. “This is consistent with my own experience as I’ve received no recent complaints from patients. “It is also reassuring that both recipient practices have been reviewing patient records and inviting patients to attend for review appointments. “I hope this will ensure that those who were moved will continue to receive the level of care they deserve. “On the extension to the Templehill surgery, the planning application has recently been submitted but not yet validated. ““Clearly it is in the interests of all patients of that practice that the required expansion takes place, and I note that subject to there being no planning issues, work is expected to begin on site in the new year. “The extension was central to the arguments made when  Medical Practice closed, and the ball is now firmly in the Surgery’s court to deliver on this commitment.” Councillor Bob Pollock agreed the actual transition process seemed to have gone well and said: “None of the Troon Councillors have received any complaints following the merger of the surgeries, butthere are any, they should get in touch.” Ms Milliken said: “Planning permission for the work was submitted to South Ayrshire Council on Friday September . The practice is optimistic that works will commence in early Januaryplanning permission is granted.” In other NHS news, it is understood community midwives have had to change their base from the Barassie Street clinic to Prestwick. One source said: “All that is left at Barassie Street seems to be podiatry. “The community nurses have to start their sht in Prestwick before coming to Troon for their first appointment.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnTroonNHS ScotlandAyrAyr News

title: borderers-told-lets-get-healthy
story: RESIDENTS in the Borders are being urged to lead healthy and active lives as part of a new campaign launched this week.Organised by the Scottish Borders Health and Social Care Partnership, Scottish Borders Healthy Lives Week is encouraging everyone to keep themselves healthy and active whilst making the right choices to support and protect vital services in the future.The week-long programme, which began on Monday, promotes services that are routinely available to communities including drop-in sessions offering advice on quitting smoking and eating well, exercise sessions, social groups and a writing for wellbeing club.Organisers of the campaign say that they hope it will encourage people to look to community services for support in order to ease pressure on key health services.Speaking at Mondays launch, Robert McCulloch-Graham, Chief Officer Health and Social Care Integration, explained: ldquoThe campaign we launched today will help promote the message that everyone has the opportunity to make the right choices in le, not only to live healthier, happier lives, but also to do whatever they can to help us reduce pressure on services which are becoming increasingly stretched.ldquoWe are encouraging and supporting people to look after their health, access the right services at the right time and make the most of the wide range of services and support available in communities."Not only will this have positive benefits for people, it will also contribute to easing pressure on our range of important services such as our Emergency Department and Minor Injuries Units.ldquoIf everyone plays their part in whatever way they can, it should have a positive impact on public service finances which means we can target the limited resources we have on those services that need it most and are most valued by our communities."It also means we are more likely to be able to maintain them in the longer term.Healthy Lives Week runs until October .For the full programme of events visit: www.scotborders.gov.uk integration

title: dyslexia-support-to-be-rolled-out-to-every-school-in-the-borders
story: SUPPORTING students with dyslexia in Borders schools is being made a priority by Scottish Borders Council.The local authoritys ruling Executive has agreed to the adoption of a dyslexia policy which will be made available in every primary and secondary.The policy has been developed following widespread consultation with parents, parent councils, pupils and staff with the aim of providing a very clear and robust framework that will give schools the strategies and approaches they need to support children.It is supported by a comprehensive set of operational guidelines and a training programme for staff that will ensure a consistent experience for all children and young people living in the Scottish Borders.Councillor Carol Hamilton, Executive member for Children and Young People said: ldquoThe formal adoption of this policy is a vital part of our ongoing commitment to making sure that all children and young people in the Borders experience consistently high standards of practice and support, in this particular case for those for whom dyslexia is a part of their daily lives."Dyslexia can have a profound impact on a child or young personrsquos feelings and confidence."It is therefore crucial that all our pupils who have dyslexia are identied in a timely way and are provided with appropriate support to ensure that they do not lose confidence in their ability to succeed."We are confident that the approach set out in the policy will ensure that these pupils have access to trained and knowledgeable staff who are aware of their responsibilities and know how to make sure that any relevant interventions and adaptations are put in place.

title: borders-railway-ignored-in-national-scotrail-improvements
story: TRAIN bosses have defended the Borders RAILWAY being ignored this week in a major timetable improvement plan.Despite the Waverley-to-Tweedbank line being widely welcomed since re-opening three years ago it has been blighted by overcrowding, cancellations and delays.This week operators ScotRail announced details of faster journeys, more seats, and more services being introduced across most of the country in December.More carriages are being added to lines in East Lothian, the central belt and Strathclyde.And new electric trains with more seats are being introduced to lines around Falkirk, Dunblane, Alloa and Edinburgh.There will also be additional trains across the central belt, Tayside and the Highlands.But the Borders Railway hasnt been included in any of this weeks announced upgrades.Local MP John Lamont is among the many who have been left disappointed.He said: "These new announcements from ScotRail are disappointing, but are by no means a surprise."Thatrsquos why I am calling for a feasibility study into extending the Borders Railway from Tweedbank to Hawick, Newcastleton and on to Carlisle."And I will continue to campaign for rail services toto Reston."This will improve connectivity across the Borders."More than four million journeys have been made on the Borders Railway since it opened in .The popularity of the -mile stretch of track is showing no signs of slowing down either with year on year increases.But there are regular complaints from passengers about standing-room only carriages for much of the journey.ScotRail announced last year that new Class  trains would be brought onto the Borders Railway - allowing for additional carriages to be added.Although not included in this weeks announcement, a spokesman has confirmed the new engines are still earmarked for Tweedbank.And they believe the improved timetable for the rest of Scotland will have a positive impact for local commuters.A ScotRail Alliance spokesperson said: ldquoThe introduction of our new trains and the electrication of the central belt will allow us to make best use of our existing fleet and make positive timetable changes in the Borders.ldquoNext year, we will begin to redeploy our existing class  trains to Fe and the Borders."These trains will add more than , extra seats each day.ScotRails improved timetable will come into force on December .Managing director Alex Hynes made the announcement this week.He said: "The improvements we are making to our timetable from December mean ScotRail has reached another milestone as we build the best railway Scotland has ever had."This is just the first phase of the work we are doing to deliver for our customers over the next year."

title: town-band-on-tune-with-new-jackets
story: GALASHIELS Town Band hit the high notes during a special weekend performance at Galashiels Academy.As well as a performance by the Town Band, the concert also included music from Galashiels Junior and Youth bands and guest appearances from three Academy pupils, Jess Thomson, Jenna McMillan and Benji Maybury.Neal Wade, Band Chairman, said: ldquoWe were delighted that Jess, Jenna and Benji were able to join us. The Band seeks to encourage young musical talent in the town and they certainly showed that talent this evening.During the concert, the band were also presented with a set of winter waterproof jackets by Sheila Robertson of Gall Robertson CA.Accepting the jackets, Iain Wilson, Band Treasurer said: ldquoAs the Band re-generation continues, we are taking on more outside engagements."With events like the Remembrance Service and Angelrsquos Wings coming up these jackets will allow us to look the part and stay warm and dry at the same time.

title: agencies-team-up-to-stop-region-becoming-a-cross-border-dumping-ground
story: ENFORCEMENT agencies have joined forces in a bid to stop the Scottish Borders and other rural parts of Scotland being used as a cross-border dumping ground.Waste crime is estimated to cost the UK economy around poundm a year and is known to include the illegal transport and dumping of waste by hauliers travelling from England, Wales and Northern Ireland.But now illegal cross-border waste haulage and disposal is the target of a series of new multi-agency interventions.The pound.m Le Smart Waste Project clampdown is led by the Scottish Environment Protection Agencyand co-funded by the European Union.In tandem with police forces across Britain and the English, Welsh and Northern Irish environment agencies, the drive out waste crime initiative involves a series of road stops, site visits and awareness-raising activities to remind hauliers of their responsibilities and the laws.Kath McDowall from SEPArsquos Waste Crime Investigations Team told us: "Intelligence gathered by the Le Smart Waste Project indicates that waste is being hauled from England and Wales and illegally deposited in Scotland."Several companies are known to be involved and many of these are under investigation by SEPArsquos Waste Crime Investigation Team for criminal offences."There are also indications of serious and organised crime group involvement in the transport, sale and disposal of illegal waste ndash so itrsquos vital that we work with partners across the UK to tackle this issue.ldquoWaste crime will not be tolerated and SEPA will, with its partners, pursue and take proportionate action against those who seek to profit from waste crime.Hauliers and building companies who ignore strict legislation can be hit with a fine of up to pound,, the loss of their operating licence and even a jail sentence.Agencies have been carrying out road checks on routes into Scotland in recent weeks.The multi-agency team pulled vehicles coming from Northern Ireland on ferries last month as well as making stops on the A into the Scottish Borders and Aat Gretna earlier this month.Waste crime flyers have also been distributed to service stations and truck stops either side of the England Scotland border.Lynsae Tulloch, Chief Operating Officer of the Scottish Business Resilience Centre, said: "Illegal waste management is a blight on our environment, our local communities and businesses."These illegal waste sites mean foul odours, water pollution, pest infestations and the increased risk of fire, which results in essential funds from the public purse being erted to cover the clean-up costs.ldquoCritically, criminals involved in the illegal movement and disposal of waste are erting income from legitimate operators, depriving them of turnover."Some haulage firms are also being used to transport waste to disposal sites ndash without them even knowing theyrsquore involved in illegal activity."

title: portrait-of-success-for-becky
story: A LOCAL photographer is in the frame after being recognised by her profession.Becky Henderson has been snapping up awards ever since launching her EnaMay Photography business in Innerleithen.And her Chapel Street studio is regularly in demand for portraits of newborns and toddlers.But now Becky is also being championed by the British Institute of Professional Photography.Last month she was awarded a Licentiateship by the body for her portrait photography.Becky told us: "I am delighted to have been awarded a Licentiateship."Being self taught and a bit shy, I have held back with my business, but now I have a recognised qualication all the hard work has paid off and itrsquos now time to go for it."I love taking photographs that capture the mood, the feelings and the emotions."I work hard so you can re-live those moments every time you see your pictures."As well as specialising in babies and young children, Becky is also a renowned wedding photographer.She added: "I enjoy working with natural light and the pureness that goes with it."The British Institute of Professional Photography is an internationally recognised qualying organisation with over  years of experience in supporting photographers.

title: sign-of-the-times-at-geological-borders-landmark
story: A BORDERS geological landmark has received an upgrade to its signage thanks to a newly formed partnership.Oil and gas operator Siccar Point Energy has joined forces with Edinburgh Geological Society to improve the visitor experience at its namesake landmark.The company has provided funding for new information boards at the site in addition to , leaflets highlighting the unique and important features of Siccar Point.Located on the Berwickshire coastline, the landform is a Scottish Site of Special Scientic Interest due to its signicance in the work of famed natural scientist James Hutton.In , Hutton observed the angular unconformity at the site which provided the evidence needed for his Theory of the Earth ndash the never-ending cycles of creation and destruction that shape the landscape today.This theory overturned the last vestiges of the Biblical account of a world shaped by the receding waters of a universal flood.Controversial in its day, Huttonrsquos work is a foundation stone in the science of geology and Siccar Point known as a globally signicant geoheritage site.Doug Fleming, Chief Financial Officer of Siccar Point Energy said: ldquoAs an oil and gas company geology is at the heart of what we do.ldquoHutton is an inspiring example of a scientist who followed the evidence and defied the conventional wisdom of the day.ldquoItrsquos a great example for a young company and a fascinating piece of Scottish history to preserve and to continue learning from.The company is also exploring further opportunities to enhance the site with the Edinburgh Geological Society.The society is currently working with heritage organisations and universities on plans to mark the th anniversary of James Huttonrsquos birth in , and to celebrate Huttonrsquos legacy in subjects including agriculture, meteorology and geology.Bob Gatlf of Edinburgh Geological Society said: ldquoThe support from Siccar Point Energy will make a tremendous dference to our plans to preserve and promote the area.ldquoOur long-term ambition is to do more to support the education and tourism potential at Siccar Point and this is a great first step in that direction.

title: cheeky-mascot-set-to-lead-remembrance-march-in-peebles
story: A CHEEKY Shetland pony who once munched on the Queens bouquet is to lead a Remembrance Parade in Peebles.Cruachan IV, who also had a nibble of Prince Harrys fingers, is the mascot of the Royal Regiment of Scotland.And on Saturday, November  he will march down the towns High Street as the build up to the centenary of Armistice continues.A packed programme of events will take place in the Royal Burgh in the days and weeks leading up to the th anniversary of the end of the Great War.The Saturday Parade will see local primary school children carry the names of each of the servicemen and servicewomen from Peeblesshire killed during the conflict.And they will be joined by Standard Bearers from the Royal British Legion, Army Cadets and Peebles Ex-Servicemens Pipe Band.Major John Currie from the organising committee told us: "Final preparations are being made for the Remembrance March on Saturday, November  and we are delighted that Cruachan IV will be at the head."Many organisations are already involved and we would be delighted to hear from any other groups or iniduals who would like to pay their respects to the fallen by taking part."The Shetland mascot tradition began in .The first to march with the Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders was Cruachan I, a jet black Shetland pony gelding, who joined with the title of Pony Major.Since then, the position has been held by another three black Shetland geldings, with Cruachan III, a pony especially adored by the Queen, retiring at the grand old age of  in .Over the past six years Cruachan IV has become infamous for his antics around the Royals.And it is hoped hell be on his best behaviour when he arrives in Peebles on November .The Saturday Remembrance Parade will muster at The Gytes at .am for a am departure.Cruachan IV will lead the march onto the High Street and down to the Old Parish Church.Community Choir InChorus will perform on the steps of the Church from .am.As part of the build up to the centenary commemorations an appeal has been made for local families to tell the stories of their loved ones during and after the Great War.Anyone who can contribute to telling the story of Peeblesshire and its people during the Great War is asked to send stories and photographs to remembrance@gmailTo take part in the Saturday Parade contact Major Currie at john.currie@btinternet

title: bridge-bother-set-to-continue-into-2019
story: DIVERSIONS and delays around Abbotsford and Lowood are set to continue for a further month after engineers discovered additional problems with a bridge near Galashiels.And the one-way system over the A Galafoot Bridge willearly next year for a further month or two.Inspections earlier this year identied major repair and refurbishment works were required.Engineers arrived at Galafoot on August  to begin the scheduled  weeks of work.But by early September it emerged the scale of deterioration in both the concrete sections and steel reinforcements beneath the surface was much greater than initially anticipated.Amey announced that full night-time closures would be required to finish the deck repairs, waterproofing and resurfacing by the scheduled October .But with just over a week until the planned completion date they have extended the timescales through to November.And bosses have also announced that engineers willto complete the extensive repairs in February.Ameys bridges manager Stuart Wallace said: ldquoThese refurbishment works were originally intended to prevent the further deterioration of the bridge structure by repairing defects at an early stage."This work has subsequently uncovered several previously hidden defects that far exceeded expectations and this is the reason for the increase to the construction programme.Since the introduction of a one-way system for west-bound traffic across the bridge with east-bound vehicles having to use the winding B near Abbotsford, there have been many reports of drivers ignoring temporary road signs.And many other drivers are using Melrose Road and Lowood Bridge, which causes tailbacks at rush hour.Rather than continue with repairs to Galafoot over the festive period and into the new year, Amey has opted to finish on November  andthree months later.Mr Wallace added: ldquoThe local community has shown incredible patience and understanding with the repair programme to date."Having listened to their concerns, we consider it prudent to avoid further disruption over the busy holiday season."This strategy will also mitigate against the possible impact that winter weather might have on this workldquoOnce again, we want to thank road users, businesses and residents for their goodwill, and we will continue to consult with local stakeholders and provide updates on this scheme .Exact dates for the  works will be announced in the coming weeks.

title: the-best-of-buble-in-galashiels
story: THE magic of Michael Bubleacute is coming to Galashiels.This weekend the Volunteer Hall will play host to Mark Daniels as Ultimate Bubleacute, in a stunning live tribute show featuring his incredible live band.Markrsquos charismatic nature, powerful vocals and boyish charm, are all perfectly packaged in true tuxedo style.A sleek, polished performance with a top coat of class and sophistication, along with Markrsquos mesmerising likeness to the modern-day Canadian crooner, the show appeals to fans of traditional big band music and Michael Bubleacute alike.In amongst a repertoire of pop standards, including Fever, Cry Me A River and Havenrsquot Met You Yet, expect some show stopping, spontaneous banter as Mark effortlessly hands out doses of unrehearsed humour and wit that you would expect from Bubleacute himself.Recently Mark appeared on ITV in a special show dedicated to the Emergency Services, hosted by Ashley Banjo from Diversity, and starring Leona Lewis, Alfie Boe and Michael Ball alongside Police, Ambulance and NHS staff.In his spare time Mark is a volunteer at the Ilfracombe RNLI Station.Having been crew for the last seven years, he said: ldquoBeing part of the ITV show was a huge honour, performing alongside such talented and courageous people was incredible."Whilst travelling Mark obviously canrsquot attend a call out, but to continue his support whilst on the road, he is raising funds with collections and an online fundraising page.On stage, expect to see lots of laughs, great humour and admirable camaraderie between Mark and his band.Backed by some of the finest musicians in the country, this line up is an absolute musical powerhouse.Ultimate Bubleacute is the first event at the Volunteer Hall as part of the Live Borders series of live music evening performances taking place across a range of town halls in the Borders.Ben Lamb from Live Borders commented: ldquoEvery penny spent with Live Borders is reinvested back into supporting the Scottish Borders, and we hope these community-focused events bring residents and visitors to the hub of the town hall.ldquoMark Daniels is a high-quality tribute act and master of his craft and we canrsquot wait to see him perform live in Galashiels.Ticketsfor this Saturdaysshow are priced from pound. and available from www.liveborders.org.uk

title: violin-virtuosos-set-to-play-in-peebles
story: SHOWCASING equal measures of fiery Celtic fiddle and masterful classical violin, two mesmerizing performers delve deeply into the soul of ancient Scotland, Ireland, and Brittany while embracing the power of contemporary string virtuosity.Internationally acclaimed master fiddler Jamie Laval teams up with one of Britainrsquos pre-eminent classical violinists Rosemary Warren-Green for a performance of Lavals unique compositions at Eastgate Theatre on Sunday, November  at pm.Lavals bold, new works are based on traditional folk melodies and delve deeply into the soul and aesthetic of ancient Celtic music while embodying the prowess of the celebrated violinists.RosemaryWarren-Green began her career as a proteacutegeacute of Sir Yehudi Menuhin and went on to become one of Great Britains pre-eminent concert violinists.She has been a guest soloist with the Philharmonia Orchestra, Halleacute, Singapore Symphony, London Chamber Orchestra, Scottish Chamber Orchestra, and the Royal Philharmonic.Rosemary currently serves as principal viola with the London Chamber Orchestra and is a devoted educator. Her teaching posts have included the Menuhin School, the Royal College of Music, and Davidson College. Rosemary is the founder of a flourishing, London-based educational program called Music Junction, which empowers children from disparate backgrounds to explore, experience, and perform music from around the world and share this music with their communities.Jamie Laval is a critically-acclaimed performer of Celtic roots music.Praised by The Herald Scotland as a ldquocommunicator and ldquovirtuoso , Jamie calls upon his foundation in classical music to inform his singular dedication to folk music. His performance style captures the pathos and perspective of Celtic peoples, drawing upon his astonishing violinistic prowess, uncanny imitation of Highland bagpipes, innovative arrangement style, and the recounting of atmospheric mythic tales. Jamie performed for Her Majesty The Queen and presented a TEDx Talk on the value of arts and culture in our communities.The performance is a culminating event of a weekend-long symposium sponsored by Nomad Beat Community Music School.Students of the course will be invited on stage with Jamie and Rosemary to perform a specially-prepared piece during the concert.

title: galashiels-violinist-tunes-up-for-rare-local-concert
story: ONE of the most prolic and talented violin players the Borders has ever produced will play a rare concert on home soil later this month.And Gina McCormack will be ably accompanied by distinguished pianist Nigel Clayton.World class violinist Gina McCormack, who lives in Galashiels, makes frequent BBC  broadcasts, has led the Sorrel String Quartet for  years and has recorded no fewer than  CDs for the Chandos label.Nigel is professor of piano at the Royal College of Music in London.He regularly performs worldwide, both as a soloist and with chamber groups.Gina and Nigel will start the concert at Melrose Parish Church with Schubertrsquos beautul Duo in A major, followed by lsquoLa Fontaine DrsquoArethusersquo by the Polish late Romantic composer Karol Szymanowkski which depicts a fable about a young hunter who chances upon a young goddess dancing by a river.Debussyrsquos Sonata in G minor, the composerrsquos last work, comes next. A powerful piece, this is followed by Faureacutersquos Romance for violin and piano.The Melrose Music Society concert concludes with Richard Straussrsquos Sonata for violin and piano, Opus , in classical form with three movements.Ticketsfor the concert on Saturday, October  are available at the door, priced pound for non-members of the Melrose Music Society, and free for accompanied school-age children.The concert starts at .pm.

title: its-time-to-flock-to-manor-valley
story: AROUND  sheepdogs and their handlers are set to take to the ring to compete for the title of top dog next weekend.Now in its th year, the popular Manor Sheepdog Trials willon Saturday, October  to test the skill of dogs and their owners.Alongside the sheepdog trials there will be a sheep show where local farmers will show the best of their stock.The popular  mile hill run will once again take place and begins at pm.The race doesnrsquot require advance registration but runners are advised to arrive in plenty of time for the start. Previous years have seen more than  runners take part.Peebles Cycling Club will also be running a family bike ride and refreshments will be provided by the Manor Rural.The event is free and a raffle in the afternoon will raise funds for ious local charities.The sheepdog trials will begin at am and run throughout the whole day. The sheep show starts at pm.Chairman Robert Barr said: ldquoIt will be an interesting day out."The quality of the dogs coming are tremendous and of international standard."The sheep that will be shown are all local, and again, of a high standard.ldquoAt the moment the hill run route is dry underfoot and there are prizes up for grabs."But irrespective of the weather, the show will go on.

title: anne-and-dick-make-welcome-return-to-the-borders
story: TWO of the most accomplished jazz and classical musicians to to regularly take to the stage in Scotland are heading for the Borders.On Saturday, October  Anne Evans and Dick Lee will perform at Heart of Hawick for the Hawick Music Club.Fresh from recent forays into the Edinburgh Festival Fringe where Anne performed as a member of Philip Continis Be Happy Band and Dick with accordionist David Vernon, they make a welcomedown the A.In February they performed for the Hawick Music Club with Edinburghs former Poet Laureate Ron Butlin - Anne on Flute and Alto flute, Dick on clarinet, bass clarinet and recorder.It was a dynamic and engaging experience that left the audience craving more.Vanda Mercer from Hawick Music Club told us: "We were left wanting the opportunity to hear more from the musicians."Next weekend we have that chance when Anne plays for us on piano as well as the flute and Dick plays on saxophone clarinet and recorder."Classically educated having studied in Edinburgh, Vienna and London, Anne contrasts with husband Dick for original versions of many jazz classics.Their concert programme lsquocomes from a place where jazz and classical meet and mingle - Debussy and Scott Joplin in one corner and Benny Goodman and Frank Bridge in anotherrsquo.Dicks own concert compositions complete the mix-Pontefiore and Tarentella concluding the first half of the concert and Blues for Jimmy featuring in the second.These will be a special treat as his compositions have been described as truly music of the future by The Scotsman.The composition Concerto for Bagpipes and Jazz orchestra was held to great critical acclaim and though, for obvious reasons, wonrsquot be heard on the night was described by The Scotsman as a revelation.Ticketsfor non-members, priced at pound for adults and free for under s, are available from the Heart of Hawick box office on  .

title: free-tap-water-points-to-be-rolled-out-across-scotland
story: REFILL tap water points are set to be rolled out in every local authority in Scotland in the next two years.The move is part of Scottish Waters Your Water, Your Le campaign which launched earlier this year.Councils across Scotland are being consulted to identy the best locations, with the aim of having the first  installed by the end of March .Douglas Millican, Scottish Water chief executive, said: ldquoOur research shows that people feel very positively towards the quality of Scotlandrsquos tap water ndash now these state-of-the-art taps can provide access to enable water drinkers to enjoy it while on the go by carrying and using refillable bottles.Environment Secretary Roseanna Cunningham MSP said: ldquoBy encouraging people to top up from the tap using refillable bottles, we will help cut down on our use of plastics and promote the benefits of hydration building on Scottish Waterrsquos Your Water, Your Le campaign."For further information visit yourwateryourle.

title: graduation-day-for-langlee-toddlers
story: TWENTY-two first-time mums and their tots have graduated the Family Nurse Partnership Programme in Langlee.The first group of young mothers to complete the programme, which aims to support young mums in the first few years of their childrsquos le, were recognised at a ceremony at Langlee Community Centre.The scheme helps new mums under the age of  by offering a voluntary home visiting programme with regular specialist family nurse support from the early days of pregnancy until their child is two years old.It encourages new mums to make healthy decisions throughout pregnancies, help them improve their childrsquos health and development as well as plan their own futures and achieve their aspirations.On hand to recognise the achievements of the mothers was Acting Director of Nursing, Midwery and Acute Services at NHS Borders, Nicky Berry, who presented certicates and gts to the mums and children who were in attendance.Speaking about the event Nicky said: ldquoIt was heart-warming to see our clients brimming with pride for their children and self-confidence in their own abilities.ldquoWe were also privileged to witness the remarkable loving relationships that our clients have nurtured with their children.ldquoOur FNP toddlers showed much exuberance and joy, participating in activities at the event such as the Bookbug area for storytelling, singing nursery rhythms and playing parachutes games.ldquoWe wish our first graduates much success for their future and look forward to engaging with more young mums and their babies, as this service continues.ldquo We will begin to host celebratory graduation events twice a year, now that the service has achieved sustainability within NHS Borders.The programme, which has helped  clients to date, has run since  at NHS Borders, in partnership with NHS Lothian.Graduating FNP client, Sophie Grieve, commented: ldquoI donrsquot know where I would beit wasnrsquot for the help of [Family Nurse] Sharon and the rest of the Family Nurse Partnership.ldquoThey have helped my son and I more than they will ever know.

title: brightening-up-winter-with-galashiels-knitwear
story: A GALASHIELS knitwear company is ready for winter.And it is proving to still be top of the style stakes with the launch of its latest collection.Fashion brand Eribeacutersquos newest range of clothing and accessories has hit the shelves in time for the cold winter months.The Netherdale-based knitwear design and micro-manufacturing company sells its wares in over  stores in  countries worldwide.Now in its nd year, its knitwear is made using "hereditary skills" handed down from one generation to the next.Founder Rosemary Eribeacute said: ldquoWe love blending colours that are harmonious and scrumptious: colours that are exciting, bright, not-easy-to-forget in our fast-moving world: colours that make you look younger and feel energised.ldquoSo many people think they are not good with wearing colour, but we want to change that, and give them back confidence and that particular feeling that they might have forgotten: I will have this forever.The collection is made from natural yarns including lambswool, angora and alpaca blend, most of them spun in Scotland.The newly launched items include sweaters, cardigans, hats and scarves and take inspiration from four winter ldquocolour stories in what the company describe as a broader ldquospectrum of colours than ever.ldquoVibrant colours are included in their ldquofizz collection, ldquorich blues and touches of whites in their ldquooceans palate, ldquoochres, russets and deep greens are inspired by autumn and finally, ldquogreys whites with touches of pale hints of colours in their ldquomist collection.On the newest collection, the company said: ldquoWith inspiration from their Scottish textile heritage of Fair Isle, lace and famous tweeds, the Winter  collection is all about being unique.ldquoThe artistic blending of colours, yarns and knitting techniques offers something new.ldquoFrom lightweight lace and sporty garments in extra fine merino to the soft chunky tactile handknit textures, there is a knit for all occasions.

title: rural-roads-to-benefit-from-900000-strengthening-project
story: THREE roads south of Hawick are set for major improvements.The rural roads will benefit from a total of pound, awarded by the Strategic Timber Transport Fund alongside pound, of investment from Scottish Borders Council.The B near Shankend Quarry will be strengthened and have edges reconstructed following years of wear and tear.The B near Newcastleton will be strengthened at two section - around Dawstonburn and also at Kirndean.And the D  Roberton to Craik road will be strengthened as well as drainage and passing place improvements, and edge widening.Councillor Gordon Edgar, SBCrsquos executive member for roads and infrastructure, said: ldquoThis allocation from the Strategic Timber Transport Fund, alongside investment from our own budgets, will greatly improve the rural roads identied as requiring attention."We recognise the importance of the road network to rural communities in terms of the local economy and employment, so this pound, investment is welcomed and compliments the additional pound.million being spent on resurfacing across the Borders in this financial year.The Strategic Timber Transport Fund was set up by the Scottish Government in  in recognition of the challenge faced in getting timber to market.It is administered by Forestry Commission Scotland in order to facilitate the sustainable transport of timber in rural areas of Scotland for the benefit of local communities and the environment, maximising the value of monies available through innovative projects and partnerships.

title: final-chance-to-pick-the-pet-idol-winner
story: Itrsquos the final countdown in our fantastic Pet Idol competition!The lucky top  pets who have made it through to the last round have been revealed.Theyrsquore competing to be crowned our  Pet Idol and win the pound cash prize.And the winner will be decided by you, readers of the Borderand Peeblesshire News.Yoursquoll find the a voting token on the inside back page of this weeks paper, so make sure you get voting now.Remember you can enclose multiple tokens in one envelope to save on postage.You have until noon on Friday, October  to vote for your winner and wersquoll announce our  Pet Idol shortly after then.Donrsquot delay ndash vote for your winning Pet Idol today!

title: bag-it-and-bin-it-message
story: DOG owners in the Borders are being urged to lsquoBag it and bin itrsquo following a warning about the health risks of dog fouling.As part of the Scottish Borders Health and Social Care Partnershiprsquos Healthy Lives Week, the Scottish Borders Council has highlighted the health risks of failing to pick up after your dog.Councillor Sandy Aitchison , who is executive member for neighbourhoods and locality services, said: ldquoThe vast majority of dog owners are responsible, but a small minority cause misery for their neighbours and their local communities by refusing to pick up behind their dog.ldquoIt is absolutely unacceptable and the health risks of dog faeces are well documented. By leaving it on the pavement, in parks and on sports pitches these people are putting the health of the public, particularly children at serious risk."The health risk posed comes from roundworm eggs which may be deposited in dog faeces. These become infectious after about three weeks and can remain so for up to two years. Anyone, but particularly children, playing near to the ground run the risk of picking up and swallowing the eggs.These roundworm parasites can cause toxocaral infection, symptoms of which range from aches, dizziness and nausea, to asthma and pneumonia. In rare cases, eye disease and loss of vision can be caused when the toxocara larva passes through the eye.Cllr Aitchison added: ldquoOur message is clear ndash play #yourpart and bag it and bin it. It is as simple as that.ldquoOur communities recognise this as a serious issue and it is also important to work with us to report problem areas and give us information which will help us tackle this real hazard to health and quality of le.The councilrsquos Responsible Dog Ownership Strategy aims to change peoplersquos behaviour to dog fouling and remind owners of their social and legal responsibilities.As part of the strategy, posters and pavement stencils can be requested by members of the public to be placed in areas where dog fouling is an issue.Communities can also sign up to SBCrsquos Green Dog Walker Scheme, which aims to change attitudes towards dog fouling.The council has also reminded members of the public to report incidents of dog fouling and to provide as many details as possible such as the exact location, the time when the dog fouling takes place and a description of the owner and their dog.Information can be provided anonymously and there is no need to provide further evidence at a later date.For more information on the strategy visit www.scotborders.gov.uk dogfouling or to report dog fouling phone   .

title: pupils-explore-the-appliance-of-science
story: PRIMARY pupils from Tweeddale got to grips with all things science at a hands-on workshop at the Eastgate Theatre.Youngsters joined scientists, engineers, and maths professionals during the second of this yearrsquos school science days.Science workshop days have been an annual feature of the Eastgate programme for more than a decade, with children learning about everything from the power of negative numbers to extracting DNA from strawberries.This year artist and glassblower Dr Ayako Tani joined Dr Roger Hillrsquos Terric Technology workshop where she invited pupils to explore the intriguing concept of the ship in a bottle.A selection of ships in bottles made in Sunderland in the s were displayed and Dr Tani showed her own extra-large example called the City of Adelaide.The final workshop culminated in a talk delivered by Professor Lesley Yellowlees CBE who discussed all aspects of renewable energy from the perspectives of science, engineering, economic, social and policy.See this weeks Peeblesshire News for our picture special from the event

title: budding-designers-asked-to-provide-cover
story: KIDS Innerleithen Youth Theatre is calling all artists across Tweeddale to get creative and design the programme cover for their debut show next month.The cast have been rehearsing for months in preparation for their performance of Annie Jnr at the Memorial Hall in November.The organisation was formed after members of Innerleithen District Operatic Society recognised the need to create a theatre group for young thespians locally.Committee members felt that, as it is a childrenrsquos show, it would be fitting to feature a childrsquos design on the cover of the programme.President of IDOS Nicola Watt, said: ldquoWe are very proud of how hard the cast of KIYT have worked since its inception, but especially in the months leading up to this, their first full production.ldquoWe thought a programme cover competition would help get other children involved and of course, help spread the word about this fabulous show and make it a huge success to reward all the childrenrsquos efforts.Both primary and secondary aged children across Tweeddale and Peeblesshire are being invited to design a cover with whatever they feel best represents the show.The showrsquos title does not need to be included as this will already be produced on the cover, however artwork must be within an area of cm x cm.While the winning design will feature on the programme, it is hoped that all entries will be displayed in the Memorial Hall during the shows which will run on November -.Designs must be submitted by October  by post to KIYT Cover Competition, Piccadilly,  High Street, Innerleithen, EH HD, or scanned and emailed to president@idaos.or.ukTicketsfor the show are now available for purchase from the Thrt Shop in Innerleithen, www.idas.org.uk booking@idaos.org.uk, Facebook inneropera, or by phoning   .

title: eastgate-theatre-is-telling-tales
story: A PEEBLES theatre is taking to the road this autumn to deliver a series of storytelling events.Eastgate Theatre will be travelling to some unexpected and beautul Borders locations as part of its Wild Little Stories series which promises songs, tunes, films and, of course, stories.The events are being run as part of the  Scottish International Storytelling Festival with the first event taking place at St Ronanrsquos Wells, Innerleithen, on Friday, October , -pm.Storyteller and clarsach player Heather Yule will weave stories and music into a fun, family afternoon before leading a workshop to create new stories inspired by St Ronanrsquos Wells and the abundant plants and animals that grow and live beside it.On Saturday, October , Wild Little Stories moves on to Kailzie Gardens, where storyteller and artist Mary Kenny will lead a walk through the grounds and relay stories including tales of the fairy realm, selkies, giants and ghosts. The event runs from -pm.The final, Halloween-themed Wild Little Stories takes place at Whitmuir Farm near Lamancha on Wednesday, October , .-.pm. Led by storyteller Lea Taylor, the event will include scary stories, a pumpkin carving workshop and a special Halloween pumpkin parade.Ticketsare pound, pound for under s and pound for a family of four , available from Box Office on   or online at www.eastgatearts

title: fox-hunting-trial-put-on-hold-for-two-months
story: THE trial of two huntsmen accused of ignoring Scotlands fox hunting legislation has been adjourned for two months.Three days of evidence have already been heard at Jedburgh Sherf Court in the case of -year-old Timothy Allen and Shaun Anderson, , both from the Buccleuch Hunt.They are accused of deliberately hunting a fox with a pack of dogs at Whitton Farm, near Morebattle, on December  last year in breach of the Protection of Wild Mammals.Both men have pleaded not guilty to the charge.On day three of the trial, police firearms expert Inspector Keith Warhurst referred to video evidence supplied by the League Against Cruel Sports.He felt there was a sufficient gap from the fox being flushed from cover to stop the hounds from pursuing it.The law prevents the dogs from pursuing the fox which should be dispatched with a gun after being flushed from cover.The trial has now been adjourned until December .Another four days have been set aside to hear further evidence in the case.

title: new-club-feeling-anything-but-blue
story: A NEW monthly Borders blues club has hit the high notes following a successful launch last week.Launched by Paul Burnett, lead singer with local band Unfinished Business, the Borders Blues Clubrsquos inaugural night took place on October  at the Vale Club Innerleithen.Showcasing two blues groups, the club hosted performances from Glasgow band Used Blues and Newcastle native Robbie Reay.The club has been launched in collaboration with The Vale Club Innerleithen, with support from The Falkirk and Stirling Blues Club, and aims to promote accessible and affordable blues music.Ticketsfor the club nights are pound and the events are being run on a not-for-profit basis, with all proceeds from ticket sales going directly to the artists.The club will run on the first Friday of every month and each show will feature two quality blues acts.The next event will take place on November  and will feature performances from The Blue Hyenas as well as Reece Hillis and John Boos.For more details on upcoming events visit The Borders Blues Club on Facebook.

title: kelso-hosts-singer-and-activist-peggy-seeger
story: Folk fans are invited to Kelsorsquos Tait Hall as singer and activist Peggy Seeger takes to the stage for what promises to be a memorable performance.The show on November  at .pm is billed as An Evening of Song and Conversation and will feature performances from Peggy, now in her s, along with her two sons Calum and Neil.Peggyrsquos new show will welcome and encourage audience participation as she performs some of the songs that have meant the most to her over the years.Following the paperback publication of her award-winning memoir The First Time Ever last month, Peggy will also be reading from the book as well as performing renditions of her husband Ewan MacCollrsquos most treasured songs.Becki Hodgson, Live Borders rural touring development officer, said: ldquoThis is a wonderful opportunity to catch this inspirational and iconic folk musician as she visits the Scottish Borders.Expect anecdotes, delivered with wry humour and an entertaining insight into the remarkable le of one of the best loved lsquoqueens of folkrsquo.Ticketscost pound-pound. Visit www.liveborders.org.uk

title: fracking-due-to-begin-at-lancashire-site
story: Fracking is due to begin in Lancashire on Monday.Energy firm Cuadrilla had hoped to start work at the site in at Preston New Road, Little Plumpton, near Blackpool, on Saturday but this was delayed by the effects of Storm Callum.It followed an environmental campaigner failing in a bid to halt the work at the High Court on Friday.Hydraulic fracturing to go ahead at Preston New Road shale gas exploration site in Lancashire. To view the full statement visit: https:t.co CaPLZuKmdash CuadrillaOctober , A spokesman for Cuadrilla said on Saturday: ldquoDue to the weather conditions yesterday afternoon and this morning, we will now start pumping on Monday.ldquoIn high winds we couldnrsquot use the crane to manoeuvre some equipment into place.At a hearing in London on Friday, Mr Justice Supperstone dismissed Bob Dennettrsquos application for an injunction preventing the company from fracking the UKrsquos first horizontal shale gas well pending his proposed legal challenge.Hydraulic fracturing ndash or fracking as it is sometimes called ndash is the long established process of creating fractures in rock formations to release the natural gas trapped inside. To learn more about the process visit https:t.co yThsIHYqBpic zJnuYZpgRBmdash CuadrillaOctober , Mr Dennett claimed Lancashire County Councilrsquos emergency response planning and procedures at the site were inadequate, but the judge ruled there was not a ldquoserious issue to be tried which would justy an interim order.In a statement after the ruling, Cuadrilla chief executive Francis Egan said: ldquoWe are delighted to be starting our hydraulic fracturing operations as planned. We are now commencing the final operational phase to evaluate the commercial potential for a new source of indigenous natural gas in Lancashire.ldquoIf commercially recoverable, this will displace costly imported gas with lower emissions, signicant economic benefit and better security of energy supply for the UK..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Fracking due to begin at Lancashire site

title: sears-files-for-chapter-11-bankruptcy-amid-plunging-sales-and-massive-debts
story: US retail giant Sears has filed for Chapter  bankruptcy protection, buckling under its massive debt load and staggering losses.The company began as a mail order catalogue in the s, featuring items from bicycles to sewing machines to houses. It began opening retail locations in  and expanded swtly in suburban malls from the s to s.Ruth Parrington, of the Chicago Public Library, studies early Sears Roebuck catalogues But the onset of discounters like Walmart created challenges for Sears that have only grown and it faced even more competition from online sellers and appliance retailers like Lowersquos and Home Depot.The operator of Sears and Kmart stores began to incur massive losses, joining a growing list of retailers that have filed for bankruptcy or liquidated in the last few years.A Sears department store in Brooklyn, New York Some like Payless ShoeSource have had success emerging from reorganisation in bankruptcy court but plenty of others have not, including Toys R Us and Bon-Ton Stores, both of which collapsed after a Chapter  filing.ldquoThis is a company that in the s stood like a colossus over the American retail landscape, said Craig Johnson, of retail consultancy Customer Growth Partners. ldquoHopefully, a smaller new Sears will be healthier.Given its sheer size, Searsrsquo bankruptcy filing will have wide ripple effects on everything from already ailing landlords to its tens of thousands of workers.The filing, ahead of the crucial Christmas shopping season, comes after rescue efforts engineered by chief executive and chairman Eddie Lampert have kept it outside the bankruptcy court mdash until now. Mr Lampert, the largest shareholder, has been loaning out his own money for years and has put together deals to prop up the company, which in turn has benefited his own ESL hedge fund.The bankruptcy filing comes just before the crucial Christmas shopping period Last year, Sears sold its famous Craftsman brand to Stanley Black  Decker following its earlier moves to spin off pieces of its Sears Hometown and Outlet ision and Landsrsquo End.In recent weeks, Mr Lampert has been pushing for a debt restructuring and offering to buy some of Searsrsquo key assets like Kenmore through his hedge fund as a  million US dollar debt repayment falls due on Monday. Mr Lampert personally owns % of the companyrsquos shares. His hedge fund has an .% stake, according to FactSet.ldquoIt is all well and good to undertake financial engineering, but the company is in the business of retailing and without a clear retail plan, the firm simply has no reason to exist, said Neil Saunders, managing director of GlobalData Retail, in a recent analyst note.Edward Lampert, left, personally owns % of Sears shares Searsrsquo stock has fallen from about  US dollars over the past year to below the minimum  US dollar level that Nasdaq stocks are required to trade in order to remain on the stock index. In April , shares were trading at around  US dollars. The company, which once had , workers, has seen its workforce shrink to fewer than , people as of earlier this year.The company has racked up . billion US dollars in losses, excluding one-time events, since its last annual profit in , according to Ken Perkins, who heads the research firm Retail Metrics LLC. It has had  years of straight annual drops in revenue. In its last fiscal year, it generated . billion US dollars in sales, down from more than  billion US dollars in .As of May, it had fewer than  stores, down from about , at the end of last year. The number of stores peaked in  at ,, including its Sears Canada ision that was later spun off.A Sears store schedule for closure in Overland Park, Kansas In a March  government filing, Sears said there was ldquosubstantial doubt that it would be able to keep its doors open mdash but insisted its turnaround efforts would mitigate that risk.But its losses continued into this year. In the fiscal second quarter ended August , net losses in the quarter swelled to  million US dollars compared with a loss of  million US dollars in the same quarter a year ago.Such financial woes contrast with the promise that Mr Lampert made when he combined Sears and Kmart in , two years after he helped bring Kmart out of bankruptcy. Back then, it operated , stores in total.Mr Lampert pledged toSears to greatness by leveraging its best-known brands and its vast holdings of land, and more recently planned to entice customers with a loyalty program. But it struggled to get more people through the doors or to shop online.Sales at the companyrsquos established locations tumbled nearly % during its fiscal second quarter ndash an improvement from the same period a year ago when it fell .%. Total revenue dropped % in the most recent quarter, hit by continued store closings..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Sears files for Chapter  bankruptcy amid plunging sales and massive debts

title: qa-whats-known-about-saudi-journalists-disappearance
story: Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi disappeared almost two weeks ago while on a visit to the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul.His disappearance has sparked an international uproar involving the kingdom, Turkey and the United States that remains unresolved.Mr Khashoggi, a Washington Post contributor, had written columns critical of Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the kingdomrsquos war in Yemen and its crackdown on activists and businessmen.Turkish officials say they fear a team of Saudi agents killed and dismembered Mr Khashoggi, and they have released surveillance footage of the alleged perpetrators and mysterious movements outside the consulate on October , the day he entered.The kingdom says the allegations are ldquobaseless but has offered no evidence Mr Khashoggi ever left the consulate.Here is a look at what we know about the disappearance.Who is Jamal Khashoggi Jamal Khashoggi writes for the Washington Post Mr Khashoggi is a long-time Saudi journalist, foreign correspondent, editor and columnist whose work has been controversial in the past in the ultraconservative Sunni kingdom. He went into self-imposed exile in the United States following the ascension of Prince Mohammed, now next in line to succeed his father, the -year-old King Salman.Mr Khashoggi was known for his interviews and travels with Osama bin Laden between  and , including in Afghanistan, where he wrote about the battle against the Soviet occupation. In the early s, he tried to persuade bin Laden to reconcile with the Saudi royal family andhome from his base in Sudan, but the al-Qaida leader refused.Mr Khashoggi maintained ties with Saudi elites and was viewed as a link between the West and the often opaque royal court. As a contributor to the Post, Mr Khashoggi has written extensively about Saudi Arabia, including criticising its war in Yemen, its recent diplomatic spat with Canada and its arrest of womenrsquos rights activists after the lting of a ban on women driving.What happened to him Mr Khashoggi, whose th birthday was on Saturday, went to the Saudi Consulate in Istanbulrsquos th Levent neighbourhood on September  seeking documents so he could be married to his Turkish fiancee, Hatice Cengiz. He was told toto the consulate on October  to pick up those documents, Ms Cengiz says.Surveillance footage later aired on Turkish state television shows Mr Khashoggi walking into the consulate at .pm on October . A little less than two hours later, surveillance footage shows several vehicles with diplomatic licence plates move from the consulate to the consulrsquos home some . miles away.Ms Cengiz, who spent hours waiting for Mr Khashoggi outside while holding his mobile phones, says her fiance never walked out of the consulate to meet her. Surveillance footage shows her pacing around outside at .pm, speaking on her phone. No footage made public so far has shown Mr Khashoggi walking out of the consulate.What is Turkey saying Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, right, and Saudi Arabiarsquos King Salman embrace each other in  Turkish officials, speaking on condition of anonymity to discuss the investigation, say they fear Saudi Arabia killed Mr Khashoggi. They claim they have audio and video recordings of Mr Khashoggi being interrogated, killed and dismembered. However, no such recordings have been released publicly so far.Turkish security officials, rather than holding news conferences, have leaked information through pro-government media. Newspapers published the names and photographs of  Saudi men in the countryrsquos military and security services who are said to have formed an ldquoassassination squad sent to target Mr Khashoggi. Turkish officials told The Associated Pressone of those men was a post-mortem expert.Turkish media have also released a series of videos, apparently taken from surveillance cameras, showing the alleged Saudi agents arriving on private jets the day Mr Khashoggi disappeared, checking into and out of hotels near the consulate, and then flying out that night.A Turkish newspaper also claimed that Mr Khashoggirsquos Apple Watch recorded audio of his slaying and transmitted it to his iPhone outside the consulate and to his iCloud account. However, the newspaper did not explain how the alleged recording was transmitted and included a claim that Mr Khashoggirsquos assailants used his finger to unlock it when such watches do not have fingerprint ID scanners.Turkish officials have not responded to questions from the AP about Mr Khashoggirsquos Apple Watch. Analysts have suggested Turkey may be trying to protect its intelligence-gathering methods by leaking information this way.What is Saudi Arabia saying It is amazing how the #Saudinarrative has changed. They are not even trying to prove that they are innocent! This is not a priority for them as it seems! Instead, they resorted to threats to face any possible actions  measures against them in #Khashoggirsquos case. pic ZVZusyMbdmdash Dr. Ali BakeerOctober , Saudi Arabia has offered no explanation for how the writer could have left the consulate and disappeared into Istanbul as his fiancee stood outside waiting for him.Early on Saturday, Saudi interior minister Prince Abdulaziz bin Saud said: ldquoWhat has been circulating in terms of supposed orders to kill him are outright lies and baseless allegations against the kingdomrsquos government.Meanwhile, Saudi media has tried to blame the crisis on Qatar, which the kingdom and three other Arab nations now boycott as part of a bitter political dispute, without offering proof of that countryrsquos involvement. The Qatar-funded satellite network Al-Jazeera has extensively focused on Mr Khashoggirsquos disappearance over the last week.A Saudi-owned satellite news channel, meanwhile, has begun referring to the alleged -man team as ldquotourists, without providing evidence to support the claim.What is the US saying Donald Trump has threatened Saudi Arabia with lsquosevere punishmentrsquo President Donald Trump has threatened ldquosevere punishmentauthorities determine Saudi Arabia was behind Mr Khashoggirsquos disappearance. However, he has also said he wants to maintain the arms deals he struck with the kingdom on a trip to Riyadh. Meanwhile, American politicians are threatening to sanction inidual Saudi officialsevidence links them to the writerrsquos disappearance.What happens next A Saudi team has arrived in Turkey to investigate Mr Khashoggirsquos disappearance. Meanwhile, Turkey has said it will search the Saudi Consulate for evidence, but that has yet to happen. Turkeyrsquos foreign minister Mevlut Cavusoglu said on Saturday that Saudi Arabia had not yet co-operated with Turkey on the search for Mr Khashoggi. That could force Turkeyrsquos hand in leaking more information about the case to pressure the kingdom to co-operate..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: QA: What us known about Saudi journalist us disappearance

title: Festival guests left feeling cheesed off call for a refund
story: The Big Cheese Festival, which was held at Hove Lawns yesterday, has been branded a "shocking experience" byguests, with some saying they counted no more than two cheese stalls.Several social media users said they left the festival feeling cheesed off and are now calling for a full refund.Charlotte Bliss, from Eastbourne, said: "The cooked cheese items also amounted to no more than three stalls with huge queues."I am appalled that this was allowed to be called a cheese festival."I also purchased another ticket at the gate."I will never attend another event like this in Brighton."In an email to the events organisers seen by The Argus, another guest, Flora Adam, said: "I attended the event this afternoon and am extremely disappointed."The event was in no way as advertised and had very little stands compared to what was promised."Only a few hot foot standswith no raclette cheese or fondue as detailed in your numerous Facebook promotions."Stands were unprepared for the event and after queuing for  minutes we were told that halloumi fries were unavailable at about .pm."The gouda stand was running out of cheese as we left at pm."Again, nothing as advertised and well overpriced at pound for two people."I believe trading standards in this instance havent been met and request a full refund."Facebook groups have even been set up criticising the event, including one titled The their way around the Main Stage Tent, creating that incredible Festival Atmosphere."We would like to express our sympathy toward some of our amazing cheese and cheesey Street Food Traders who were
