title: Clearances tourist trail idea hailed
story: A TOURISM trail which would highlight the impact of the notorious Clearances on the Highlands, while also generating increased tourism for the region, has won the backing of a Ross-shire MSP.Gail Ross, the SNP member representing Caithness, Sutherland and Ross, praised the idea as a great way to educate the wider world about the huge effect the Clearances has ndash not just in Scotland but in fuelling the Scottish diaspora across the globe.She said: "There has been several ideas proposed for a trail for tourists and locals which would tell our story of the atrocities that happened during the Highland Clearances and I think the time is right to turn these proposals into reality.""Tourism is a vital sector in the Highland economy, however, Irsquom worried that at present wersquore not giving enough information to visitors to come to our area and really explore."More research onof stay is needed, but anecdotally communities throughout the North are concerned that the NC is more of a race than a tourist route, with visitors spending very little time, or money, in our communities."The trail would be excellent not only in economic terms, but also to educate people of the traumatic past of the Highlands."Irsquom concerned that the Clearances are being simplistically seen as purely a consequence of lsquoeconomic improvementrsquo as opposed to the brutality and sadness of the times."Communities were wiped out overnight, whatever the reason for this, they should not be forgotten.""A trail would enable visitors and locals to see for themselves the communities which were lost as a result of the clearances and encourage folks to spend more time getting to know the precious past of the Highlands."Monday  Oct  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Disruptive works at Stromeferry are progressing well
story: HIGHLY disruptive roadworks near Stromeferry are "progressing well" and should be complete by around November , Highland Council has revealed.Contractors are currently carrying out work to shore up the clf face above the A in a bid to tackle the arearsquos notorious landslip problems. But the work is very intensive and requires the repeated closure of the vital road link multiple times every day.A road-rail ersion onto the neighbouring railway tracks has been created to allow key through-access for cars but this can only operate during gaps in rail services ndash causing serious disruption to drivers who miss those windows. At peak times the queues waiting for a window can stretch back  cars in each direction.Highland Council has now given an update on the worksrsquo progress, and urged the public to plan their journeys carefully to avoid missing one of the windows when the ersion is operating.Cllr Allan Henderson, the chairman of the councilrsquos environment, development and infrastructure committee, said: "We have worked closely with Network Rail and our contractor to keep disruption to road users to a minimum when the road rail ersion is in place but inevitably there will be times when road users will face longer waits so we urge people to plan their travel carefully."Questions and answers about the works have also been published online following public meetings. They are available at www.highland.gov.ukMeanwhile, Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch MSP, Kate Forbes, has called for train services between Strathcarron and Kyle to be suspended during the works to reduce the disruption. She said bus replacement services would have less of an impact than the road closures.She said: "Itrsquos been well documented that the current convoy system is having a hugely detrimental impact on pupils attending Plockton High School as well as local businesses."The situation is far from ideal. I believe a better solution is that ScotRail and Network Rail should terminate all trains at Strathcarron and for a bus replacement service to operate and call at all stations between Strathcarron and Kyle. This would allow the road to rail section to be open whilst works continue on the rock face."Monday  Oct  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Invergordon set for housing boost after council buys land
story: A "BRIGHT future" awaits an Easter Ross town after a swathe of land was bought by Highland Council to create up to  new homes.Invergordon is set for the housing boost on land at Cromlet, lying to the south of Harbour View.Describing the news as "so exciting", Councillor Maxine Smith, said she had long campaigned for new housing for the town."We could be looking at council houses, Albyn houses, LIFT houses, as well as mid-market rentals and private housing. I see a bright future for the town, now things are starting to move forward," she said.This was echoed by long-serving Invergordon hairdresser Sharon Mitchell. She agreed more houses were desperately needed but said more shops must follow because the town centre was sorely lacking its yesteryear "buzz"."It used to be thriving here but itrsquos Alness thatrsquos thriving now. If theyrsquore going to be building more houses we need more shops."The celebrated land deal cost pound,.The council said this was funded through grants from the Scottish Government.A spokeswoman said no decision had been taken as to the timescale for development or of the mix of tenure for the land, which is identied within the Inner Moray Firth Development Plan as having capacity for  homes,She said it is likely that the development will include housing for mid-market rent and shared equity as well as housing for social rent by the council or Albyn Housing Society.Ms Mitchell, who has been running Sharonrsquos Unisex Hair Studio on King Street for more than  years, said the council should make the homes available for purchase under a LIFT Scheme, known otherwise as a Low-cost Initiative for First Time Buyers.Under this shared equity scheme, of which there are two dferent models, the Scottish Government is this year providing pound million to help people buy a home, within certain price thresholds, for sale on the open market. It also can help people buy a new-build home from a council or housing association.Ms Mitchell said: "A LIFT scheme would be the best. The majority of my younger clients are saying theyrsquore still staying at home with their mums and dads and trying to save and getting nowhere."Or a few friends have clubbed together and are renting a place because they canrsquot afford to live on their own."Cllr Smith, who has been campaigning for new homes for Invergordon, is overjoyed with the move.She said people want to live and rent social housing in Invergordon, but some also want to buy privately."To this end I managed to include two new housing sites in the Inner Moray Firth Local Plan a few years ago. These were the northern end of the Cromlet site, opposite the rugby club and the farmland at Davidson Drive, surrounding the farm buildings."Both landowners were approached and the latter is under discussion."She added: "Invergordon has so much to offer in terms of employment, both atthe base and industrial estates, as well as the cruise sector, which is growing, but people need a decent roof over their heads."By encouraging inward-migration and moving around within the town we also encourage the economics to grow, so more people means more people in the town shopping and more new shopping ideas popping up as there would be people to use them."In latter years, Invergordonrsquos population has settled around the  mark, whereas Alness has grown to just over ."It is time this balanced-out and allowed both towns to be more equal in terms of shopping experiences."Monday  Oct  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Port of Cromarty Firth hails its best ever year
story: THE Port of Cromarty Firth recorded its best ever year in , with almost pound million in turnover, it reported.Its annual review reports a total turnover of pound. million last year, pound million higher than its previous turnover record in .The strong results will allow the port to continue to invest in major developments, such as the new quayside and laydown space, which is in the planning stages for construction through  .A ersication from its core business of oil and gas to renewables, decommissioning and cruise and a higher number of vessels than expected resulted in the improvement.Bob Buskie, its chief executive, said: "At the start of , with low oil and gas prices, we knew the port had to adapt to sustain our growth and help keep local people in work."Firstly, supporting our core customers in oil and gas was a key concern. After the necessary consultation, we introduced a new pricing for statutory dues in January , which meant an average five per cent reduction in fees for most clients, supporting them through the downturn."Secondly, the port had to look to the future and see what we could do to help sustain jobs and growth."This is where our ersication strategy came in, with  seeing us undertake a project to introduce decommissioning to the port in an open port policy, where our supply chain could bid for work under our licences."The pound million investment in our phase three quayside and laydown area in  , allowed us to bid for renewable energy work. The largest project for this new berth was in support of the pound. billion Beatrice Offshore Windfarm Project."The port was awarded two contracts by Seaway Heavy Lting for laydown space, berthing and office space to support the -turbine wind farm. These contracts will run until the end of ."The cruise liner market continued to be a success story in , with the port being named as the busiest in Scotland. It welcomed  ships and more than , passengers ndash a  per cent increase on . The direct spend from passengers is put at pound million.The port has outlined plans to build a new multi-use berth development to provide modern facilities and to accommodate the largest cruise ships currently being built around the world.The port also ran two workshops, in conjunction with the cruise companies and Highlands and Islands Enterprise, to help local businesses understand and work with this lucrative sector. A cruise stakeholder group was also established to help improve logistics and communication.POCF board chairman Douglas Russell said: "The portrsquos record-breaking year was not without its challenges. We started the year on a low as the price of oil and gas remained depressed and as our core market suffered, so did we."It is a remarkable achievement that we ended  on a high, which was down to the huge amount of hard work delivered by the entire staff, and a measured ersication strategy that was developed by the portrsquos senior management team."Monday  Oct  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Tain road junction options set to be discussed
story: SAFETY options for improving two junctions in Easter Ross could be on the table next month following fears someone will die in a horror car smash at one of the black spots.MSP Rhoda Grant demanded to know what steps were being taken to allay the communityrsquos safety concerns over the accident-prone junctions close to Asda and Lidl at Tain.Transport Scotlandrsquos roads director Hugh Gillies responded this week indicating police may need to take a tougher stance on speeding and overtaking.He also said video survey results were being fed into a study which sets out safety options, and which should be available by the end of next month.Mrs Grant was pleased Transport Scotland "is taking this very seriously"."It has taken into account not only safety performance but video surveys of both junctions to see exactly what is happening," she said."These surveys have highlighted any near-misses or conflicts as well as incidents which have happened to increase the risk of a collision without necessary appearing in personal injury accident records."The agency has assured me that on-going work at the junctions remains a high priority."Local MP Jamie Stone was also buoyed by news saying it was a welcome change after what he described as "a blanket refusal by the Scottish Government to recognise that there was something seriously wrong".There have been calls for a radical rethink to prevent fatalities at the junctions for several years. A recent smash near Tain ndash which has numerous accesses onto the busy A ndash sparked demands from Westminster, Holyrood and Highland Council representatives for safety measures to be introduced.Monday  Oct  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Top cop staggered over driving offences
story: A DRIVER clocked at mph in a mph zone on the A on the Black Isle was among those nabbed during a police clampdown on illegal driving.Police in the Highlands and islands dealt with  drivers over ious road traffic offences during the first week of the road safety initiative Operation Cedar .There was particular focus during the first seven days on the Ross and Cromarty area.Offences detected included driving under the influence of alcohol, speeding, driving without insurance and driving while using a mobile phone.Eighteen drivers were dealt with for speeding offences ndash including the driver exceeding the limit on the A on the Black Isle. A report will be submitted to the procurator fiscal.Five people were dealt with for drink driving. The others were caught driving while using a mobile phone, no insurance and no MOT.Chief Inspector Iain MacLelland, lead officer for the Highlands and Islands Operation Cedar said: "The fact that drivers from across the region continue to place the lives of themselves and other road users at risk while driving under the influence is staggering."From the weekend past, across the Highlands and Islands we arrested eight drivers for driving while under the influence of alcohol and one while under the influence of drugs. Some of these drivers were more than five times the drink-drive limit."These arrests demonstrate that some from among our communities have a clear disregard towards the safety of others and need to be stopped."The dangers of drink driving are well publicised ndash you are not only putting your own le and livelihood at risk but that of every other road user."We have seen too many lives lost following collisions and my message to people across the Highlands and Islands is do not tolerate drink driving."You can pass on any information you have on drink drivers by calling  ndash or  in an emergency. If you want to remain anonymous, you can also contact Crimestoppers online or by calling   ."The enforcement work in Ross and Cromarty this week has involved local officers and from roads policing responding to concerns in our communities on a range of road traffic issues."Where we identy drivers who present a clear risk to the safety of other road users, we will enforce legislation and remove vehicles from drivers."This enforcement work will continue across the Highland and island area as we work to challenge, educate, detect and reduce injury collisions. title: Tranquility in mind for new garden space
story: A garden aimed at boosting the recovery of adults who have experienced mental ill health was officially opened during a special event and Macmillan coffee morning.Several dozen people attended the opening of Companas Cottage garden in Alness High Street amid sunny weather that helped to show the garden off in all its glory.Sally Mackintosh, a senior project worker based at Companas Cottage with Support In Mind Scotland, said: "We had more than  people attending."The Support in Mind Scotland area manager Bruce Armstrong spoke about how inspired he has been by the hard work and skills of the service users, especially John, who have worked so hard on transforming the garden for all to enjoy."Councillor Carolyn Wilson performed the ribbon cutting for us and praised John and other service users for all their immensely hard work in turning the garden from an overgrown tangle into a peaceful and beautul space."The Macmillan coffee morning went extremely well, with everyone munching their way through their body weight in cakes and pastries and we have sent pound to Macmillan as a result."Companas Cottage is a resource centre for adults recovering from mental ill health and offers a range of self-management and recovery focused courses, educational programmes, activities and social opportunities. It works to improve confidence and coping skills so that those with mental ill health can manage it more easily and move on to lead fulfilling lives.The centrersquos clients not only wanted to transform the garden into a tranquil place that will benefit large numbers of people, they also wanted to do something to boost Macmillan. title: Treasure found in a 1 box of goods
story: AMATEUR antiques collector Simon Grech took a punt when he spotted a box of bric-a-brac at Dingwall Auction Mart on sale for pound.But the Highland Council community warden was stunned to find buried beneath the chipped crockery and tea pots a beautul slate box hand-made by a -year-old African prisoner more than  years ago while he languished in a camp during the Boer War.The artefact, which has the prisonerrsquos initials SJP Venter scratched on its underside and is inscribed with the name Bellevue Kamp and the dates  and , is being snapped up by a notable London specialist.The expert, who collects Boer War memorabilia, has offered Mr Grech pound for the box, which is engraved with a South African folk flower mot and topped with an intricate quail bird.Mrs Grechrsquos we Marianne, who traced details about the boxrsquos original owner, said it was a "really exciting find".She said: "Simon likes to visit the Dingwall Auction Mart because he collects and fixes clocks."He came home with this box and the prisoner of war box was stuffed inside. It caught my eye so we did some research and it seems to have been made by a -year-old prisoner who was locked up in the Bellevue Kamp for prisoners of war in Simonstown, South Africa, during the Boer War."But we donrsquot know what happened to him or how the box came to be in Scotland, and we would love to find out."The couple, who stay at Balnacraig Road at Dalneigh in Inverness, contacted The Anglo-Boer War Museum in Bloemfontein, the only museum in the world dedicated solely to the Anglo-Boer Wars of  to , and they gleaned some interesting information.A historian told the couple a large number of Boers were captured in the vicinity of the Brandwater Basin in July and August of .A quick run through the names on the Bellevue Kamprsquos prisoner database reveals that Stephanus Johannes P Venter, a -year-old man from the Wepener District, was captured at Fouriesburg in July .But the young prisonerrsquos fate may never be known because no more details are held.The historian described the item as "a beautul slate box" and said it had signicant historical importance.Mrs Grechsaid it was a good thing Mr Venter had scratched his name on the box."Irsquod never have tracked this poor young guy right down to the day he was captured," she said.Praising her husbandrsquos nose for buried treasure she said: "Hersquos done really well. Hersquos only been going to the auction mart for a few months, itrsquos just a hobby, but he came back with a painting of The Alps for pound which Irsquove had valued at pound."However, she said some of his other finds were rather more questionable."The other week he bought a piano. title: Tribute to tragic dad raises thousands for charity
story: A BLACK Isle family left devastated after their -year-old son took his own le last year weeks after the birth of his son have raised thousands of pounds for suicide support lines in a fundraising drive.Wendy and James Mulleryrsquos son James, a father-of-three, was struggling with anxiety and depression.The Cromarty-based couple, together with Jamesrsquos partner Jodie, launched a fundraising campaign and a support group to help others.There has been a positive response from people facing similar trauma.The threesome, joined by friends of James, climbed the highest mountains of England, Scotland and Wales within  hours in what is known as the Three Peaks Challenge.They raised pound., of which pound went to the Inverness suicide support helpline called Mikeysline and the remainder was donated to The Campaign Against Living Miserably, a leading movement against male suicide.Mr Mullery , a commercial waste manager for Highland Waste Services in Invergordon said the challenge, completed on June  was emotionally tough.He said: "It was when we got to the third peak that it really hit me."We raised a bottle of beer to James. We just remembered him and talked about him, it was quite emotional all the way down."It was a very hard thing to do but also very rewarding and at the end of it we raised a lot of money for good causes so something good is going to come out of this."The family set up Jamesrsquos Support Group, a monthly meet-up at the Mercure Hotel in Church Street, Inverness for anyone affected by bereavement or who is supporting someone who is suicidal. Anyone wanting more information about the support group meetings can call   .Mikeysline founder Ron Williamson said he was "very grateful" for the donation.The next meeting of Jamesrsquos Support Group is on Sunday, October  at pm.Monday  Oct  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Word has it that laughs are on their way
story: The Word on the Street Festival celebrating female writers and comediennes will kick off in Dingwall with an evening of comedy and slam poetry on Thursday, October .The Ross-shire Club in the townrsquos High Street will host a troop of Highland comediennes, including Hazel Urquhart and Jenny Johnstone while local slam poet Danielle Quist and award-winning performer Catherine Wilson will also be on hand to wow with their words.On Friday, October , Highland-based authors, Barbara Henderson, Helen Sedgwick and Cynthia Rogerson, will read from their work and discuss the opportunities and challenges for women writers in the north today. A writing workshop with published writer, Sherry Morris, follows to encourage Highland writers.The festival will also feature the work of Dingwall Yarn Bomber Sharon Scobbie, an artist working with fibre who will transform the High Street with her unusual yarn art on each day of the festival. To get a sneak preview of what may be in store, you can see some of her work on display in High Flight Books.Festival organisers said they were particularly proud to be holding hold these events to mark and celebrate the -year anniversary of some women getting the right to vote.As well as the marvellous works of the women, organisers promised an appearance from a superhero ndash known locally as Alexander Donaldson ndash on Saturday, October , the final day of the event.
